TrackingIssues.Author: tsenart
TrackingIssues.Title: Cloud 2020-09-23 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### Cloud

We plan to complete all functional changes necessary to have individual Sourcegraphers (teammates) be able to add public code on sourcegraph.com. This is part of our first Cloud milestone as documented in [our team page](https://about.sourcegraph.com/handbook/engineering/cloud). All work items on this goal are labeled with `RFC-211` and `team/cloud/milestone-1`.

#### Security

For Cloud Milestone 1, in addition to the functional changes above, we need to complete the necessary work to store relevant secrets securely (i.e. encrypted). Even for public code, it's important that we store teammates access tokens in an encrypted fashion. All work items on this goal are labeled with `RFC-214` and `team/cloud/milestone-1`.

Additionally, we have some miscellaneous security bugs to address, marked appropriately with ğŸ”’ in the Work section below.

#### Backend infrastructure

**RFC 167: Generate new licenses with versioned tags** is small enough and we can get the benefit of new licenses already being versioned, minimising the migration effort needed by the sales team later. The remainder of the work in RFC-167 accounts for roughly 2 weeks and we tentatively plan to take it on in the next cycle.

We'll also work on a number of customer issues and tech-debt, marked appropriately with ğŸ‘©  and ğŸ§¶ in the Work section below.

### Availability

**Period**: 23rd of September until the 6th of October (10 working days)

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

- @ryanslade: 24th of September (1d) 
- @daxmc99: 28th of September (1d)
- @unknwon: 1st until 8th of October (4d)

### Work

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: Bazel Aspect-dev: building the frontend
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Aspect Migration Plan

- PNPM pre-factor
- Convert gulp generation steps to Bazel build targets 
  - schema
  - graphQlSchema
  - graphQlOperations
  - cssModulesTypings
- Build & bundle @sourcegraph/web with Bazel 
- Jest test examples (including jest snapshots) 
- Demonstrate fast development round-trip with webpack devserver
- Demonstrate optimized fast CI
- Demonstrate BUILD file generation

More detail is in their  notes doc:
https://hackmd.io/@aspect/By-gEU4Ni

<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: team/devx --> 
<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: bazel --> 

## Process

@ Aspect: creating any issue and tagging it with `aspect-dev` will bring it to this issue automatically. Our usual workflow is to only tag issues, and have PRs to close the issues. 

See this page for more info: https://handbook.sourcegraph.com/departments/engineering/dev/process/tracking_issues/

For the reviewers, you can tag @jhchabran, @valerybugakov 

## Resources

- [Bazel @ Sourcegraph](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HYbaYz9GAhjfHKCMgxi8O3Zi6n3uDkezR3pETxjtO8g/edit)
- [Sourcegraph / Aspect.dev](https://docs.google.com/document/u/2/d/16CcBg9dEK1SwmdXHAzKqQmhcIH3jpB_bwAB7KJC_ETc/edit)

## Plan

### Sourcegraph

- [ ] Eliminate circular dependencies to unblock the Bazel integration.
    - [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/45978
    - [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/45979
    - [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/46115
- [ ] Migrate from `yarn` to `pnpm`.
    - [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/45970
    - [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/45990
    - [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/45991

### Aspect

_TODO Aspect (plan as you see fit)_

TrackingIssues.Author: CristinaBirkel
TrackingIssues.Title: Insights Tracking Issue: Investigate testing at strategic scale
TrackingIssues.Body:
Currently there's no way for us to test Code Insights at strategic scale. (500k repos, 50GB monorepo, 60k users.) I imagine this will be needed across all teams, so we may not need to own setting up this sort of environment? But we'll still need to set up tests to hit things like:
- Many concurrent users fetching insights/dashboards from the API
- Many concurrently created series that all need to be backfilled (we could maybe do this manually? If we're not targeting thousands of series running at a time? We probably want to figure out what our goal here is, for how many insights can be created in a day or something.)
- Once our database is filled up with huge numbers of insights/series/points, is there performance degradation when fetching?

This is something to start thinking about right away so that we're ready to test improvements as they come in. And it's really important to prioritize because otherwise we'll be flying blind and won't be able to confidently tell customers that things will work at their scale.

### Tracked issues

<!-- BEGIN ASSIGNEE:  -->

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: logging(gitstart) tracking issue: migrate graphqlbackend to use sourcegraph/log
TrackingIssues.Body:
<!-- FOR THE ISSUE CREATOR -->
<!--
  1. Replace **X hours** with your estimate in the "Time estimate" section. Use a P50 cost estimate. (_P50_ means there is a 50% probability the work takes more than the estimated time, and 50% probability that it takes less.)
  2. Add a created issue to the board: https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/206.
  3. Use the `important` label if the issue is urgent.
  4. Issues placed higher in the "To do" column have higher priority.
-->



## Problem statement

<!-- Describe the problem and why it is important to solve it, point to external resources. -->

The `graphqlbackend` layer in Sourcegraph's `frontend` service has a lot of log15 usage. As a core entrypoint to many parts of Sourcegraph, having this layer migrated could help speed adoption of the new logging library.



## Success criteria

<!-- List all changes required for this issue to be completed. -->

All 85 usages of log15 in `cmd/frontend/graphqlbackend` are replaced with usages of appropriately scoped loggers.

https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=context:global+repo:%5Egithub%5C.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph%24+file:%5Ecmd/frontend/graphqlbackend+log15&patternType=literal

## Implementation details

Most usages here fall in one of two places:

1. a `resolver` struct function
2. a helper function

In case 1, the resolver struct should hold a reference to a `log.Logger`. In case 2, the helper should accept a logger parameter.

## Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: BolajiOlajide
TrackingIssues.Title: Implement Role-Based Access Control (Tracking)
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Problem statement

Customers expect us to have the authorization on the API implemented (product gap â€œInterservice authenticationâ€ from one of the customers). This is standard across the industry but we are not enforcing it. 
Not being able to define fine-grained access to several resources limits customers from enabling some features on Sourcegraph like [Batch Changes, because they donâ€™t want just anyone to be able to make bulk code changes across multiple repositories](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/34491).

### Problem validation / why

Some customers are blocked from enabling features like Batch Changes because we don't have an access control system.
Examples of customers that are currently **blocked**:

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/579
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/1
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/3
>There's no way we're going to give x,000 engineers the ability to deploy changes across all our repositories

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/8243
Also, see [product gap](https://sourcegraph2020.lightning.force.com/lightning/r/Product_Gap__c/a1B5b00000MwQNZEA3/view).

See [RFC 747 Role-Based Access Control](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mCg5-GiqRuBx2Hrls8lrYEfPMlzuZHmUQ4rCJd0JLeg/edit?pli=1#) for current candidate

TrackingIssues.Author: DaedalusG
TrackingIssues.Title: WIP: src-cli users clean
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
This is a project to bring a python utility script `users_clean.py` into the main project under `src`. Currently the CE team often provides this utility script to customers as a bandaid for cleaning up users for license seat reasons. 

The script to be emulated: https://github.com/sourcegraph/customer-assets/blob/main/ce-tools/pysdk/cleanup_users.py
_Thanks @mike-r-mclaughlin !_

### Tracked issues

Working branch: 
https://github.com/sourcegraph/src-cli/tree/users-clean

- ğŸ‘© Customer issue
Users need to be able to remove users in a single command based on usage, this will help to maintain seats for an accurate number of users

- ğŸ™† Stretch goal
- specify hard removal and soft removal
- send emails to removed users

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: monitoring: panel API redux tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

@pecigonzalo I believe this also covers a note you added:

> Enable the full grafana SDK functionality for panel configurations
>
> We would like to be able to fully customize panels to adapt to the type of information being display.

IMO we should instead enable better iteration on the useful defaults we provide in the generator (discussion: https://github.com/sourcegraph/about/pull/2000#discussion_r523027773) instead of _full_ customization of panels (we will have #15873 for that instead)

That said, we should:

* Enable some more options on the current API where appropriate
* For more drastic departures from our current panels:
   * Identify other types of data that aren't line-graph-time-series that we want to support panels for (the recent Cloud dashboards are probably a useful reference for what some teams might want)
   * Design & implement an API for opting in to different types of panels 

How panels are currently generated:

* API: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/tree/main/monitoring/monitoring#type-observablepaneloptions
* Code: https://k8s.sgdev.org/search?q=repo:%5Egithub%5C.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph%24+file:%5Emonitoring+for+_%2C+row+:%3D+range+group.Rows+%7B+:%5B_%5D+%7D&patternType=structural

TrackingIssues.Author: malomarrec
TrackingIssues.Title: Per batch change control for pushing to forks (Tracking)
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Context

We have recently introduced the possibility to push branches created by Batch Changes to a fork of the repository, rather than the repository itself. 

This was built as an [MVP](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/17879) to address:

- Most users do not have write permission on all repositories, so branch creation fails for them (https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/544)
- Some companies _enforce_ that all PRs created by automation are opened on forks. (https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565, https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/4778 )

### Problem
The current MVP state is the end state solution for companies that mandate using forks for all repositories. It's not a fully mature solution though for users that don't have write-permission on all repositories and only want to use forks in some cases. In particular:
- not all users want to use forks
- a given user wants to use forks, but only for a specific batch change
- a user wants to create forks, only if they're missing permissions
- site admins aren't aware of the fork setting, or don't set it up, resulting in  https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/40922 not being solved despite the current minimal fork support (e.g. https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/544)

#### Impacted customers

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/6859 ([insight](https://sourcegraph.productboard.com/feature-board/2104383-batch-changes/notes/22661534))
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/544
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/6716
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/7485

### Next iteration

- Introduce a `fork` attribute, allowing users to specify the fork
- The site admin setting`enforceForks` allows admins to force that all branches are created on forks.
  -  TBD: Add a UI message that surfaces this to the user? "Some changesets have been created on a fork because ..."
- Allow forks to be deleted when a Batch Change is closed or deleted (Source Control hygiene)

The `fork` attribute behaves in the way proposed by @LawnGnome  (whose legacy lives on forever):

```
changesetTemplate:
  fork: foo           # forks into the `foo` organisation/user, assuming the
                      # user has permission
  fork: LawnGnome     # forks into the user's namespace as well (assuming the
                      # user is LawnGnome), but explicitly by name
  fork: user          # forks into the user's namespace, same as the current
                      # switch
```

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: sashaostrikov
TrackingIssues.Title: 1-click export MVP Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

This is a tracking issue for 1-click export project MVP. Related discussion can be found here: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/discussions/37930

This issue can be considered closed when the MVP version of the project is implemented and 1-click export can be successfully used in production.

Due to its nature, 1-click export feature is easy to extend (by adding new processors which fetch additional data about SG instance), that's why this tracking issue is not intended to be open until 100% of 1-click export functionality is developed and on the contrary tracks the progress of an MVP version implementation. Every future extension (GH issue) can be linked to this issue and implemented separately, out of the scope of this tracking issue.

TrackingIssues.Author: attfarhan
TrackingIssues.Title: Search: 3.18 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan 

Our Q2 OKRs are:
 * allow users to search across contexts of their organizationâ€™s code as outlined in RFC 136.
 * Sourcegraph.com WAU grows by 5x to N6 WAU.

The problems we want to solve this iteration:

1. New Sourcegraph users are not given onramps for successful onboarding.

    **Solution: provide a guided way for users to search relevant repositories via repository groups pages.**

2. Sourcegraph is missing familiar search features found in alternative solutions like OpenGrok. These missing features have [actively turned away potential users and customers](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=22555917):

    > I use them [boolean operators] every single day and the lack of support in Sourcegraph immediately disqualified it for us.

    There is a longstanding history of requests for this feature and it is a clear gap in our product [[1](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/7154), [2](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/7154#issuecomment-564713240), [3](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/1005#issue-380986675)]
    **Solution: implement full hierarchical search with AND/OR queries behind a feature flag.**

3. Customers have asked us for a solution to search across older versions of their code. These code states live on, because they map to enterprise releases that are still being used by their customers. Some of these requests come from customers  that have been on OpenGrok previously, and have spun up multiple OpenGrok instances to allow them to search old versions of code. They want to use Sourcegraph, but want a seamless solution to do so.

    **Solution: enable indexing on non-main branches so searches using version contexts are fast. We have built the version contexts feature without indexing in the previous iteration.**

### Availability

Period is from **June 22** to **July 17** (20 days). Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- @attfarhan : 15d (out July 6 - 10)
- @rvantonder: 19d (I will likely take 1 or 2d off between July 11 and July 24, but not committing to this yet).
- @asdine: 20d 
- @keegancsmith: TODO

### Workload

TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

TrackingIssues.Author: malomarrec
TrackingIssues.Title: Track batch change from Code Insights
TrackingIssues.Body:
One of our goals at Code Graph is to make the power of our features [easier to find and use](https://handbook.sourcegraph.com/strategy-goals/strategy/code-graph/#make-the-power-of-our-features-easier-to-find-and-use) and to enable [end to end workflows](https://handbook.sourcegraph.com/strategy-goals/strategy/code-graph/#user-focused-workflows).

It'd be great for Batch Changes to be more integrated with Code Insights. It can work both ways:
- How a Code Insight can be the starting point for a batch change is tracked in https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/31693.
- We could also make tracking a batch change from an insight much easier. The ideal end game is to be able to track Batch Changes progress from a batch change. This is not as easy as it sounds, as today, Code Insights can only track a search query, and changesets are not indexed or available as search query results.  But there are likely easy steps we can take to make this happen iteratively.

## Measure of success

This feature is successful if it increases Insights usage. We should ideally track the # of insights created from this feature.

## Plan

The proposal is to downscope this to the minimum feature that brings value to the user. One way to view this is that, after a batch change is merged, the number of hits of the `repositoriesMatchingQuery` decreases. Whilst the ideal scenario is to track the status of the changesets of a batch change, it still creates immediate value to the user to track the search results used in a batch change.

- [ ] #32010
- [ ] Associate a batch change with an insight, for example having a "tracked in" linking to a code insight, and vice-versa
- [ ] Track batch changes PRs from insights

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Code Intelligence 3.21 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

**Goal:** Get the top three most popular language indexers: lsif-go, lsif-java, lsif-clang stable by working directly on implementation with customers to identify and resolve any remaining issues that prevent the tool from being use in a wide release. This goal takes top priority for this milestone and each member of the team is leading the initiative on an indexer. 

**Goal:** Improve the reliability and the precise code intel backend by migrating data away from SQLite and into a more suitable database, Postgres.

**Goal:** Improve best effort auto-indexing for supported languages (see issues related to RFC 201).

### Availability

Period is from 2020-09-20 to 2020-10-20. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

* Aida: 10d
* Eric: 19d (off 2020/09/28-30)
* Noah: 21d (off 2020/10/02)
* Garo: 10d (off 2020/10/05-09)

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: â­ Q4B1: Observability
TrackingIssues.Body:
# Observability Bet Q4 ## Problem Since the introduction of OpenTelemetry in 4.0 we still do not have a good grasp on our tracing observability. We still send a large amount of traces, so much so that Honeycomb and Grafana Cloud have: * Rate limited us (Grafana cloud) * Dropped our large spans (Grafana cloud) * Notified us of large spans (Honeycomb) * Notified us of breaking our quota (Honeycomb) In terms of being rate limited and busting our quota, we addressed this by adding a Tail Sampler to the otel-collector. Even with the tail sampler weâ€™re still sending a large amount. Which means we still havenâ€™t addressed the source. We also need to reduce the amount of providers we use for observability. Today, across all environments we send metrics, logs and traces to:
Provider What Environment
GCloud Metrics, Logs, Traces Managed instances (cloud), dotCom, Scaletesting
Grafana Cloud Traces, Logs CI, dotCom, Dogfood
HoneyComb Traces, Metrics CI, dotCom
Jaeger (Bundled) Traces Dogfood*, S2
Grafana (Bundled) Metrics Dogfood*
As per above table, we can see there is a big overlap with the providers that we use for dotCom, which is also our largest spender. **Recently Grafana cloud has been â€œdeprecatedâ€ and we need to move from it ASAP**. With the move, we should also consolidate on one preferred provider, at least for dotCom. _As a side note: A few engineers have mentioned that they quite enjoy using Honeycomb._ ## Scope For this bet we are removing the use of Grafana Cloud. We also want more control over our tracing. With more control we want to be able to enable and disable tracing easily and have a good idea about our size and rate of traces that we send. ## Boundaries * No additional overall spend for observability * Same version of otel-collector * No additional tracing * Update configuration regarding tracing * For the CI pipeline, we only want to handle the pipeline case of uploading logs * CI pipeline is not significantly interrupted with the move away from Grafana Cloud * We can add metrics regarding our tracing and spend ## Definition of Done * We have a single provider (outside of cloud) for all our observability and have made everyone aware of the single provider * We have an answer for our send rates regarding our traces * We know why we produced big traces/spans * We are able to identify the source environment of a trace * We have a dashboard with alerts set indicating our spend and quotas * The handbook is updated with our preferred observability provider * We are able to control our tracing through configuration * Any configuration changes are documented ## Payout * We have a preferred observability provider which we use in all our environments * We donâ€™t encounter warnings, alerts regarding the rate and size of our traces and spans * We are alerted if our trace rate has increased and we will hit our budget/quota * We are still able to troubleshoot and provide metrics of our CI * Our Grafana Cloud usage and spend is 0. ## Approach * We consolidate on one provider for all of our environments outside of cloud * We introduce more tracing configuration to allow us more control * Add metrics to our tracing to better observe how the feature is behaving * Update the CI pipeline to stop using Grafana Cloud and switch to Honeycomb/Gcloud ### Tracked issues @unassigned - TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: GraphQL Client adoption: Batch Changes
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
Weâ€™re looking to increase adoption of Apollo Client across batch changes components.

The aim of this issue is to identify and eventually improve areas that:
- Would benefit from serving cached data. High-traffic areas where data is unlikely to change whilst the user is on the page.
- Would benefit from refactoring data fetching logic into a shared API. Some examples may be complicated RxJS code that could be abstracted, or usage of FilteredConnection that has proven difficult to modify previously. 

### Useful resources
- Migrating from `requestGraphQL | queryGraphQL | mutateGraphQL` usage to [useMutation and useQuery](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/client/shared/src/graphql/graphql.ts?L127-157) hooks.
- Utilising the [Apollo cache](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/graphql#how-do-i-use-the-apollo-cache) by adding the correct `id` fields to queries or providing alternative [keyFields](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/caching/cache-configuration/#customizing-identifier-generation-by-type) to use.
- Migrating from `FilteredConnection` to `useConnection` and abstract FilteredConnection UI components: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/commit/037dc8022ae8e0368e07131856c684715b731a1e

Please use this issue to discuss and identify these areas. Will create follow-on tickets to track implementation.

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Worker tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

This issue tracks progress of moving the background-tasks out from the frontend and repo-updater services. Because engineers knew how these services were deployed, it made it very easy for the answer to "where does this code go" to be "put it in the background of the frontend/repo-updater" more than it should have been.

Original POC can be found [in this old PR](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/21537).

Similar discussions/goals:
- [Sunset repo-updater](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/16197)
- [Isolate code intel background processes](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/18253)

### Availability

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: DevInfra: Test Quarantining Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

  - Introduce a mechanism to distinguish quarantined tests from the normal ones (tags?)
    - It must be easy to quarantine a test: `sg test quarantine [--remove] //my/target` perhaps? 
    - Create a GitHub issue on the fly?
  - Exclude quarantined tests from the main test jobs and run them in a separate job (soft-failing?)
  - Weekly report about the quarantined tests
    - Newly added tests 
    - Warning about upcoming disabled tests
    - Ping EM of tests target owners

TrackingIssues.Author: kalanchan
TrackingIssues.Title: DevX: Q2B2 GCP cost savings
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Problem
Dotcom and preprod were largely over provisioned as at the time multi-tenancy was the prioritized strategy for Sourcegraph. Now that Cloud (Single tenancy) is the new strategy, there is a huge opportunity to tune our infrastructure for cost and performance. 

### Scope
An [GCP spend analysis](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1FQScUkS6fyBfW__dG0WiHmXH6-Fl_4zWwMTY9IWASSI/edit#) has been completed, and there is an opportunity to reduce our cluster size by up to 50%. This could translate to $30000/month in savings. Further tuning can be made to each service itself to find a balance between spend and performance.

- **Boundaries**
  - Soucegraph dotcom and preprod for now
  - Other workloads and GCP projects can be analyzed in the future for further cost saving opportunities
- **Definition of done**
  - Being able to reduce cluster size without impacting SRE and performance
  - Ability to show cost savings from month to month basis
- **How**
  - Utilize GCP Cost optimization tool for [dotcom](https://console.cloud.google.com/kubernetes/workload/cost?project=sourcegraph-dev&pageState=(%22savedViews%22:(%22i%22:%227f5175881a074fc49c9aeb7780f4ea3c%22,%22c%22:%5B%5D,%22n%22:%5B%22prod%22%5D))) and [preprod](https://console.cloud.google.com/kubernetes/workload/cost?project=sourcegraph-pre-prod)
  - Extract monitored usage from [Kubecost](https://github.com/kubecost) (usage current being logged, need ~15 days to get clearer picture)
  - Once targetted CPU/Mem ratio has been identified, make changes to infrastructure and deployments files
  - Follow approach in [scratch doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_Q5FuspJJNXF6EYKh4yKut7w9IXPQugu1Q0eRyW_oMA/edit#heading=h.etirvf439bq7)

TrackingIssues.Author: jjinnii
TrackingIssues.Title: Code navigation: Code Mirror design support tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

We've observed latency issues with the file view rendering and popover that makes the Sourcegraph file navigation experience feel slower and less snappier than comparable products. CodeMirror is a new implementation of the file blob view that improves the performance of the file view and popover. 

Before we can ship CodeMirror, there is a need to: 

- Ensure that CodeMirror has no unintentional differences in the UI/UX. CodeMirror is an implementation detail, not something that should impact how our user's navigate our files
- Intentionally review improvements to the UX that can be made with CodeMirror and carefully implement for a first release 


### Tracked issues

- [x] #40542 
- [x] #40724 
- [ ] #41187 
- [x] #41975

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: Metrics, dashboards, and alerting export tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body: Our firm stance at the moment that custom metrics/alerting backends are not supported: [Can I consume Sourcegraphâ€™s metrics in my own monitoring system (Datadog, New Relic, etc.)?](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/admin/faq#can-i-consume-sourcegraph-s-metrics-in-my-own-monitoring-system-datadog-new-relic-etc). This is a [significant product gap](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C033PDEV740/p1652339586898659?thread_ts=1652167767.937359&cid=C033PDEV740). The situation is historically because our monitoring components are highly customized: - Dashboards and alert rules are generated by the [monitoring generator](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/observability/monitoring-generator) and are not easy to export, and are heavily tied to Grafana/Prometheus - Alerts are delivered by a [bundled Alertmanager deployment](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/observability/prometheus#alertmanager) that is operated by an embedded service called [prom-wrapper](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/observability/prometheus#prom-wrapper), which integrates with Sourcegraph site configuration to apply [alert settings](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/admin/observability/alerting#setting-up-alerting) and deploy highly customized templates tailored to alert rules: To detach all this, some general ideas would be: - Identify what custom Prometheus configuration we apply, and how to generalize metrics export for other o11y backends that remain compatible with our dashboards and alert rules - For example, [executor observability configuration](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/admin/deploy_executors#configuring-observability) - Identify how to generalize dashboard generation for other o11y frontends - Identify how to generalize alert rules generation for other o11y backends - Identify ways to make the alerting integration via prom-wrapper optional/seamless to detach - Explore feasibility of [OpenTelemetry metrics](https://opentelemetry.io/docs/reference/specification/metrics/) ### Tracked issues #### Legend - ğŸ‘© Customer issue - ğŸ› Bug - ğŸ§¶ Technical debt - ğŸ© Quality of life - ğŸ› ï¸ [Roadmap](https://handbook.sourcegraph.com/departments/product-engineering/process/planning-process#roadmap) - ğŸ•µï¸ [Spike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spike_(software_development)) - ğŸ”’ Security issue - ğŸ™† Stretch goal

Goal 2: Store and handle external service and external account secrets securely.

### Availability

Period is from July 20th to August 19th (23 working days). Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- **@chayim**: 19d (off Aug 10-13)

TrackingIssues.Author: vovakulikov
TrackingIssues.Title: `Reactstrap` migration Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Background

For historical reasons, we've been using reactstrap components a lot. We primarily use them for our product's Modal, Popover, Combobox, and Menu UI. This was a good decision back then, but now we're moving towards the wildcard components. In this project, we want to remove reactstrap package from our dependencies and migrate all consumers that currently use `reactstrap` for their UI to the `wildcard` component. 

## Why 

Basically, we have two reasons that make this migration vital.
- **Consistency**. We've been fighting with different component implementations a lot. Some time ago, we created the wildcard package where all reusable components should live. They should have clear documentation and should implement our design system. Reacstrap is yet another implementation in our codebase that confuses engs a lot; they usually have to answer questions about what I should use and How I should implement something with given shared components. Since reacstrap components don't have any guidelines or docs around how average engs should build UI with them, these components introduce more chaos than clear, well-documented structure in our codebase.
- **Bundle size**. Reactstrap isn't a cheap package from a bundle-size perspective. Even if we're using subset of reactstrap components, it greatly increases our initial bundle size. For example `Dropdown`, `DropdownItem`, and `DropdownMenu` are the most popular reactstrap  components in our codebase (it brings around 80kb just itself without sub deps) pull a bunch of thrid party packages like
  - `popover.js`around 105kb
  - `react-transition-group` around 50kb

TrackingIssues.Author: mrnugget
TrackingIssues.Title: Source tracking issue: Distributed Rate Limiter v2
TrackingIssues.Body:
## [Goal](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UWqNJsQoTmqreNqQw8X0Rqe1_FbDhidqcWy0UPHfN_I/edit)

- Admins don't get confused by it
  - "I don't want to send more than X request to this given server"
- Developers at Sourcegraph don't have to worry about rate limits again

## Milestones/Tasks

- Move rate limits to the per-URL limit
  - (soft) introduce a code host entity
    - can be as simple as: A dictionary from a URL to a rate limit config

- Live in the HTTP CLI so that integrators with external services never need to worry about it or could forget it
  - Should there be a bypass?
  - The same should be true for the GitHub.com singleflight lock

- Once we are in the HTTP CLI, it would be great to have an HTTP grafana dashboard to see what services we wait on, how many requests, and so forth

- Wrap up removal of GitHub Proxy

- Consolidate setting names and move them onto the right entities
  - `siteConfig.gitMaxConcurrentClones` is not across gitservers, make it distributed
  - Rename `gitMaxCodehostRequestsPerSecond` to operations. Also, per second is a bad metric, doesn't allow less than 3600 an hour
    - Move it to the set of limits defined per code host as well
  - Consider moving `siteConfig.repoListUpdateInterval` into the code host connection config
  - Maybe make rate limit burst configurable?
  - Do *NOT* support per code host connection rate limits anymore

### Plan

For each team who reached us to perform testing at scale, we want to make sure they can perform at least an experiment on their own. Our role is to support them by removing roadblocks and adjusting their goals toward what we can provide at this stage. 

We are to provide support and gather feedback from their attempts. 

- What do they want to test 
- What went well 
- What went bad 
- What they'll need next

TrackingIssues.Author: caugustus-sourcegraph
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue - Health Status Tooling
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

[SDD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1shS8DZkZXMB-T4rKwLMogU70N4mSyOpDG1G7ElkjHD4/edit#heading=h.5owhf6uyyp03)

We want to offer admins a simple way to evaluate the health of a Sourcegraph deployment.

### Requirements 
* Define a list of technical health checks that validate deployment is healthy
* Ship a prototype health status tool that provides validation that everything is set up properly. The prototype should assess the following:
  * Can services talk to each other as expected
  * Is the disk configured as expected (i.e., each replica has a separate location defined, etc)
  * Is the disk and network performing as expected
  * Can the instance communicate with the code hosts
* The tool should work for Kubernetes deployments (w/ or w/o Helm)
* The tool should render health status in a visually simple way via CLI (think stop sign colored updates). For an example please see [this Reddit post](https://www.reddit.com/r/ethstaker/comments/n3nyv8/valid8r_cli_for_easy_validator_health_check/).
* Ship documentation on remediation efforts or troubleshooting best practices. The documentation should be descriptive enough to assist customers/CEs debug at each level of the health check. The documentation should address both Yellow and Red output statuses.
* Share this tool with CE to validate with select customers

### Plan

âš ï¸ TODO: reshape further 

  - I'm debugging some stuff, I want to see the logs for Gitlab 
    - It's a PITA. Can't I get that in my cloud-loggings logs for my instance?
  - [linked to testing] Gitlab can be deployed ad-hoc to isolate tests
  - [linked to testing] GitHub GHE (and Bitbucket) is not the same. But can't we create a "materialized context" 
    - start your test 
      - some service gets you a user (you get a receipt of your resources) 
      - you use that user to create repos
      - end of your test: some service kill your user and drop your resources (thanks to the receipt) 
    - this is heavy work, this should be really evaluated in terms of impact

TrackingIssues.Author: jtibshirani
TrackingIssues.Title: Intelligent search ranking beta
TrackingIssues.Body:
This issue tracks our plan to use the code reference graph to improve search ranking. High-level summary of the initial implementation:
1.  Introduce a code intel job to compute + store the number of inbound references to a file
2. Update search ranking strategy to incorporate this new signal, and to sort all results by file scores (instead of bucketing by repo)

### Implementation
#### Code intel

- [x] Compute a global reference count for each file, by traversing the entire code graph
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47985
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47987
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47989
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47994
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47997
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/48002
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/48004
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/48008
- [x] Load test implementation with entire code graph from dotcom
- [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/48578

#### Search
- [x] Combine ranking signals
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/523
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/546
  - Better normalization for file reference signal
    - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/48387    
    - https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/553
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/555
- [x] Improve search result determinism
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47649
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47931
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/543
- [x] Consolidate configuration
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/46953
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47135
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/48164
- [x] Ensure new ranking strategy is exercised in integration and e2e tests
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/537
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/545
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/47781
- [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/48588

### Rollout preparation
- [x] Identify 1-2 customers who want to try out new ranking
- [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/48970
- [x] Improve observability
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/49043
  - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/49275
- [x] Docs for beta customers

### Open questions
- Every time new file ranks are computed, we reindex all associated code. We don't want to reindex customer code too often -- can we find a reindex cadence that balances freshness and reindex cost?
- Could ranking files based on the number of inbound references have a bad effect, where important files (like the main app) are given a low ranking? Make sure to test and make necessary adjustments.

/cc @sourcegraph/search-core

TrackingIssues.Author: mrnugget
TrackingIssues.Title: Core Services: 3.8 Tracking Issue & beyond
TrackingIssues.Body:
# Planning 3.8 and beyond

## Main questions:

- What will break with 80k repositories?
- What's the delta between the current state of Sourcegraph and the state that would close current deals in our pipeline?

## 3.8

- TomÃ¡s: Improve ACL performance
    - [#4812](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/4812) - Global Repository Permissions Caching (@tsenart)
- Thorsten: Improve site-admin experience
    - [#5145](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5145) - Use streaming in repo-updater to make syncing process more responsive
    - [#5146](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5146) - Make external service syncing errors visible to site-admins 
- Keegan:
    - Assisting and helping out the search team with architectural decisions & design process
    - Improve Zoekt performance
      - Horizontally scaling Zoekt
      - (If time permits: single-node performance, see _Beyond_)

## Tickets & Bugs & misc

- ~Fix Quinn's issue with `EXTSVC_CONFIG_FILE` setting: [#5134](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5134)~
- ~Allow configuring external service with `orgs` (do not require `repos` or `repositoryQuery` to be set if `orgs` is set): [#4322](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/4322#issuecomment-519176161)~
- Customer issue: `repo-updater "failed to run repository clone purge"` (the `<>` bug)
- Fix gitserver purging process: introduce "mark & sweep process". [#5056 and comment](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5056#issuecomment-518551181)
- Querying repository by name with github.com prefix always returns empty string for name: [#5125](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5125#event-2540430023)
- Gitolite EOF: [#5119](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5119)
- Gitolite not cloning: [#5121](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5121)
- GitHub Oauth scope: [#5111](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5111)

## Beyond

### Zoekt

- Investigate, understand, tweak and improve **concurrency model**
- Introduce shard compaction to improve read performance (Inspiration: Cassandra + SS Tables)
- Bloom filters in main process to avoid looking into shards that won't yield results
- Improve memory usage
- Experiment with more efficient posting lists in Zoekt https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/10
- Improve parsing of newlines in Zoekt

### Frontend/Zoekt

- Improve memory usage by getting rid of "list of 80k repos". Send IDs instead

### Others

- Improving **gitolite** performance: large-scale customer reported that it takes gitolite **27 min** to list all repositories (that is: without Sourcegraph being involved at all, it's pure gitolite)
- Determine resource allocation "equation" and update docs for admins to provision them accordingly for their Sourcegraph installation (e.g. https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/scaling-bitbucket-server-776640073.html)

## Ideas for far future

- Index commit diffs (diff search right now is unindexed)
- Automation

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: DevInfra: CI Observability Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

  = use gcp for everything 
  - Infra related metrics and alerts
    = Use opsgenie to trigger incidents
    - Agents: resource usage across time + alerts (disk, memory, cpu) 
    - Agents: queuing time + alerts
    - Agents: cost reporting
  - Build related alerts 
    - Agent / Bazel Crashes 
  - Flakiness reports
    - Test targets metrics on `main` 
    - Test targets metrics on everything else
    - Test targets metrics per team
      - Find a mechanism to assign test targets to a given team
  - Usage metrics 
    - Builds across time, on both main and other branches 
    - Speed ...
  - Logs are uploaded to GCP cloud logging 
  - Logs are easily searchable 
    - We want to be able to easily find out if a given error has been happening a lot or not
  - Detect if failure is caused by code or infra related
    - don't use cody yet, just hardcode the few various cases where it's known to be infra (like OOM) 
  - Automated Weekly report 
    - How many builds, flakes per team, quarantined tests, etc ...
  - Track (code insights?) usage of GithubAction across the entire org

TrackingIssues.Author: malomarrec
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking: MVP - Lockfile-indexing-based dependency search
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Context

We're iterating ton a dependency graph workflow to help security engineering and development teams triage and remediate vulnerabilities faster. See the problem we want to solve in ([PD 35 WIP - Dependency Graph for code security](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Bq2SAx-FXxzW0YFbkIYoPS6bvy-LvlvZMyOTNUI1NV0/edit#heading=h.z5ozjpfzh2yl)).

### MVP

In the MVP, we want to let users navigate the dependency graph of their code in an iterative manner. Instead of just showing a flat list of dependencies/dependents for `repo A`, you can:
- see the list of direct dependencies/dependents of `repo A`
- see the list of transitive dependencies/dependents of `repo A` at depth `n`. Exact syntax TBD, eg.`dependencies:(sourcegraph depth=3)`.
- easily navigate along the `repo A` -> `repo B` -> `repo C` dependency/dependents path
- search for code predicates inside any of those scopes

This partially answer: "how is my code affected by dependency on `repo A`? What are optimal resolution steps?". It's a first step towards our goal to answer questions such as:

> Does my repo depend directly on X? If not, what dependencies of my repo bring X into scope?

In the MVP, we will focus on javascript, golang, python (in order), and Java/Maven because we can use lockfiles and already have a lot of building blocks ready. We want to move to Java/Gradle next, using precise code intel data, because that's what's most valuable to customers.

_UI is ultimate TBD, for illustration:_

![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25070988/173081457-2d0a1fa9-461f-4577-8150-634faf791fba.png)

Design discussions are happening in this [RFC](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1nRs20p_-ImyRXt9nZa5WjwJIaRfiXTyOYHOL6i1DFUA/edit#).

### Plan

TrackingIssues.Author: malomarrec
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue: Track and increase batch changes merge rate
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Background

The key measure of success for batch changes creators, as well as the platform team lead that champions for Batch Changes, is the number of batch changes changesets that get merged. 
Making our users successful can be broken down into allowing them to create batch changes for lots of scenarios, and making sure batch changes [changesets get merged](https://handbook.sourcegraph.com/strategy-goals/strategy/code-graph/batch-changes/#enterprise-scale).

## Problem to solve

Our users report that some batch changes never get completely merged, and remain in an incomplete state. This can be broken down into several subproblems:
- as the team lead, how do I view the total value that was created (# merged batch changes)
- as the team lead, how do I know what batch changes are making progress? what batch changes are stuck? also see https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/20738
- as the batch change creator, how do I stay on top of all my batch changes and analyze their progress?
- as the batch change creator, how do I make sure the target repository owners are aware of my changeset?
- how does a repository owner get notified, in their workflow, that the changeset needs to be merged?

Private [insights](https://sourcegraph.productboard.com/feature-board/2104383-batch-changes/features/12008251/insights) are tracked here.

## Measure of success

Increase 1-month merge rate from x to y.

## Solution summary

This is pending discovery and UX research
Work with Dudley if we create a dashboard that highlights value created on top of tracking and providing actionable ways to get changesets merged.

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/6859
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565

## Impact on use cases

This impacts all Batch Changes use cases, and in particular:
- Code Health
- Code Reuse
- Incident Response


## Delivery plan

Here are the issues that relate to this and could be good candidates:
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/32773
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/20738
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/32559
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/16078
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/34600

## Planned work

<!-- BEGIN WORK -->
<!-- END WORK -->

TrackingIssues.Author: beyang
TrackingIssues.Title: Cody tracking issue 2023-04-03â€“2023-04-17
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Plan
Early user feedback has indicated the following are important:

* improved context quality (context quality almost always dictates the accuracy of the Cody response).
* some also prefer a less chat-y, more code-search-y interface
* would like an easy way to insert a generated snippet of code into the right place
* fast autocomplete, triggers automatically
* VS Code is shipping new native plugin endpoints for an upcoming version of GitHub Copilot. We are investigating whether they are willing to open these up.

We also think it would help drive awareness if Cody lived in a separate repository that was completely open source.

```[tasklist]
### Features
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50448
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50281
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50344
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50507
```
```[tasklist]
### Bugs and other stuff
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50446
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50462
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50445
```

```[tasklist]
## Next cycle wishlist
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50459
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50273
- [ ] Abuse detection + blocking mechanism
- [ ] Factor out stuff in Go binary
- [ ] Toggle LLM backend endpoint, need to support both OpenAI and Anthropic, $CUSTOMER wants it
- [ ] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50713
- [ ] Self-hosted embeddings
```

TrackingIssues.Author: jensim
TrackingIssues.Title: Mount file on batch change steps containers
TrackingIssues.Body:
#### User outcome and current workflow

It's frequent for users to run complex scripts or internal tools in batch changes. To do so today, they gave two choices:
- bake the script/ or binary inside the step container. This is painful and slows down iteration as it requires to rebuild the container.
- Use [steps.file](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/batch_changes/references/batch_spec_yaml_reference#steps-files), which is also painful and slows down iteration. To convince yourself, paste a python script of a 100 line in a batch spec and fix the indentation :). 

#### Proposal

Allow users to mount a file (a script, a binary of an internal tool) on the batch spec container. This means the user can iterate on the file easily, without needing to copy-paste it inside the spec, or rebuild a container.

One thing we need to figure out is caching. If the spec does not change, but the file changes, we should invalidate the cache.

This is discussed in [RFC 560 REVIEW: Mount file on Batch Changes container](https://docs.google.com/document/d/146zr_cD2a6TEf2UJdmlq4_sOD_KzvZL-Le9eJUWMSZU/edit#heading=h.trqab8y0kufp)

#### Additional context

<!-- Add any other context or other information you'd like to provide. -->

#### Impacted customers (details in thread)

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/8202
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/1
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/537
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/544
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/278 (Use case: to replace all docker files by a specific docker file, `files:` is not convenient)
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/6859 because they need to run custom tooling, and it's currently brittle


### Delivery plan

- [x] #31790
- [x] #37216
- [x] #31791
- [x] #31792
- [ ] #31793
- [ ] #37751
- [ ] #41549
- [ ] #45278
- Make sure template UI supports template with mounted files

TrackingIssues.Author: tsenart
TrackingIssues.Title: devx: Feature flags UI/UX tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
We have a feature flag system in place that would certainly see wider adoption if its UI/UX would be improved. Particularly, toggling a feature flag [currently requires a GraphQL API call](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/how-to/use_feature_flags#create-the-feature-flag-through-the-graphql-api).

It would be great if we could have a site-admin page that lists feature flags and allows updating state as well. I could imagine us being able to quickly do that from `sg` as well.

TrackingIssues.Author: pecigonzalo
TrackingIssues.Title: Distribution: 2020.12.14 - Kickass Fly
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### [Support new and existing deployments](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/74)

This is an ongoing expense, we anticipate this taking no more than 5d of work spread across the entire team.

#### [Seamless Upgrades](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/71?card_filter_query=milestone%3A%22dist%3A+2020.12.14%22)

Re-synchronize our base with [sourcegraph.com](https://github.com/sourcegraph/deploy-sourcegraph-dot-com/) and add tests to components missing them.

- @ggilmore 
- @uwedeportivo 
- @daxmc99 

#### [Monitoring Redux](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/112)

Make our monitoring stack more compelling for engineers at Sourcegraph to interact with and build on top of. Support more use cases specific to the needs of engineers at Sourcegraph and Sourcegraph Cloud.

- @bobheadxi 
- @davejrt 
- @pecigonzalo

TrackingIssues.Author: thenamankumar
TrackingIssues.Title: Permission Syncs Dashboard: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

Currently, there is no way for site admins to monitor the permissions syncing, which works in the background. Debugging failed permission syncs is also not easy. We get our inspiration from the "Manage Code Host", "Repositories", and "Executor Instances" pages to build a similar dashboard for permission syncing. 

The initial version of the dashboard will include the following:

- [ ] Sync bobs listing (real-time via polling)
    - [ ] User/Repo details + link to their permissions info page
    - [ ] Status of job (success, in progress, failed)
    - [ ] queuedAt, successAt, failedAt, execution time
    - [ ] Reason type: manual, scheduled-*, webhook-*event
    - [ ] Count of new permissions added/removed and total number of permissions
    - [ ] Execution logs
- [ ] Stats
    - [ ] Queue Size
    - [ ] Total no of failures, success, etc TBD
- [ ] Filters
    - [ ] By user
    - [ ] By repo
    - [ ] By status
    - [ ] By trigger reason
- [ ] Actions
    - [ ] Clear Queue -> cancel all jobs in the queue
- [ ] Bonus TBD

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: tsenart
TrackingIssues.Title: Core Services: 3.12 Tracking Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Context

**Status**: This tracking issue is finalized.

### Availability (__59d__)

Period is the Dec 16th -> Jan 15th. Please put in the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period. Merry Christmas and a happy New Year! :santa: :christmas_tree:

Total availability, excluding @mrnugget, @ryanslade ([a8n](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/7129)) and @tsenart (management): 16 + 15 + 15 + 13 = __59d__

- @keegancsmith 12/24 - 1/1 OOO. 16 days available.
- @kzh Dec 23th - Jan 1st. 15 days available.
- @mrnugget OOO Dec 23th - Jan 3rd. Available Dec 16th to 20th (**5d**) and Jan 6th to 15th (**8d**). 13 days available.
- @rvantonder 12/24 Dec to  1/2. 15 days available.
- @ryanslade 30th Dec - 15th Jan (__13d__).
- @tsenart 16th Dec - 20th Dec (__5d__), 6th Jan - 15th Jan (__8d__). 13 days available.
- @unknwon (CST +8) 12/18 - 12/23 Part-time (= 2 working days), 1/3 - 1/15. 13 days available.

### Planned work

All planned customer issues, technical debt and roadmap items are meant to be finished in the iteration. If we don't finish all planned work, it is either due to unknown unkowns or our estimating accuracy. While we cannot work on the former, we can on the latter â€” over time, we aim to estimate better.

Roadmap items may take more than an iteration to implement. As such please link to an issue which is scoped to this iteration. IE the issue should be closed at the end of the iteration.

All issues listed need to have a number of days estimate attached. When setting days, try and overestimate the time needed. Do not use a granularity less than half a day. The total amount of work assigned to you needs to be about 75% of your available days.

- [x] Ability to filter out archived Bitbucket Server repositories [#5494](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5494) __1d__ [ğŸ‘©](https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/company/407948923)

TrackingIssues.Author: pecigonzalo
TrackingIssues.Title: Distribution 3.20 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### [Support new and existing deployments](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/74)

This is an ongoing expense, we anticipate this taking no more than 10d of work spread across the entire team.

#### [Support teams migration to per-team alerts](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/73)

We have enabled per-team alerts and on-call rotations on [3.19](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/11954), as teams onboard to this new workflow we will need to provide support and guide them through the transition.

#### [Reduce upgrade overhead](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/71)

We decided to move forward with the Dhall implementation and we will work on defining a roadmap for it **(spike)**. Additionally, we will work on a "`yaml-to-dhall`" and define a Dhall architecture that supports customizations **(spike)**.

- @ggilmore 
- @uwedeportivo 
- @davejrt 
- @bobheadxi 

#### [Enable failed e2e test notifications and blocking the pipeline](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/72)
Although we run the e2e tests daily, their failures are not visible to all which means at the end of the iteration we must ask teams to pitch in on short notice.
We will inline our e2e tests and notify engineers when a merge breaks our e2e tests to ensure our `main` branch is always in a working state.

- @slimsag 
- @davejrt 
- @pecigonzalo 

#### [Dogfood Kubernetes deployments](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/83)

Deployments to dogfood-k8s are automated from our latest images and reflect our customerâ€™s workflow. [deploy-sourcegraph](https://github.com/sourcegraph/deploy-sourcegraph) is kept up to date with our latest images. 

- @bobheadxi
- @pecigonzalo
- @ggilmore
- @slimsag

### Availability

Period is from **August 20th** to **September 19th (22 working days)**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- **Gonza**: 22d

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: RFC 740: Accept SCIP in the backend - Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

This issue tracks progress against the proposal [RFC 740: Accept SCIP in the backend](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PuTYmHYLElYKIEW0sSAAUbXf7XtnsMdEq3EshD-O7do).

This work changes our backend to accept SCIP payloads over LSIF, and store the data in an SCIP-centric way (instead of a way dictated by LSIF).

Benefits:
- SCIP is stored as a binary format, where LSIF is stored as gzipped JSON
- SCIP document payloads are deterministic (LSIF is not) and will allow us to deduplicate documents that did not change between index runs

This effort unlocks:
- The ability to add new data to SCIP (and be queryable from our product)
- This effort is a prerequisite to incremental indexing on the user/executor side

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: DevInfra: Local Env Improvements Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

  - `sg start` also fires up a structured log browser (loki?) 
    - Look into `logcli` https://grafana.com/docs/loki/latest/tools/logcli/
  - (stretch) `sg start` also always fire up the tracing?  
  - `sg start` shows panic very explictly
  - `sg start/run` uses Bazel for almost everything 
    - frontend being runnable this way depends on the work with ESBuild 
    - no target should depend on Bazel 
  - Install Comby through statically built release 
    - We may have to ship this one on our own (check the nix folks work)
  - Install universal-ctags through statically built release 
    - We may have to ship this one on our own (check the nix folks work)
  - Replace dev-private with a devx-service API call to download the latest config
  - Make asdf optional in `sg setup` 
  - Create a packaging mechanism so it's easy to just bump a tool version for the stateless agents
  - No CI job should require asdf 
  - `sg setup report` prints out all the local config, path, versions, of everything it depends on.
  - Install pre-commit (ask in `sg setup`) 
    - shellcheck
    - shfmt 
    - prettier

TrackingIssues.Author: ElizabethStirling
TrackingIssues.Title: Security 3.21 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

We plant to gain visibility into the attack surface of Sourcegraph components, in order to support hosting private code on sourcegraph.com. For this release our focus will be on container visibility.
<!--
Summarize what the team wants to achieve this iteration.
- What are the problems we want to solve or what information do we want to gather?
- Why is solving those problems or gathering that information important?
- How do we plan to solve those problems or gather that information?
-->

**Goal:** Increase visibility into the threat surface of our product by running automated vulnerability scanning, both of our code and of our docker containers. This goal is our top priority, since it will allow us to more accurately prioritize future work.

**Goal:** Centralize logging in order to allow for analysis of events across the Sourcegraph platform, rather than events as they're contained within a single microservice.

### Availability

Period is from 2020-09-20 to 2020-10-20. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

Elizabeth: 1d, (2020-09-25)
Chayim: 3d (2020-09-28, 2020-09-29, 2020-10-06)

### Tracked issues

<!-- BEGIN WORK -->
<!-- BEGIN ASSIGNEE: ElizabethStirling -->

TrackingIssues.Author: kalanchan
TrackingIssues.Title: â­ Q4B1: GCP Cost Saving Phase 3
TrackingIssues.Body:
Previous work: 

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/42154
- [GCP Cost Savings Bet phase 3](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HA1p-5EbqZvacRTQN5003C1nEDopUP6h2Jd96bFn5Pk/edit#)

## Problem

Continuation of previous [GCP Cost savings bet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iQwvnQBl_NzFB39xCarIpk-GQH6Q-EjDzWyVK7SroSw/edit#), there are still a couple key areas we can reduce spend on.

## Scope

We have used cookie cutter templates in the past that over provisioned our infrastructure; to reduce cloud cost and properly tune infrastructure we can work on the following:

- Identify services and deployments that are over provisioned using metrics to backup our reasoning
- Remove redundant or legacy infrastructure added in the past that creates overhead
- Work with other internal teams to understand how their services work and what is the proper deployment baseline
- Implement new tooling to help us control environments and reduce workloads

### Boundaries 

Sourcegraph dotcom and preprod 
Dogfood
Sourcegraph-CI 

### Definition of Done

- Reduce rest of dotcomâ€™s deployments
- Optimize buildkite to have less pods hanging around and efficiently spin up the right # of nodes
- Dogfood environment is operating at their minimal provisioning while still operating properly
- Assist finance in creating FY2023 and 2024 cost models


## Payout 

We have an opportunity here to save another $20k-$30k/month on dotcom, dogfood and CI. Our goal is to not just cut costs, but to correctly tune our infrastructure so that we arenâ€™t wasteful while still performant. These extra resources can be allocated to other parts of the company to help grow and sustain our business.

## Approach
We have the following areas to work on

Dotcom
- Work with search core and frontend teams to reduce CPU/Mem allocation for their services
- Integrate GKE backups and replace Velero
- Add node affinity for heavy workloads

Dogfood
- Continue cutting down resources until minimal environment is available
 
CI
- Understand and identify how the buildkite agent queue algo works
- Pack more jobs onto a node, and have less node hang time
- Reduce job agents in queue on weekends / low priority hours
- Research whether current custom VM is most cost effective

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: GraphQL Client adoption: Search
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
Weâ€™re looking to increase adoption of Apollo Client across search components.

The aim of this issue is to identify and eventually improve areas that:
- Would benefit from serving cached data. High-traffic areas where data is unlikely to change whilst the user is on the page.
- Would benefit from refactoring data fetching logic into a shared API. Some examples may be complicated RxJS code that could be abstracted, or usage of FilteredConnection that has proven difficult to modify previously. 

### Useful resources
- Migrating from `requestGraphQL | queryGraphQL | mutateGraphQL` usage to [useMutation and useQuery](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/client/shared/src/graphql/graphql.ts?L127-157) hooks.
- Utilising the [Apollo cache](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/graphql#how-do-i-use-the-apollo-cache) by adding the correct `id` fields to queries or providing alternative [keyFields](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/caching/cache-configuration/#customizing-identifier-generation-by-type) to use.
- Migrating from `FilteredConnection` to `useConnection` and abstract FilteredConnection UI components: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/commit/037dc8022ae8e0368e07131856c684715b731a1e

Please use this issue to discuss and identify these areas. Will create follow-on tickets to track implementation.

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Code Intelligence 3.22 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

**Goal: Provide precise code intel for the primary programming languages that combined cover > 50% of usage across customer projects**. Garo is forging ahead with lsif-clang bugs, and will aim to index 10 more open source repositories as preparation to ship to a wider audience. Noah is forging ahead with lsif-java features, and will aim to have Gradle support by the end of the milestone.

**Goal: LSIF indexers can operate in monorepos architecture**. Garo will be merging their work on incremental indexing into the main branch of the relevant repositories. After this is complete, we should be able incrementally index source code in customer environments (for at least Go) and accept partial indexes in the backend.

**Goal: Provide best effort auto-indexing for supported languages**. Eric will continue building out the auto-indexing infrastructure so we can provide a wide coverage of code intelligence in the cloud environment. By the end of the milestone we should have updated metrics and UI, and will deep-dive into errors we see currently in production to harden the system and make it more reliable.

**Uncategorized.** Eric and Maria will also be spending time updating metrics, pings, and documentation across the code intelligence feature space.

### Availability

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

@efritz 21d
@macraig 21d
@gbrik 14d
@Strum355 20d (26/10/2020)

### Tracked issues

<!-- BEGIN WORK -->
<!-- BEGIN ASSIGNEE: Strum355 -->
@Strum355

- [ ] lsif-java: Tracking issue ([#14564](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/14564))
  - [ ] Potential for numerous files to be missed on indexing ([#35](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/issues/35))
  - [ ] hovers for stdlib and cross repo symbols ([#54](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/issues/54))
  - [ ] Maven support ([#56](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/issues/56))
  - [ ] Javadoc links support ([#57](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/issues/57))
  - [ ] Java record hover text ([#66](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/issues/66))
  - [ ] Improve gradle project meta inference  ([#70](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/issues/70); PRs: ~[#74](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/pull/74)~)
  - [ ] Transform Javadoc hovers to Markdown hovers ([#76](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/issues/76))
  - [ ] WIP: Intercepting of javac calls with gradle ([#78](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/pull/78)) :shipit:
  - [ ] WIP: JDK 8 (+?) Standard Library Hovers ([#80](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/pull/80)) :shipit:
  - [x] (ğŸ 21 days ago) Gradle support ([~#42~](https://github.com/sourcegraph/lsif-java/issues/42))

TrackingIssues.Author: taylorsperry
TrackingIssues.Title: Improve engineering onboarding: tooling
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve
<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->

`sg` has become an integral part of engineering at Sourcegraph. There are several categories of issues that need to be resolved due to its rapid growth and adoption.

- New Sourcegraph developers end up being guinea pigs for our `sg setup` tool because we don't have an automated testing process in place, and similarly for some other features of the `sg`
- Features have been haphazardly implemented, and we may need to start implementing a better architecture internally to keep up with new features. This most noticeably applies to features that have multiple internal job/task types (`sg lint`, `sg generate`, `sg test`, etc.)
    - [`sg.config.yaml` is also nearing 1000 lines of configuration](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/blob/main/sg.config.yaml), which may become problematic.
- We may have outgrown the capabilities of the current CLI framework of choice, and would benefit from a more feature-rich framework that enables (for example) better feature discovery
- We have no visibility into feature usage, adoption, and feedback for `sg`
- Lots of rough edges could be improved: `sg doctor`, update experience, intro guide to `sg`, half-migrated tools - many tasks can (and are) still invoked both directly and via `sg`.

Issues with `sg` are becoming increasingly prominent and disruptive (e.g. many engineers fixing ) so it is important we tackle improvements to smooth out the experience and lay the groundwork for future investments.

## Measure of success

- `sg` features better suggestions, completions, and convenience features for improved CLI UX
- `sg` has robust internal frameworks for implementing lints, tests, and generate tasks
- `sg` has more robust features for getting started on "inner development loop": 
   - Integration testing of core features
   - Checks and generate tasks are unified across CI and local dev
- Reduced size of `sg.config.yaml`
- Feedback and analytics on `sg` usage

## Solution summary
<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artifacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

New teammates should be set up for success on day one of the job so that they can start contributing productively as soon as possible. 

Artifacts: none

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?
<!--
Reference customers by linking to their issue in our accounts repository. DON'T REFERENCE CUSTOMERS BY NAME!

Example:
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/537
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
-->

Sourcegraph developers

## Impact on use cases

<!--
Describe how this roadmap item contributes to improving the customer experience for one or more of the 5 use cases and apply the relevant use-case/* labels to this issue.

For enablement projects that don't target a specific use case, describe how you expect this work to enable teams/projects that are focused on use cases.
-->

## Delivery plan
<!--
The overall plan for how we are going to achieve this roadmap item. This should be formulated as a checklist of concrete steps that are kept up-to-date so anyone can glace at the issue description to get a sense of what we have already delivered and what remains.

Each item on this list is ideally a concrete deliverable with an estimated delivery date and owner, but we don't want false precision, so just document the plan to the best of your ability, even if you don't have all the steps yet.
-->

- [x] Identify roadmap of action items
- [x] Make `sg` approachable as it scales: completions, suggestions, unified documentation
- [x] Make development of tasks in `sg` easy to scale: framework migration, implementation of internal frameworks for testing, code generation, and scripting tasks
- [x] Migrate some shell scripts into Go-based implementations with `sg`: checks, code generation, misc. tooling
- [x] `sg setup` gets automated testing and also supports the use case of ensuring an environment stays up to date (automated fixes)
- [x] Unify linting tasks across CI and local dev using `sg`
- [ ] `sg` exports metrics indicating usage, timing, and error trends, and metrics are viewable in OkayHQ

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: mrnugget
TrackingIssues.Title: Core Services: 3.7 Tracking Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Goal

99th percentile latency of indexed search at 42req/s with 20k repos is under 2s.

## Availability

Team:
- Hackweek(s) **July 22nd - Aug 2nd** ([see details here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ljs7C3uB7Di6tfyUsKOHMuFHflrGQFC6quQR_SoOQ34/edit#heading=h.yahdutol4v38))
- @tsenart & @mrnugget in San Diego for GopherCon from **July 22th-27th**
- @tsenart, @mrnugget & @keegancsmith in Berlin for Core Meetup **August 5th-10th**

Invidividuals:

- @mrnugget: Not working **August 12th-16th**
- @tsenart Available
- @keegancsmith Available

## Background

A requirement for future work on Zoekt performance is to define a performance model of Zoekt's current architecture that allows us to predict Zoekt's performance to a certain extent.

After doing back-of-the-napkin math, we came up with the following formula:

"With N cores and M shards it can take up to X to search a single shard when aiming to do 42req/s (T)"

![IMG_4654](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1185253/61435859-cb446d00-a939-11e9-9997-7087955b54fa.jpeg)

With variables plugged in, that gives us:
- "With 384 cores and 30000 shards and 42 req/s it can take a maximum of 300us to search a single shard"
- "With 1 core and 30000 shards and 42 req/s it can take a maximum of 0.79us to search a single shard"

## Planned work

- [ ] Global repository permissions caching (#4812)
- [ ] Determine resource allocation "equation" and update docs for admins to provision them accordingly for their Sourcegraph installation (e.g. https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/scaling-bitbucket-server-776640073.html)
- [ ] Experiment with more efficient posting lists in Zoekt https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/10
- [ ] Scale Zoekt horizontally
    - [ ] Write proposal, derive implementation plan from it.

### Moar Ideas 
- [ ] Reduce contention in Zoekt
- [ ] Improve `indexData.simplify` in Zoekt
- [ ] Improve parsing of newlines in Zoekt
- [ ] Shard compaction
- [ ] Shard compression (are we I/O bound?)

TrackingIssues.Author: vovakulikov
TrackingIssues.Title: Chart API primitives Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

This project came up during this issue spike about chart API https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/40009#issuecomment-1251023014

**Start date**: TBD
**Due date**: TBD

## Quick recap of spike results
In the past 1-2 months, we introduced a lot props in the high-level charts. This stands against the high-level chart principle - "High-level chart doesn't support all possible cases but provides a simple good first data visualization".

This project's goal is making chart API more customisable and composable. For example 
```tsx
function ConsumerChart() {
  const xScale =  scaleBand<string>({ domain: ['category1', 'category2', 'category3'] }),
  const yScale = scaleLinear<number>({ domain: [0, 100] })

  return (
     <Chart xScale={xScale} yScale={yScale}>
        <ChartAxisLeft {/* Any consumer specific props */}/>
        <ChartAxisBottom {/* Any consumer specific props */} /> 

        <ChartContent>
              { content => <AnyConsumerSpecificContent {/* Any consumer specific props */}/> }
        </ChartContent>

        <ChartTooltip {/* Any consumer specific props */} />
     </Chart>
  )
}
```

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: Thorsten/DevX `sg setup` Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body: ### Plan (ported from https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/24900) The idea is that `sg setup` replaces the quickstart steps in our onboarding docs. Goal: `sg setup` installs databases, it sets them up, it installs dependencies, it asks users how they want to run X or Y, helps user setup `/etc/hosts`, etc. After that the user can run `sg start` to get a working dev environment. Inspiration: this [tweet](https://twitter.com/Nick_Craver/status/1375871107773956103) by a StackOverflow developer. ### Availability If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here. ### Tracked issues @unassigned: __1.00d__ -
