TrackingIssues.Author: chrispine
TrackingIssues.Title: Campaigns Sprint 1 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

Note: We have moved to 2-week sprints! This one is our first.

The main theme of this cycle is quality of life improvements for our users. Campaigns could be a lot easier to use! Many of these improvements will be around debugging a campaign, to shorten the cycle of â€œtweak the spec, apply the spec, see what went wrong, repeatâ€.

We also have several tickets that continue the theme of the previous cycle: bug fixing and polishing.

User feedback (from customers and internal folks) is driving our focus. We are also finishing up a round of formal user testing to further validate that we are focusing on the most urgent needs.

### Availability

Period is from Sep 21 to Oct 6, for 12 working day in total before branch cut.

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

@chrispine 3d (Sep 23-25)
@mrnugget 1d (Sep 25)
@eseliger 0d

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Code Intelligence Sprint 1 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

This sprint covers 2020/11/23 to 2020/12/04.

Owen, our team's new EM, will be starting 2020/11/23 :tada:. The team's priority will be to onboard Owen, discuss a hiring strategy, then get alignment on our goals and re-state them in the handbook.

Until we have a formalized plan, we have decided to concentrate on continuing work on auto-indexing (stability and observability) to ease adoption of precise code intelligence and build a massive open-source index, and on lsif-clang (making it more easily debuggable) so that the team can re-build expertise with the indexer.

### Availability

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

Owen: 8d (4x10 workweek)
Maria: 9d (out 2020/11/27)
Eric: 7d (out 2020/11/25-27)
Noah: 9d (out 2020/12/04)

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: Q3BX: Bazel proof-of-concept
TrackingIssues.Body:
See https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HYbaYz9GAhjfHKCMgxi8O3Zi6n3uDkezR3pETxjtO8g/edit#heading=h.e0xahoi7r2c7 

:arrow_right: This ticket is focusing on building POC to use Bazel.

The potential benefits of moving to Bazel are really high, but so is the cost. We need more clarity around that cost. If we don't do this, we won't be able to understand when such a move is best to be taken, at the cost of investing in solving problems that may be addressed by Bazel further down the line.

@rafax doesn't have the bandwidth to drive the POC, but he can support us, along with @olafurpg. A [slack channel](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C03LUEB7TJS) has been created for that purpose.

TrackingIssues.Author: mrnugget
TrackingIssues.Title: SSBC-EM2.1: Malo can use SSBC in a demo
TrackingIssues.Body:
Experimental scope:
> As a customer, I want to run a large batch changes, that I can parallelize on several executors so that they run faster. I'm fine with debugging with the CLI first. All I want to do is paste a spec, run it across executors,  be able to see the logs per repo/step, then go to preview/apply. I also want to be able to edit the spec and re-run it to correct mistakes.

Items:

- [x] One executor job per workspace (repository+path+commit)
  - [x] src-cli able to execute a batch spec in a given workspace (not doing resolving of workspaces at all) https://github.com/sourcegraph/src-cli/pull/608 @mrnugget
  - [x] Add the necessary workers in the backend to resolve a batch spec into workspaces and execute those https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/24749 @mrnugget
    - [x] Create `batch_spec_resolution_jobs`
    - [x] Create `batch_spec_workspaces`
    - [x] Execute `batch_spec_workspace_execution_job`, one per executor
      - [x] `batch_spec_workspace_execution_job` are executor-jobs etc.
      - [x] Each workspace-execution-job, if successful, creates a `changeset_spec` (from the JSON log line of `src-cli`) with correct `batch_spec_id` and stores `changeset_spec.id` on `batch_spec_workspace_execution_job.changeset_spec_id`
  - [x] Follow-up: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/24886 @mrnugget
  - [x] Follow-up: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/24965 @mrnugget
  - [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/24985 @mrnugget
  - [x] Remove old code `batch_spec_executions` @mrnugget
  - [x] Cancellation of `batch_spec_workspace_execution_jobs` https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/24893 @mrnugget
  - [x] Build and switch frontend UI to use new API @eseliger
    - [x] API schema and stub resolvers for SSBC @eseliger  https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/24966
    - [x] Implement `createBatchSpecFromRaw`/`replaceBatchSpecInput`/`executeBatchSpec` mutations @mrnugget 
    - [x] Implement workspace resolvers
    - [x] ~Fix the TODOs left in https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/25182/files~
    - [x] ~Implement rest of mutations...~
    - [x] Move parsing of log lines to backend
    - [x] ~UI: build workflow to create, preview, and then run a batch spec~
  - [x] Clean up non-executed workspaces, resolution_jobs. **Update**: We don't need to do this, since we want to keep batch specs around for now and use `replaceBatchSpecInput` to not amass a large number of specs.
  - [x] Switch dogfood executor to new queue @eseliger
  - [x] result from new graphql api: implement `validatechangesetspecs` https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/25547 @mrnugget 
  - [x] Implement "importingChangesets" to restore functionality. First version: in request, when creating batch spec, simply create imported changesets. @mrnugget https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/25397
  - [x] Ensure that only one `batch_spec_resolution_job` exists for the batch spec at a given time @mrnugget
  - [x] https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/25943 @mrnugget
- [x] Alpha customer deployment of `executor` @eseliger
  - [x] Improve deployment of executor
    - [x] Build AMI in CI for executor https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/23364
    - [x] Implement AWS support @eseliger
    - [x] ~Deploy new executor from CI~
    - [x] Generalize code-intel terraform stuff in infra repo https://github.com/sourcegraph/infrastructure/pull/2704
  - [x] Documentation for customers on how to deploy `executor` @eseliger
    - [x] ~Bare metal~
    - [x] Google Cloud
    - [x] AWS

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: All Sourcegraph components can easily raise runtime errors for debugging
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve

<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->

- Errors are not actionable: 
  - It's hard to understand without a lot of familiarity with the code that produced the error to understand if an error is a big problem or not. Transient errors are mixed up with big ones. 
- Noise is making the task difficult: transient errors are generating a lot of volume and makes it harder to diagnose the root cause. 
- Errors are potentially missing or not being reported: in some cases, an error is reported by a customer, but we're not seeing any relevant errors in the logs. 
- Getting access to the errors is not always an easy task: depending on the instance type where the error happened, it can be difficult to retrieve the logs. 
- Error reporting is ad-hoc in various services, leading to implementation fragmentation which makes the problem hard to tackle as a whole. 

Overall, we have a low signal to noise ratio that makes debugging tedious. We can take this opportunity, as a secondary objective to improve our sensitive data redaction in error reporting. 

Related problem: due to the lack of a unified reporting mechanism, diagnosing creates a lot of communication overhead, which can take days in some cases when those communications are subject to strict internal policies in place in some companies. 



## Measure of success

- The handbook documents a set of conventions on how to write errors that has been collectively approved by both errors consuming and producing teams. 
- Have at least one service fully migrated to use the new errors conventions to serve as an example to later migrate all other services to the new conventions.
- Errors rates are provided with enough metadata to identify what component they are coming from, making them monitorable. 
- Error reporting works across all instance types. 
- Have a mechanism in place to access seamlessly access the errors on a given instance.
  - TODO: Get in touch with the cloud devops team, as they possibly have related work on this matter. 

<!-- How will we validate/verify/know that we have solved the problem? -->

## Solution summary

We will propose an RFC with a set of conventions for runtime errors, actively seeking feedback from the biggest errors consumers. We're likely to include documentation tasks and content producing work to improve onboarding on the general topic of errors. 

We will audit the codebase to understand better the current state to identify possible source of debt as well as proposing changes on the error-related packages to facilitate following the above convention as well as passing additional data.

<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artifacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

Artifacts:
- TO DO GitHub discussion to brainstorm on this topic. 

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?

Internal Sourcegraph developers and SREs. 

<!--
Reference customers by linking to their issue in our accounts repository. DON'T REFERENCE CUSTOMERS BY NAME!

Example:
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/537
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
-->

## Impact on use cases

This effort contributes to the company-wide effort to improve Observability.

<!--
Describe how this roadmap item contributes to improving the customer experience for one or more of the 5 use cases and apply the relevant use-case/* labels to this issue.

For enablement projects that don't target a specific use case, describe how you expect this work to enable teams/projects that are focused on use cases.
-->

## Delivery plan
<!--
The overall plan for how we are going to achieve this roadmap item. This should be formulated as a checklist of concrete steps that are kept up-to-date so anyone can glace at the issue description to get a sense of what we have already delivered and what remains.

Each item on this list is ideally a concrete deliverable with an estimated delivery date and owner, but we don't want false precision, so just document the plan to the best of your ability, even if you don't have all the steps yet.
-->

- [ ] â¡ï¸ Investigate existing proposals, issues, and problem space @jhchabran 
- [ ] Prepare a draft RFC with standardized proposal around conventions. 
- [ ] Partner with a given team on improving the errors on a specific domain and evaluate those results with SREs. 
- [ ] Raise RFC as formal standardization proposal


### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking Issue: Consolidation of frontend test frameworks
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

Most of our tests (all of our unit tests) run through `jest`. All tests that use Puppeteer run through `mocha`.

We should migrate our `mocha` tests to `jest` because:
- Having a single test framework will improve DX and productivity
- It will help us avoid cross-framework bugs which are difficult to debug and track. Example: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/31397
- `jest` is a library with greater usage and, generally, better support with different tooling
- The vast majority of our tests use `jest`, and we haven't had any major complaints about it in recent times.

**Note:** We previous had some complaints about `jest`. I investigated them in this issue: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/31630. I found that there wasn't anything major that should block us in this migration.

TrackingIssues.Author: keegancsmith
TrackingIssues.Title: Core Services: 3.5 Tracking Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Goal

Improve support for instances with 30,000 repositories.

## Availability

- @mrnugget out on the 30th of May as well as the 10th, 20th and 21st of June. 8th-10th July (next iteration).
- @tsenart out for a wedding from Friday the 14th of June until the 18th.
- @keegancsmith out for a SA public holiday. Friday the 14th until 17th.

## Dependencies

For this iteration we have some needs and wants that we think other teams are already focusing on. This list is based on our current understanding and is prone to change with new information.

- Ensure that our large scale environments have appropriate data in them and can support continuous load testing while reflecting the setups of our most important customers.
- Shortened feedback cycles after pushing code
  - CI time
  - Fast deployment to multiple environments
  - Understanding what is in each environment
  - More sentry integration?

## Proposed Work

- [x] Postgres reliability
  - [x] insert: pq: duplicate key value violates unique constraint" on clean 3.4.1 instance #4210
  - [x] management-console: ... Failed to migrate the DB... canâ€™t acquire database lock during upgrade from 3.2.1 to 3.4.1 #4208
- [x] Transfer ownership of auth{N|Z} by implementing Bitbucket Server authn and authz (ACLs) (#1108)
- [ ] Improve UX for site admins with 30k repos
  - [x] Fetch GitHub repositories in batches #4223
  - [x] "Not cloned" repositories page times out if there are a lot of repositories and none are cloned #4063 
  - [x] Visiting a repository for the first time shows "starting to clone" but doesn't start #3447
  - [x] "Empty repository" banner shown on repo page in between enabling and cloning a repo #1744
  - [x] Special case `org:` in repositoryQuery so that it doesn't use the limited Search API. #4036
  - [x] Delay deleting repos and indexes to be resilient against admin mistakes in configuration (#2572)
  - [x] Cloning repositories return 404 Not Found (#4081)
  - [ ] Add a global "repositories are cloning"/"Sourcegraph is not ready yet" indicator #4120  [WIP @mrnugget]
    - [ ] When adding 1000's of github repos at once, there is no feedback in the UI for hours at a time #3413
    - [x] repos: Indicate schedule for cloning in UI #4232
- [ ] Improve Zoekt memory usage https://github.com/google/zoekt/issues/86  [WIP @keegancsmith]

- [ ] Synthetic load testing and complementary monitoring. Will do in testing week. [Ancient implementation](https://github.com/sourcegraph/enterprise/tree/a4c3283198105242f994ca5a2d56a9d6addcaf3b/test/load)
  - [x] Load test Bitbucket Server ACLs
  - [ ] Load test repo page
  - [ ] Load test indexed search
  - [ ] Load test non-indexed search
  - [ ] Measure and alert on time from commit upstream to indexing
  - [ ] Measure and alert saving an external service config that yields 30k repos

## Stretch Work

TrackingIssues.Author: ggilmore
TrackingIssues.Title: gRPC September 2023 Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
# gRPC September 2023 Issue

Overall, the primary goal is to support the managed instance gRPC rollout and respond to any issues that arise from it. 

After this iteration, gRPC will be on by default in the 5.2.X release. In the 5.3.X release, gRPC will be the only option - the legacy REST codepaths will be removed.

**Note**: Even after the 5.2.X release, there will be a large number of follow up tasks:

- any follow up configuration changes that arise from the launch will self-hosted customers
- any tasks required to remove the legacy HTTP REST methods
- the syntax highlighter service still needs to be converted to use gRPC

## about this tracking issue 

**Since there aren't really fixed-length tasks for gRPC this iteration -  and more on going support, the tracking issue is represented as a list of priorities instead of a strict task lists.**

# priority 1: support gRPC managed instance rollout

gRPC is rolling out on al of our managed instances up through the end of August. See **[Cloud feature launch: gRPC#2228](https://www.notion.so/gRPC-September-2023-Issue-0e53a429fa8140289f0b8c6f87b9c40e?pvs=21)** for the full schedule. 

The cloud team has set up monitoring in such a way that weâ€™ll be notified if any errors from the â€œinternal errorâ€ logic that we added pop up on any of the instances. 

Our top priority is to respond to and resolve to any alerts that popup from these instances, or any other issues that the cloud team brings to our attention (or our customers let us know about). 

# priority 2: ongoing issue rundowns

There are two known classes of issues that we need to fix individual instances of. In general, there are no one sized fits all solutions to theses issues, we fix invidiual occurrences of the problem as they arise. 

In order to find new occurrences of these problems, we look at reports from:

- [sourcegraph.com](http://sourcegraph.com)â€™s gRPC error logs: [https://app.golinks.io/prod-logs-grpc-errors](https://app.golinks.io/prod-logs-grpc-errors)
- alerts-managed-instances (gRPC specific errors): [https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C017SLJGA2Z](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C017SLJGA2Z)

## non-utf8 string issue

**Issue**: [gRPC error reporting indicates non-UTF-8 string fields are slipping through somehow](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/52181)

**TL;DR:** Our conversion to gRPC has revealed errors due to non-UTF-8 strings in certain gRPC endpoints (`gitserver.v1.GitserverService` and `symbols.v1.SymbolsService`). This issue arises from inconsistencies in how the system handles strings and the assumption that strings are always UTF-8 encoded. The protobuf's `string` type only allows UTF-8 encoded strings, however, Go's string type does not enforce this, and some functions might not work correctly with non-UTF-8 strings. This is likely to be a broader application issue that gRPC's stricter requirements have revealed.

There isnâ€™t a one-sized-fits-all type of solution to this issue. We take each individual occurrence of the issue (from [sourcegraph.com](http://sourcegraph.com)â€™s [error logs](https://console.cloud.google.com/logs/query;query=resource.type%3D%22k8s_container%22%0Aresource.labels.project_id%3D%22sourcegraph-dev%22%0Aresource.labels.location%3D%22us-central1-f%22%0Aresource.labels.cluster_name%3D%22cloud%22%0Aresource.labels.namespace_name%3D%22prod%22%0AjsonPayload.InstrumentationScope%3D~%22gRPC.internal.error.reporter%22%0A;cursorTimestamp=2023-08-06T02:26:37.786373604Z;duration=P2D?project=sourcegraph-dev) or from managed instance alerts) and come up with a fix for that unique occurrence. 

Fixes:

- [x]  [https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55269](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55269)
- [x]  [https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55275](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55275)
- [x]  [https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55327](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55327)
- [x]  [https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55369](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55369)
- [x]  [https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55449](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55449)

## message size too large

gRPC wasnâ€™t optimized for sending large messages. Quoting from [Microsoftâ€™s â€œPerformance Best Practices with gRPCâ€ page](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/grpc/performance)

> gRPC is a message-based RPC framework, which means:
> 
> - The entire message is loaded into memory before gRPC can send it.
> - When the message is received, the entire message is deserialized into memory.

As such, large messages can cause a lot of memory allocations for 
both the client and server. For this reason, the Go GRPC implementation 
has the following default limits

- [sending](https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc#MaxSendMsgSize): maximum ~2.1 GB (2^32-1 bytes) message
- [receiving](https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc#MaxRecvMsgSize): maximum 4 MB message

In the 5.1.X release, weâ€™ve already implemented a workaround to be able to [tune the maximum size via environment variables](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/52036/files). However, this is just a workaround while we work to resolve the problem (and can get rid of these environment variables). 

Fixes: 

- [x]  [https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55242](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55242)
- [x]  [https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55209](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/55209)
- [x]  [https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/52208](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/52208)

# priority 3: convert configuration and zoekt-webserver services to gRPC

- [x]  Switching over the configuration package to speak gRPC.

- [x]  [fix zoekt-webserver gRPC support](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/53356): We tried converting zoekt-webserver to gRPC for the 5.1.X release, but we ran into last-minute issues that caused us to have to put it behind an additional feature flag (turning it off).

# priority 4: get test self-hosted customers to enable gRPC on their instances

Our next priority will be to chat with our delivery teams and ask them to connect us with some test customers to enable gRPC on their self-hosted instances. We will target friendly and responsive admins and perhaps ones that have odd networking setups (firewalls, service meshes).

We'll use these experiences to build out enablement materials ([like this](https://handbook.sourcegraph.com/departments/engineering/dev/tools/grpc/)) for the delivery / CS teams.

**Note**:Â **this is probably the task that will get cut if necessary**.

- If we decide to cut this, the trade-off here is between having those pre-emptive configuration conversations to head off those issues versus being very responsive to helping admins out after gRPC is on by default in the 5.2.x release. I am comfortable making this trade-off since I'm confident that the kinds of issues we'll see would be related to the customer's restrictive firewall configuration (and settings that theyâ€™ll need to change)

/cc @sourcegraph/source

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking Issue: Consolidation of React testing libraries
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Plan

We currently have multiple React testing libraries in use across the application. This results in inconsistent tests and unnecessary dependencies.

Current testing libraries that we use:
- [React Test Renderer](https://reactjs.org/docs/test-renderer.html)
- [Enzyme](https://enzymejs.github.io/enzyme/)
- [React Testing Library](https://testing-library.com/docs/react-testing-library/intro/)

### Comparing approaches
React Test Renderer
- Limited in functionality
- [Usage in our application](https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=context:global+repo:sourcegraph/sourcegraph+from+%27react-test-renderer%27&patternType=literal) is also limited. We primarily use this library for snapshots and basic tests. Other libraries offer the same functionality.

Enzyme:
- Powerful functionality
- Can encourage bad practices. For example, shallow rendering, accessing a component instance directly. accessing component props. In particular, here's an [article](https://kentcdodds.com/blog/why-i-never-use-shallow-rendering) that states the dangers of shallow rendering

React Testing Library
- Powerful functionality
- Encourages better practices. Does not support shallow rendering, or other techniques that do not follow the libraries [guiding principles](https://testing-library.com/docs/guiding-principles). From my experience, following these principles makes tests much easier to write, and much more brittle to change.

Our preferred approach should be **React Testing Library** We should also consider moving snapshots to Storybook

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9516420/140932429-263ad346-9ae7-4a0e-a571-21fb7a875d56.png)

### Goal

To complete this issue we should:
- Only use a single testing library across our frontend unit tests
- Have clear documentation that describes how we should write our frontend unit tests

TrackingIssues.Author: ElizabethStirling
TrackingIssues.Title: Security 3.22 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

<!--
Summarize what the team wants to achieve this iteration.
- What are the problems we want to solve or what information do we want to gather?
- Why is solving those problems or gathering that information important?
- How do we plan to solve those problems or gather that information?
-->

This iteration, we want to resolve container scan vulnerabilities, initiate scanning of compute nodes, and host a dummy security repository on Sourcegraph Cloud as a proof of concept. This will ensure that our underlying infrastructure has no significant known flaws. Additionally, by having this proof of concept private repository, we can validate our design, and ensure that there are no obvious flaws in our access control.

**Goal:** Resolve container vulnerabilities with a score of at least 4.0, or have plans to resolve when resolutions are released.

**Goal:** All compute nodes are continuously scanned for known security vulnerabilities, and the security team is alerted when one is found.

**Goal:** We connect our [test security repository](https://github.com/sourcegraph/security-test/blob/main/README.md) to Sourcegraph Cloud and [only members who can access that repository on GitHub](https://github.com/sourcegraph/security-test/settings/access) can access that repository on Sourcegraph Cloud. These people are the organization owners, and members of the security team. Note that this depends on our [ability to host private code on Sourcegraph Cloud](https://about.sourcegraph.com/handbook/engineering/cloud#private-code-on-sourcegraph-cloud).

### Availability

Period is from 2020-10-20 to 2020-11-20. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Code Intelligence 3.19 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

**Goal 1: [Add support for monorepos](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/76)**

Unblock customers [C1](https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/company/464956351/) & [C2](https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/company/554275594/) from adopting LSIF by removing known blockers for large repositories with high commit rates. This milestone will make progress of removing the known blockers for these companies by following tasks (will still need a follow-up in (at least) the 3.20 milestone):

Building a prototype to speed up indexing on all repos. This is necessary for large monorepos as indexing the entire codebase is infeasible. This prototype will act as the feasibility study referenced in the [RFC 170](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NPu0Vc7FpdoYwCrtpnu-8KB4OPbw7L0KBTqw96JVc8w). If we determine that this technique is viable, then the 3.20 milestone will focus on a proper implementation of the prototype (which also requires updating indexers to create patch indexes). @efritz @gbrik 

**Goal 2: Improve developer experience for use of LSIF in CI**

Users aren't configuring LSIF in CI because it is technically cumbersome, carries a maintenance burden, difficult to explain, and may involve red tape. We are aiming to alleviate these issues by automating the process and reduce number setup steps needed by developers to deploy. To support this effort we are also going to create additional quickstart documentation.

**Goal 3: Increase LSIF adoption**

Users are blocked from adopting LSIF because existing indexers don't support their use case, or there is no indexer for their language. We plan to distribute lsif-clang to customers that already have precise C++ support to ensure that it continues to meet their use case and is ready for wider distribution. We will also write a plan for precise SWIFT & Java support. 

**Goal 4: Resolve technical debt to improve quality and reliability**

This work is to improve overall quality of code intel components, including fixing worker concurrency bug, UI hover experience and implementing graceful failover for bundle manager.


### Availability

Period is from **2020-07-20** to **2020-08-20**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- Aida: 24d
- Eric: 17d (out 07/23-07/24)
- Garo: 11d (out first week)

TrackingIssues.Author: DaedalusG
TrackingIssues.Title: WIP: Tracking issue - Deploy-Sourcegraph-Docker compatibility with latest Podman
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Tracking issue - Deploy-Sourcegraph-Docker compatibility with latest Podman

Some orgs require the use of Podman to orchestrate containers, in theory because Podman supports running `docker-compose.yaml` files [Deploy-Sourcegraph-Docker](https://github.com/sourcegraph/deploy-sourcegraph-docker) should be possible to deploy and manage via podman.

While this is possible in theory we do not currently test our deployment against podman and as such it is not considered a supported deployment option.

This issue is to track some feasibility testing for podman support

TrackingIssues.Author: burmudar
TrackingIssues.Title: DevInfra: Integrate Cody to explain build errors to our developers
TrackingIssues.Body:
ğŸ““ Plan

We want to leverage Cody to first help us to classify failures are infra or code related, as this will help to reduce the influx of support requests, and then in a second time to explain build failures. 

This would help to gather experience of the potential of turning this into a product in the future while solving an immediate problem for us.

ğŸ¨ Prior work:
- POC https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/50640

ğŸ¯ Goal or north â­ 

> Cody can automatically classify CI failures as infra-related or not. Cody can explain build errors (only) from our CI if asked.

TrackingIssues.Author: keegancsmith
TrackingIssues.Title: Core Services: 3.4 Tracking Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Goals

- All supported code hosts have moved to the new model of syncing repository
  metadata. This allows us to support detecting deletions and renames,
  avoiding expensive code host API requests on a user request path and solves
  many related repository metadata bugs.
- A better model for repositoryPathPattern. Also known as aliases for
  repository names. This allows users to have more succinct names for
  repositories on their Sourcegraph instance. Additionally the use of the
  feature won't break the browser extension.
- Onboard Thorsten.

### Availability

- @keegancsmith is out from 19th of April until the 26th.
- @tsenart is out from the 15th of May until the 22nd.
- @mrnugget is joining on the 23rd of April.

We are aiming for **17d** person days of planned work. This is to account for
responding to customer issues, vacation, helping other teams and onboarding
Thorsten.

### Planned Work

- Integrate remaining code hosts with the new syncing model
  - [x] Gitolite #3464  (@tomas) 
  - [x] AWS CodeCommit #3465 (@mrnugget)
- [x] RepoLookup should load metadata from database #3466 (@mrnugget)
- [x] Support new syncer in sourcegraph.com deployment #3459 (@mrnugget, @keegancsmith)
  - ~~[ ] Add git repos to Sourcegraph.com #3457~~
  - [x] Sourcegraph.com does not auto add soft-deleted repositories. Will only be
    an issue once new syncer is enabled. #2933 
- [x] Remove syncer feature flag and delete old code paths #4000 (@tomas)
- [x] Repo name mappings are not universally supported #462 (@keegancsmith)
  - [x] Impossible to change repositoryPathPattern after adding repositories #2741 
  - [x] GitHub link disappears intermittently in 3.x #2677
- [x] repos: Deprecate enabled/disabled state #3291 (@keegancsmith)


### Stretch Goals

- [ ] enqueue-repo-update should use an ID debt #3345 (@tsenart)
- Visiting a repository for the first time shows "starting to clone" but doesn't start #3447 
- Repo language not being updated https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/2586
- Redis
  - Redis AOF database corruption #651
  - Redis AOF file grows unbounded due to frequent container restarts #3300
  - redis: Log spam warning when redis is loading the dataset in memory #2904
  - Redis OOM error prevents sign in or using server #296
- postgresql: (Auto)tune DB pool sizes based on max_connections #3473


### Onboarding @mrnugget

> Note: We can adjust this plan based on Thorsten's preferences.

- **Week 1**: Thorsten should spend first week getting to know people in SF and
understanding the high level picture of Sourcegraph Inc. and
sourcegraph/sourcegraph.

- **Week 2**: Pair with us on whatever we are working on. Likely implementing a code
host #3464 or #3465.

- **Week 3-4**: Continue to learn how things are put together and begin taking on some of the planned work in the iteration or other important issues that can pop up.

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: DevX: Q2B2 Codeintel OpenTelemetry and s2 observability
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Problem

Cloud instances are lacking observability tooling (_make Cloud the preferred deployed method_), and inconsistent tracing export is a long-standing problem on self-hosted instances (_provide a world-class admin experience_).

### Scope

- **Boundaries**
  - We target [sourcegraph.sourcegraph.com](https://github.com/sourcegraph/customer/issues/1046) (not all Cloud instances), and explore feasibility for sourcegraph.com
  - We will not touch anything that isn't related to CodeIntel, _unless_ absolutely necessary/tangential (e.g. API change)
  - We will not add vendor-specific integrations within the code (e.g. vendor-specific push)
- **Definition of done**
  - OTel Collector is deployed and collecting OTel data
    - Data is then pushed into a service provider HoneyComb ~and Grafana~
    - Prove that we can send data to other provider, in this case ~Grafana~ Jaeger
  - Codeintel error logs are reported to Sentry, and Cloud + codeintel makes an assessment on its usefulness in operating   Cloud instances
  - ~Codeintel shares an experience report of having such observability in place, and we publicize in relevant channels and newsletter~

<!--
Summarize what the team wants to achieve this iteration.
- What are the problems we want to solve or what information do we want to gather?
- Why is solving those problems or gathering that information important?
- How do we plan to solve those problems or gather that information?
-->

TrackingIssues.Author: briemcnally
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking Issue: FY23 Q3+ Resource Estimator Improvements
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Plan
This tracking issue is a follow up to our FY23 Q2 Resource Estimator commitments seen [in this issue](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/31201). This tracking issue should be used to store incremental RE improvements needed for LT RE improvements.

[SDD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dQPkU4ajp6WlgIvfSo2iYk4xgzhT1BrZ65mSGklDIuw/edit#heading=h.q983jwvomu4c)

### Product Requirements

- Help to define a process for storing a centralized source of truth for internally storing customer self-hosted resource allocation and any changes over time. This should be stored in a way that easily be fed to the calculator to ensure long term accuracy
- Discover new ways to format the output of RE data - requires Product discovery
- Ship reference architectures for the customer categorization buckets defined in Q2

Measure of Success:
Reduce the number of support questions and requests related to customer resource allocation for standing up and maintaining their Sourcegraph instances. Resource estimation will be self-serve and no longer require engagement from Delivery engineering team

TrackingIssues.Author: slimsag
TrackingIssues.Title: Distribution: 3.18 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### Support new and existing deployments

This is an ongoing expense, and based on the current state of customers we anticipate this taking taking no more than 10d of work spread across the entire team.

#### Reduce upgrade overhead

Upgrading Kubernetes deployments requires customers spend a lot of engineering time to converge our released Kubernetes manifests with their fork as documented inÂ [RFC-141](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1tsksAlqe77NmdPLw7oyy2u0-1rYDQeVpPeDo1T0Xt50).

We have evaluated and eliminated Bash and Cue as solutions to this problem, and have partially evaluated [Dhall](https://dhall-lang.org/). We will continue to evaluate [Dhall](https://dhall-lang.org/) more extensively this iteration by dogfooding it on k8s.sgdev.org.

#### Reduce support burdens

Investigating and troubleshooting problems with deployments currently requires a lot of overhead to retrieve all necessary information. We will improve documentation around tooling and services to simplify data collection in customer issue reports and streamline observability tooling.

#### Onboard @pecigonzalo

As the team grows, the management overhead of the teams makes it harder for engineers to focus on our objectives and OKRs. We will finalize the initial onboarding and handover of processes to @pecigonzalo.

#### Improve reliability sourcegraph.com alerts

Sourcegraph.com alerting does not use our new monitoring stack we ship to customers and has flaky alerts due to that and site24x7. We will begin using the new monitoring stack on Sourcegraph.com and explore more reliable replacements to site24x7 such as [blackbox exporter](https://github.com/prometheus/blackbox_exporter). This supports [RFC 189](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1noZf86g2QwTbFNt3XSSbMg36D-_HCptP1thMzZsgt2Q/edit)

### Availability

Period is from **June 22nd** to **July 17th**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- @daxmc99: 1d
- @ggilmore: 1d
- @slimsag: 1d
- @bobheadxi: 1d

TrackingIssues.Author: JenRed777
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue - FY23 Q2 Resource Estimator Updates
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

Our current Resource Estimator is out of date and needs some attention. We need to go through and update our current metrics as well as add any new ones that we find are relevant 

[SDD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dQPkU4ajp6WlgIvfSo2iYk4xgzhT1BrZ65mSGklDIuw/edit#heading=h.q983jwvomu4c) 

### Product Requirements
* Define key metrics that impact Sourcegraph performance and how resource requirements change as a result of these indicators
* Make modifications to the Resource Estimator calculator to ensure we are including all services and that it is using the most up to date data retrieved via [Resource Estimator Data](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1N7X_OXDwKk0QSR2Ghbj7ZhjVrQXcMNj-yC8mF1amBi4/edit)
* The improved tooling should aim to be able to provide recommendations/guidance for database selection.configuration and disk guidance.
* Help to define a process for storing a centralized source of truth for internally storing customer self-hosted resource allocation and any changes over time. This should be stored in a way that easily be fed to the calculator to ensure long term accuracy

### Measure of Success:
* Reduce the number of support questions and requests related to customer resource allocation for standing up and maintaining their Sourcegraph instances. Resource estimation will be self-serve and no longer require engagement from Delivery engineering team

TrackingIssues.Author: malomarrec
TrackingIssues.Title: Batch Changes permissions
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Context

Currently, Batch Changes permission model works like documented [here](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/batch_changes/explanations/permissions_in_batch_changes). In a nutshell:
- there are two levels of access: `read` and `admin`
- all users can `read` all batch changes. 
- the batch change creator and site-admins have `admin` access to it
- having read access to a batch change does not give you read access to the changesets it contains. You can only view changesets you have view access to according to repository permissions.
- there are two namespaces, the user's and the org's. All users in an org are admin of a batch change in the org's namespace.

## Problem

This permission model is insufficient:

- in security use cases, the security team might want to keep a batch change private to only one person or their team.
- any customer in the strategic segment wants control over who can see Batch Changes, ideally per individual, team, org

## Customer issues and impacted customers

Also see this [product gap](https://sourcegraph.productboard.com/feature-board/2104383-batch-changes/features/12651125/insights)

**This issue needs feedback.** If you encounter an instance of this, please document it in the comments or privately and link back here.

## Proposed solution

We are in the process of collecting additional feedback on this issue.

<!-- LABEL: needs-feedback -->
<!-- BEGIN WORK -->
<!-- END WORK -->

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: GraphQL Client adoption: Code browsing
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
Weâ€™re looking to increase adoption of Apollo Client across code browsing components.

The aim of this issue is to identify and eventually improve areas that:
- Would benefit from serving cached data. High-traffic areas where data is unlikely to change whilst the user is on the page.
- Would benefit from refactoring data fetching logic into a shared API. Some examples may be complicated RxJS code that could be abstracted, or usage of FilteredConnection that has proven difficult to modify previously. 

### Useful resources
- Migrating from `requestGraphQL | queryGraphQL | mutateGraphQL` usage to [useMutation and useQuery](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/client/shared/src/graphql/graphql.ts?L127-157) hooks.
- Utilising the [Apollo cache](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/graphql#how-do-i-use-the-apollo-cache) by adding the correct `id` fields to queries or providing alternative [keyFields](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/caching/cache-configuration/#customizing-identifier-generation-by-type) to use.
- Migrating from `FilteredConnection` to `useConnection` and abstract FilteredConnection UI components: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/commit/037dc8022ae8e0368e07131856c684715b731a1e

Please use this issue to discuss and identify these areas. Will create follow-on tickets to track implementation.

TrackingIssues.Author: aidaeology
TrackingIssues.Title: Code Intelligence 3.20 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

**Goal:** Get the top three most popular language indexers: lsif-go, lsif-java, lsif-clang stable by working directly on implementation with customers to identify and resolve any remaining issues that prevent the tool from being use in a wide release. This goal takes top priority for this milestone and each member of the team is leading the initiative on an indexer. 

**Goal:** Perform research spikes of features such as Bazel integration (to improve monorepos support) in order to find the best approach, and scope the development effort for adding new core capabilities to code intel platform.

**Goal:** Improve the reliability and usability of code intel tools by triaging and resolving UI bugs and performance issues (i.e. the bundle manager process) for an improved developer experience.

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: DevInfra: Revamp integration/e2e testing Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan


  - Rework integration/e2e tests so it's easy to understand where each test is defined
  - Extract the backcompat tests in its own pipeline (it's a trigger step basically, but we still depend on it to be green) 
    - Different pipeline, just apply the patch to inject the migrations and run bazel again.
  - Document and add cookbook recipes for handling backcompat test failures
  - Write an RFC to explain how to organize integration and e2e tests 
    - Great candidate to partner with us: Source
    - Go ahead and implement stuff before getting everything approved, can totally be POC'ed as part of the RFC 
    - idea:
      - //testing/[domain]/A,B,C -> ex: //testing/source/p4, //testing/source/gitlab, ...
      - //cmd/mything/integration -> run my service integration tests 
        - only require to fire up the given service (nothing else) 
          - go myservice.Start() (it might be acceptable to also go mydependency.Start(), the rule is it has run within go) 
            - i.e. it's just a normal go test, it just happens to be heavy.
        - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/54419 should be "reproducible" in an integration test (or revealed) 
  - Run graphql backend tests locally
    - What's the intent of this test? Do we want to keep this as an integration test or an e2e test? 
      - e2e test -> keep docker 
      - integration test -> drop docker
  - Run codeintel-qa locally
  - Run e2e tests locally 
    - github host is required
      - pull creds from devx-service?

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue: Global state management
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Motivation
We want to move forward with a global state management solution to address some of the problems in [RFC 391](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-CBkQMO8Db3onfBF4onEn4I_3YljsfxIeJ6h64ZynGM/edit#heading=h.twdj57egor10).

The two proposed approaches here are either [useContextSelector](https://github.com/dai-shi/use-context-selector) or [Zustand](https://github.com/pmndrs/zustand).

Our view is that both approaches are actually quite similar. There is an important issue to be solved that is to avoid multiple stores creating non-directional dependencies. This is a potential problem in both libraries and we'll need extra work to make sure we avoid this!

### Plan

It's important we decide on a single approach so we can move forward with this, our proposed solution is:

**Adapt Zustand to use a single global store, add better linting and improve documentation**

How we will do this:
- Update existing Zustand code to use a global store. This means moving part of [this code](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph@tr/webpack-manifest-local/-/blob/client/web/src/search/navbarSearchQueryState.ts#L69:3) to be a generic store, [similar to how we create the Apollo cache.](https://sourcegraph.com/-/editor?remote_url=git%40github.com%3Asourcegraph%2Fsourcegraph.git&branch=tr%2Fwebpack-manifest-local&file=client%2Fshared%2Fsrc%2Fgraphql%2Fapollo%2Fcache.ts&editor=VSCode&version=1.4.0&start_row=0&start_col=0&end_row=0&end_col=0).
- Add an eslint rule to ban this kind of import: `import create from 'zustand'`. This is to enforce that we only allow creating a single global store. The one exception to this rule will be where we actually create the global store ğŸ˜ƒ 
- Add more documentation:
  - Managing different types of state:
    - Global state: shared across the application and should be stored in a single Zustand store. 
    - 'Localized' state: Will typically be used for things like reusable components, and may change depending on some configuration, should be stored in a normal React context. Example: Setting a `compact` state for all `FilteredConnection` UI components in a tree.
    - GraphQL state: Data fetched from our backend API, should be stored in the Apollo cache.
    - Local state: Normal React state that should be isolated in components, e.g. `useState`
  - FAQS
    - How to test
    - Common problems
    - ... etc

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: keegancsmith
TrackingIssues.Title: Core Services: 3.11 tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
**Theme**: What will break with 80k repositories across multiple code hosts?

**Q4 Vision Statement**: Sourcegraph operations are fast (e.g. search), instances scale to 80k repositories, private code is secure and respects ACLs for every authorization provider, and the product settings are easy to set up and understand for our largest customers.

[Core Services Roadmap](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1cBsE9801DcBF9chZyMnxRdolqM_1c2pPyGQz15QAvYI/edit#heading=h.5nwl5fv52ess)

#### Housekeeping

- @unknwon 12/16 - 12/17 OOO, 12/18 - 12/23 Part-time (CST +8 timezone)

#### Required

- [ ] [RFC 40: Explicit Repository Permissions Model](https://docs.google.com/document/d/167WV_rhBg3oj0yw9fHwUMlB-8BR3ktk2FSsKiUQo55Y/edit) - #6086 [@unknwon]
- [ ] [RFC 45: Extending Bitbucket Server Plugin](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1I3Aq1WSUh42BP8KvKr6AlmuCfo8tXYtJu40WzdNT6go/edit) Permissions Layer - #6091 [@kzh]
- [ ] [RFC 48: Structural Search](https://docs.google.com/document/d/16WwZA8zf-soI0HgCXGrRL5IrmyZnGYrB5VTXsqguUzo/edit#) Production Ready - #6679 [@rvantonder]
- [ ] [RFC 79: Refactor CI Pipeline](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_F2xiuNxkrdTHhgaR3jyaaWcs9OsUs9eMAF9fSCxie0/edit) - - #6690 [@keegancsmith]
- [ ] RFC ??: GitLab Production Ready - #6738 [@keegancsmith]
- [ ] [RFC 70: Expose full repository languages/file types inventory via GraphQL](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1h83x8z8tqx7o0coammGnJUvCvQC6aMIiBEMdb1l9TqY/edit) - [@ryanslade]

#### Polish

These are smaller tasks which anyone can do. They are all stretch tasks, with the main tasks being first priority.

Note: If the task is assigned to someone already, you can do it (please ping the person first).

- [x] Rev not found error for commits that exist on code host #6539
- [x] On any change to external services, restart sync #6058
- [x] 3.9.2: panic during gitserver cleanup #6710
- [ ] Gitserver should auto-recover from corrupt repository clones #6676
- [ ] Default symbol sidebar to using Zoekt for indexed branches #6078
- [ ] Verify sourcegraph.com falls back to non-indexed search when indexed pod is down #6057
- [ ] Speed improvements for repohascommitafter #6745
- [ ] Setup 80k repos on k8s.sgdev.org (old issue #5726, now we have zoekt scaling try again).
- [x] Band aid for poor diff/commit search experience https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/5519#issuecomment-555226517
- [x] Backend returns invalid filter chip with space "lang:ignore list" #6498

3.10 tracking issue is #6031

TrackingIssues.Author: cbart
TrackingIssues.Title: [done] Ownership inference
TrackingIssues.Body:
Spike https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50801

**File level**

At this point the goal is to use online fetching of signals on the file level.

- [x] Display recent contributor signals https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50565
  - We compute recent contributions for file with a gitserver call - something we can demo quickly
- [x] Display recent viewer signals https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50564
- [x] Enabling/disabling ownership signals in the UI

**Aggregation**

Aggregation can piggyback of the existing code intel indexing and also reuse the Admin UI.

- [x] Stub graphQL API for displaying ownership https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50800
- [x] Repo and directory page UI for displaying ownership [figma](https://groups.google.com/a/sourcegraph.com/g/own-team)
- [x] Implement a recent contributor aggregate signal
  - [x] Database and stores https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50946
  - [x] #51382
  - [x] **TBD** Knobs and monitoring
- [x] Implement a viewer indexer **NEEDS EXPANDING**

Notes:

- For the recent viewer signal, it is enough that we [keep the last timestamp](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/50571#issuecomment-1507528266) a repo was reindexed for viewership.

Notes:

- all ownership signalling work should be hidden behind `own-signals` feature flag

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: â­ Q3B1 Mitigate Observability expenses
TrackingIssues.Body:
This was brought to us by @bobheadxi over this [Slack message](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C02MWRMAFR8/p1664234859716079).

## Problem

Dotcom is seeing continuous growth in traces export [that is amounting to significant expenses](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C07KZF47K/p1664224894990579?thread_ts=1662734633.832289&cid=C07KZF47K) ($22k in Grafana this month) as well. @bobheadxi  worked on a few mitigation efforts, but I think we need a more concerted strategy here about how we are going to handle tracing in the application (see below) and investigate why this is happening and how we can keep costs under control.

We are missing guidance on how to write good tracing and potential misuse of tracing policy due to how tracing policies have been implemented in Sourcegraph for a long time. I suspect a significant issue we are seeing is that background jobs always enable tracing (https://sourcegraph.sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph@af1c9d3a8ef24cc35f3b248b66b0e89dfed46258/-/blob/internal/workerutil/worker.go?L315) because there's no concept of "selective" for background jobs yet, which causes libraries like otelsql to emit large amounts of traces for every background job that gets run. 
@jhchabran and @burmudar did some work previously on options for otel-level sampling - IIRC (@bobheadxi) one of the conclusions is because of selective we can't really reliably suggest generalized probabilistic sampling, so we need a solution designed and implemented here (whether that be more feature flags, research into more filtering/sampling, etc).

## Scope

We're not looking to refactor entirely the tracing API nor to make the selectiveness property work perfectly across all the components, as this would require to migrate all the existing opentracing code to OTEL.

Instead, by order of importance: 

1. Mitigate the spending by fixing the biggest source of traces that do not respect the `selective` property.
2. Provide a clear path to write tracing code that respects the type of tracing. 
3. Sketch a plan for taking up this further. 

### Boundaries

- Do not migrate open tracing code in OTEL (unless we're 100% sure it's mandatory to reach 1., and if it's the case, we need to revisit this ticket).
- Do not implement solely on our own the changes in the code, reach out for their respective owners for help. We have a lot on our place for this bet cycle, and we need to leverage any help we can get. 

## Approach 

- @jhchabran and @burmudar  to review all the existing PRs submitted by @bobheadxi 
- @jhchabran and @burmudar  to scrutinize the code to get better understanding from where those traces are coming from. 
- @jhchabran, @burmudar, and @bobheadxi to hold a meeting to chat about the approach. 
- Work

## Payout

Mitigate by TODO the spending for tracing. Possibly some guidance on how to write correct tracing code. 

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: eseliger
TrackingIssues.Title: executors: Support multiple queue
TrackingIssues.Body:
Today, a single executor instance can only process a single queue or a single type of job like `codeintel` and `batches`. To easy pains around managing and deploying executors, executors should be able to support multiple queues.

## Done

- Update the `queue` to take an array of values instead of a single value
- Update the executor to be able to process multiple queues
- Demo

## Technical Considerations

- How to distribute jobs
    - If a `batches` job is taking forever, `codeintel` jobs take longer than acceptable to process
- Backwards compatibility
- How to name these multi-queue executors
    - Today they are named based on their queues
    - Maybe additional data in the **Side admin** view of executors?
- [Diagrams](https://app.excalidraw.com/s/4Dr1S6qmmY7/2ndPldKrBxE)

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: â­ Q4B1 ScaleTesting
TrackingIssues.Body:
<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: team/devx --> 

# ScaleTesting

## Problem

Now we have scale testing capabilities in place and some teams have started using it, our main problem is to increase our ability to conduct scale testing. 

So far, testing permissions is lacking, making it a complete blind spot for everyone to test those. It's a notoriously difficult thing to test and is vital for customers as this usually gets in the way of adopting Sourcegraph.

Another problem is that we need more test-data, as this is the defining factor in our ability to test our product at scale. This data needs to be properly organized and should be easy to recreate in the eventuality of a mistake overwriting it while conducting some tests. This test-data should be available on the necessary variety of codehosts. What is available where is based on the needs of our users. 

Finally, automation and having the ability to define test scenarios is required as it will provide a canvas to each team to start accumulating test scenarios they can reuse. 

## Scope

The main scope of this bet is around test-data and providing automation around running the tests themselves. While it may be tempting to think about automating the provisioning of scale testing instances, the current situation for our users is that tests are conducted manually and spontaneously when needs arise. We haven't once had a case where two users had to use the scale testing at once. 

Therefore, it's tactically more sound to postpone this, and to focus on providing better test-data and automation to provide that data. Once we have this, scaling the operations horizontally will be meaningful. 

### Boundaries

- Single instance only. 
- Automate running tests, but not the scale testing instance itself. 
- Limited automation for provisioning the instance: populate, snapshot and restore.
- We maintain, but do not monitor the scale testing instance, that's up to the teams using the instance (but if you see something, tell them eh).

### Definition of Done

- We have a set of test-data matching the immediate needs of each team that agreed to participate in the effort. 
- There is a defined way of creating a scenario to run a test against scale-testing. It can run in the CI pipeline. 
- We have a cost report available somewhere (stretch: automated). 
- We produce content to broadcast the use of scale testing throughout all engineering. 

## Payout 

- We are able to test permissions against all code hosts. 
- All participating teams are able to conduct tests on the scale testing instance, pertaining to their domain. 
- A runner for test scenarios against the scale testing instance is available, and participating teams can start writing those. At least two teams have written scenarios. 
- Everyone in engineering is aware of how to use scale-testing. 

## Approach
- We double down on test-data generation, as it proved to be delicate and slow in some cases. 
- We port remaining dev-ops tasks, as they're added as we go. 
- We set strong expectations toward our users, we escalate to EM level to sort out if things are not moving fast enough. 



### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: rrhyne
TrackingIssues.Title: Getting started checklist for new authenticated users
TrackingIssues.Body:
New, registered users will get more value from Sourcegraph if they clearly understand what tools are now available to them. 

Additionally, certain tasks should be completed to ensure users are set up to succeed. 

If the [getting started for visitors](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/27177) project works to increase sign-ups and retention, it could also be utilized to address these issues. 

Content for this section should align to items found to activate and retain users, and actions that [lead to PQLs](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WuOhQBY9yErAYJuuDyjKtrKECvn3deFVDGs6qd_R2MQ/edit).

While the PQL definition is changing, it is generally understood to relate to the following:

* A measurement of DAU/MAU use
* Number of invited users
* Code monitor usage
* A number of private repositories added to the account
* Code hosts added

Getting started tasks should relate to those objectives.

Resources
- [Figma designs](https://www.figma.com/file/hpL5H1kmNOgSJdnFDUpN9L/AUTHenticated--Getting-started-checklist?node-id=0%3A1)
- [RFC 610](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1np4b_dz3XJvc_ciewqbgd3xFuCHb7RFhhg1L5q1CBBk/edit#)

## Issues
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/32712
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/32713
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/32714
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/32670

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: GraphQL Client adoption: Code Insights
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
Weâ€™re looking to increase adoption of Apollo Client across insights components.

The aim of this issue is to identify and eventually improve areas that:
- Would benefit from serving cached data. High-traffic areas where data is unlikely to change whilst the user is on the page.
- Would benefit from refactoring data fetching logic into a shared API. Some examples may be complicated RxJS code that could be abstracted, or usage of FilteredConnection that has proven difficult to modify previously. 

### Useful resources
- Migrating from `requestGraphQL | queryGraphQL | mutateGraphQL` usage to [useMutation and useQuery](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/client/shared/src/graphql/graphql.ts?L127-157) hooks.
- Utilising the [Apollo cache](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/graphql#how-do-i-use-the-apollo-cache) by adding the correct `id` fields to queries or providing alternative [keyFields](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/caching/cache-configuration/#customizing-identifier-generation-by-type) to use.
- Migrating from `FilteredConnection` to `useConnection` and abstract FilteredConnection UI components: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/commit/037dc8022ae8e0368e07131856c684715b731a1e

Please use this issue to discuss and identify these areas. Will create follow-on tickets to track implementation.

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: DevX Q2B2: s2 continuous deployment
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

<!--
Summarize what the team wants to achieve this iteration.
- What are the problems we want to solve or what information do we want to gather?
- Why is solving those problems or gathering that information important?
- How do we plan to solve those problems or gather that information?
-->

s2 needs an interim continuous deployment mechanism for dogfooding purposes while Cloud works on a long-term CD system for the Cloud product. The DevX team will drive these efforts with the assistance of the Cloud team.

@michaellzc has prepared the following for us:

- [x] `mg update-golden` - will fetch the latest docker-compose and update tags to latest (https://github.com/sourcegraph/deploy-sourcegraph-managed/pull/788)
- [x] `mg upgrade` - use the updated golden files to upgrade the instance (https://github.com/sourcegraph/customer/issues/1141)
- [x] GCP authentication in GitHub Actions: https://github.com/sourcegraph/deploy-sourcegraph-managed/blob/main/.github/workflows/reload_frontend.yml
- [x] Automate: https://github.com/sourcegraph/customer/issues/1174

The above tools can be used to create an action that runs the golden update, upgrade to it, and then commit the changes back to repo.

Related: https://github.com/sourcegraph/customer/issues/1153

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: CI key result metrics are centralized and aggregated in reports
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve
<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->

Today, there's not an easy way for stakeholders to get at-a-glance observability into the health of our CI pipeline. We're capturing daily metrics for "time main is red" in the #dev-experience channel, but this data is insufficient because it conflates incidents (which are mostly in the hands of PR authors themselves) with flakes (which can be improved with more stable tests and more resilient infrastructure). These are different problems with different solutions, and they have different implications for pipeline health. 

## Measure of success
<!-- How will we validate/verify/know that we have solved the problem? -->

The most important CI metrics are captured and easily observable. Our hope is that by the end of the quarter, as a result of our other efforts, these metrics will reflect that less than 10% of builds are flaking per day and build time is under 30 minutes. 

## Solution summary
<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artifacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

We will export the identified metrics to a single service, making it easily consumable for stakeholders and allow for better decision making based on said metrics. 

Artefacts:
- [Scratch pad - CI pipeline metrics](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1QvyMnMJIAEMmVcmHAkj472Fhx7bbSEBjF9DPXafqvTc/edit#)

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?
<!--
Reference customers by linking to their issue in our accounts repository. DON'T REFERENCE CUSTOMERS BY NAME!

Example:
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/537
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
-->

Internal Sourcegraph stakeholders

## Impact on use cases

<!--
Describe how this roadmap item contributes to improving the customer experience for one or more of the 5 use cases and apply the relevant use-case/* labels to this issue.

For enablement projects that don't target a specific use case, describe how you expect this work to enable teams/projects that are focused on use cases.
-->

This work contributes to our overall effort to increase operational maturity. 

## Delivery plan
<!--
The overall plan for how we are going to achieve this roadmap item. This should be formulated as a checklist of concrete steps that are kept up-to-date so anyone can glace at the issue description to get a sense of what we have already delivered and what remains.

Each item on this list is ideally a concrete deliverable with an estimated delivery date and owner, but we don't want false precision, so just document the plan to the best of your ability, even if you don't have all the steps yet.
-->

- [x] [Identify the metrics we want to capture](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1QvyMnMJIAEMmVcmHAkj472Fhx7bbSEBjF9DPXafqvTc/edit)
- [x] Make sure we are capturing desired metrics ([`buildchecker history`](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/dev/buildchecker/README.md#history))
- [x] Slack notification to report weekly incident and flake numbers
- [x] Push relevant metrics to Okay

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: cesrjimenez
TrackingIssues.Title: Fix the alert and dashboard for commitgraph
TrackingIssues.Body:
A recent change to the metrics moved the metric that updated this jobs health to a new dashboard. The alert didn't get updated yet, and was firing as soon as cloud deployed the most recent version. The job is running as expected, and there is no known disruption to cloud service.

The team will fix the alert and dashboard next week.

TrackingIssues.Author: valerybugakov
TrackingIssues.Title: CSS Modules migration: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Description

It's important to completely migrate to CSS Modules to improve the front-end developer experience. This will give us important benefits such as:

1. Most of the CSS will be removed from the global scope â€” easier to maintain and update.
2. Stylesheets written for components will be consistent through the codebase. All components will use CSS modules.
3. CSS recompilation time will be significantly reduced because CSS modules can be rebuilt independently from each other.

Based on [the CSS isolation RFC](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VedPoFy7WIuHeXPzwRGMmgjDPL4CBdTKmhy4OBmlmf8/edit#heading=h.trqab8y0kufp).

The Code Insight lives on the [Frontend Platform migrations dashboard](https://sourcegraph.com/insights/dashboards/frontendPlatformMigrations).

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: â­ Q3B1: GCP Cost Saving Phase 2
TrackingIssues.Body:
Previous work: 

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/38347 
- [WIP GCP Cost Savings Bet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1eLpTgsIgxUhb9AN67vkWdhDvbYayTB8--V7EMdUb-_0/edit#)

## Problem

Dotcom and preprod were largely over provisioned as at the time multi-tenancy was the prioritized strategy for Sourcegraph. 

Now that Cloud (Single tenancy) is the new strategy, there is a huge opportunity to tune our infrastructure for cost and performance. We made pretty good progress on the previous one, see https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/38347#issuecomment-1252601209 but there are still many things left to do. 

Now that we have S2, DogFood is also a good candidate for cost reduction. 

## Scope

We have used cookie cutter templates in the past that over provisioned our infrastructure; to reduce cloud cost and properly tune infrastructure we can work on the following:

- Identify services and deployments that are over provisioned using metrics to backup our reasoning
- Remove redundant or legacy infrastructure added in the past that creates overhead
- Work with other internal teams to understand how their services work and what is the proper deployment baseline
- Implement new tooling to help us control environments and reduce workloads

### Boundaries 

Sourcegraph dotcom and preprod 
Dogfood
Sourcegraph-CI 

### Definition of Done

- GitServer & Indexed-search are operating on dotcom at their minimal provisioning while still operating properly. 
- Dogfood environment is operating at their minimal provisioning while still operating properly
- Removal of environments that are not being used anymore (Preprod or Dogfood)
- Exhibit how much cost saving this brings on a monthly basis. 
- Create platform for teams to easily monitor their cost

## Payout 

We have an opportunity here to save over $100k/month on dotcom, dogfood and preprod. Our goal is to not just cut costs, but to correctly tune our infrastructure so that we arenâ€™t wasteful while still performant. These extra resources can be allocated to other parts of the company to help grow and sustain our business. 

## Approach
We have the following areas to work on

- Dotcom
  - Work with search-core and reduce indexed-search disk allocation
  - Deep dive on dotcomâ€™s backup tooling (velero) and see how we can optimize backup schedules and snapshot creation
  - Work with frontend platform to reduce CPU/Mem allocation for their frontend services
  - Determine if moving over to managed SQL is worth it
- Preprod
  - Remove cluster or spin down to low costing environment for infrastructure testing
- Dogfood
  - Remove cluster or spin down to low costing environment for infrastructure testing

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: unclejustin
TrackingIssues.Title: [Webapp Refactor]: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
This is a placeholder for a general readiness discussion.

[The main RFC/overview doc on the Code Insight FE types problem](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GYLfV6VCB42YyoqWCoM9ACFaEnPQz1n5_veArEVCus4/edit#heading=h.gt6sdv90qn1)

Notes: This is referring to the frontend only. This also assumes that _something_ will be asked of us in the current codebase (i.e. dashboards). None of this is necessary if we never touch `/insights` again.

- We must get rid of the context-based API class since this approach is no longer needed and it makes our codebase more complicated. This class-based approach isn't something that other parts of the product adopted, and therefore it's difficult to reuse outside of code insights, and it makes it harder to bring some UI into code insights from other parts of the product.

- We must assess what code needs to be moved out of the enterprise and into shared. Right now, it is impossible to reuse some CI code that will slow down or even prohibit development later. **Example:** For the aggregation feature, we had to extract some components so they would be available. It took a decent amount of time before we could start working on the feature. It makes sense that this will happen again, so we should do our best to prepare for it.

- We must remove most custom frontend types and consume the GraphQL types directly. Adding, updating and testing are still harder than they could be because of all this debt we carry.

Strategic customers have a much higher expectation of resiliency, plus many more eyes on our product. We need to tighten things up before it's a problem.

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: Frontend Platform core workflow performance: Tracking Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
Goal: **Noticeably improve performance across the core workflow for Sourcegraph 4.0** This is also a placeholder issue for ongoing, post-4.0 performance improvements that we expect to be identified through https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/39272

### Plan

Original drafts and discussion [in this Google doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ic2bt29YKRfcNe6b5jiU0lB9ajzcoUhJcOFCvcQmIX8/edit)

This tracking issue is a collection of work that we think will be valuable and worth doing for the 4.0 release. 

**Note**: This tracking issue comes with the caveat that, as of writing, it has been created from ~3 days of sporadic performance investigations, and that we are slightly limited by some uncertainty with the search/file UX changes for 4.0. _It is still subject to changes as we discover new possible performance wins_.

TrackingIssues.Author: BolajiOlajide
TrackingIssues.Title: Sign commits created by Batch Changes with GitHub App (Tracking)
TrackingIssues.Body:
This issue is related to #15271. 

We have requests from some of our customers to add an extra layer of security when creating changesets from a Batch Change to have the associated commits in a changeset signed by the author of the Batch Change. To achieve tho

* [Gitlab](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/repository/ssh_signed_commits/)
* [Github](https://github.blog/changelog/2022-08-23-ssh-commit-verification-now-supported/)
* Bitbucket [(Unsupported)](https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/Sign-commit-with-SSH-Key/qaq-p/2002101)
* Azure DevOps [(Unsupported)](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/show-whether-commits-are-verified-with-gpg-key-on/383281)

The proposal here is to have users generate SSH keys on Sourcegraph, the private key will be encrypted and stored and used for creating commits, while the public key will be displayed to the user to be added to their code hosts.

Thanks to Erik, we have a draft PR [here](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/43286/files). 

The scope of work involved to finish this implementation includes:
- Extending the user credential and site admin credential types by a flag "I want signing bool" that can be toggled from the UI
  - If that is checked, we will show the generated SSH key regardless of if ssh on the code host is enabled
  - And inform the user that they need to store that key in their profile as a signing key
- Polishing the gitserver part of that PR, likely want some testing and such
- Adding some feature gating because older GitHub instances don't support this signing type
- Investigating if GitLab supports this, implementing support for it if so
- Documenting
- Testing

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: pecigonzalo
TrackingIssues.Title: Distribution: 2020.11.03 - Amazing Otter
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### [Support new and existing deployments](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/74)

This is an ongoing expense, we anticipate this taking no more than 5d of work spread across the entire team.

#### [Releases are created in a single day](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/90)

We have a goal of reducing the time it takes to create releases, and this current several-day system has encouraged us to view releases as â€œbakedâ€ rather than â€œsnapshots of the main branchâ€, leading to situations where main is broken and we have to retrospectively fix it or adding last minute features.

- @davejrt 
- @bobheadxi 
- @daxmc99 

#### [Market k8s.sgdev.org internally](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/107)

Make k8s.sgdev.org a compelling destination for Sourcegraph engineers to encourage dogfood. Changes should mostly be surface-level improvements.

- @bobheadxi 
- @davejrt 
- @pecigonzalo 


#### [Implement 2+ sourcegraph.com services using dhall](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/71)

`sourcegraph.com` sees the highest amount of Kubernetes changes out of all of our deployments + `deploy-sourcegraph`. Scoping a single component limits the customizations that we need to implement and allows for easier onboarding other engineers.

- @ggilmore 
- @uwedeportivo

### Availability

Period is from **November 3rd** to **November 14th (9 working days)**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period. _This is a shorter iteration to align sprints with weeks_.

- **Dave (1d, Nov 1)**
