TrackingIssues.Author: tsenart
TrackingIssues.Title: Cloud: 3.18 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Status

This tracking issue is being worked on.

### Context

This iteration is the first we're working officially as the cloud team on items from the [RFC 151 roadmap](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qSSo83MJNcNbJhQOhDyHsGBCYPjyr7uhVQKGfZ8Vxfg/edit#heading=h.az00lc90wa5j), which we have no OKRs for yet.

However, there's still work outside of this roadmap that needs to be completed, and as such has been prioritised in this iteration, namely:

- @unknwon is working on [RFC 167: Enforce product tiers](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1XozQ4JINJqirdaG-XqGtboT2-PlIXPyBn6EwV7Q3pWI/edit), starting with **Spike: Enforcing product tiers #11577** and ensuing work is addressing the OKR `Product: Deliver on projects to increase and support sales efforts. KR: License keys enable features for each license tier.`
- @unknwon is wrapping up work from [RFC 137: Better automated testing](https://docs.google.com/document/d/14f7lwfToeT6t_vxnGsCuXqf3QcB5GRZ2Zoy6kYqBAIQ/edit#heading=h.trqab8y0kufp). There's no specific OKR for this effort.
- @keegancsmith is wrapping up work from [RFC 136: Navigating Version Contexts](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-Hn3bSVmwZ9iY0nfztXMoDfzWMdOHYTKrhK2F5ZJZI8/edit#) with **Index multiple (non-master) branches #6728** which directly addresses `Product: Deliver on projects to increase and support sales efforts. KR: Users can search across contexts of their organizationâ€™s code as outlined in RFC 136. `
- @keegancsmith will be working streaming search support in the context of Sourcegraph Cloud roadmap afterwards â€” no OKR for this yet.
- @ryanslade main focus will be on **scaling repo-updater** as part of the Sourcegraph Cloud roadmap.
- @daxmc99 main focus will be on [RFC 174: HA Postgres for Sourcegraph Cloud](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1zNy-9QTAS4-i4C-ooFsfSwLf-kdnIJlTE8-uyub6-Ik/edit#heading=h.kct20jix194c) #11496
- @asdine main focus will be on **Store git commits in Postgres** as part of the Sourcegraph Cloud roadmap.

### Availability

Period is from **20th of June** to **20th of July**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- @keegancsmith: TBD
- @tsenart: 21d
- @unknwon: 19d (National holidays June 25-26)
- @ryanslade: 21d
- @daxmc99: 21d
- @asdine: 20d
- Chayim Kirshen (Security Engineer starting June 29th): TBD

### Workload

TrackingIssues.Author: pecigonzalo
TrackingIssues.Title: Distribution: 3.19 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### [Support new and existing deployments](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/74)

This is an ongoing expense, we anticipate this taking no more than 10d of work spread across the entire team.

#### [Reduce upgrade overhead](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/71)

Upgrading Kubernetes deployments requires customers spend a lot of engineering time to converge our released Kubernetes manifests with their fork as documented inÂ [RFC-141](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1tsksAlqe77NmdPLw7oyy2u0-1rYDQeVpPeDo1T0Xt50).

We will finish the [Dhall](https://dhall-lang.org/) investigation and make a decision by the end of 3.19.

- @ggilmore
- @uwedeportivo

#### [Increase our e2e test frequency](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/72)

To increase our release cadence, we need to be able to run e2e tests more frequently. This is currently not possible as our CI infrastructure causes tests to be unreliable.

- @slimsag
- @davejrt
- @pecigonzalo 

#### [Support per-team alerts](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/73)

To allow teams to support and monitor the services and features they ship, we need to be able to route alerts to the relevant teams as described in [RFC-189](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1noZf86g2QwTbFNt3XSSbMg36D-_HCptP1thMzZsgt2Q).

- @bobheadxi
- @davejrt
- @slimsag

### Availability

Period is from **July 20th** to **August 19th (23 working days)**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- **Dave**: 22d (off July20)
- **Robert**: 23d

### Workload

TrackingIssues.Author: valerybugakov
TrackingIssues.Title: Strom ğŸŒªï¸: web architecture changes to improve UI performance
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Goals

Come up with a new approach for defining web application pages that would yield better UI performance and significantly reduce the complexity of the React tree.

1. Improve the web application performance.
2. Reduce the complexity of the React tree.
3. Standardize the new approach for defining web application pages + data-loading functions.
4. Come up with an approach that would allow us to switch to SSR if we want to later.

Prefer committing to ideas that we can deliver incrementally and build on top of each other. That way, we can stop at any point with the deliverable MVP and consider extending the project to build more stuff.

<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: team/code-exploration --> 
<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: i-acknowledge-this-goes-into-the-release -->

TrackingIssues.Author: 5h1rU
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking `Welcome feature` stacked PR's
TrackingIssues.Body:
- [x] #23316 - [x] #23317 - [x] #23318 - [x] #23319 - [x] #23320 ### Description These PR's adds the post-sign-up (welcome) flow + a `Stepper` and `Terminal` components (@5h1rU ) Relevant links: * [New post-signup flow epic](https://sourcegraph.atlassian.net/browse/COREAPP-3) * [UX enhancements to new post-signup flow epic](https://sourcegraph.atlassian.net/browse/COREAPP-18) * [Design in Figma](https://www.figma.com/file/zXvqCASHDzmvKbrAl1EVsd/Public-and-Private-Repos-for-Users-on-Cloud?node-id=2633%3A60566) ### Demo https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1319181/126425814-01ec3cf8-4bb9-4512-b994-7440709ef50f.mov ### Notes ğŸš§
How to test in Dev (hard)
It could be hard to test the welcome flow in Dev because of: - local repo caches - feature flags - local storage cache keys that prevent the user from going through the flow multiple times **Steps**: 1. _to enable the post sign up flow_: **a**) (**preferred way**) enable `enablePostSignupFlow` experimental feature for the instance Experimental features can be found here: `Settings -> Site Admin -> Site configuration -> experimentalFeatures` **b**) add a user `AllowUserViewPostSignup` tag to your user Local DB access needed 2. _to see private repositories_: Set `externalService.userMode` to `all` in Site configuration (see above) 3. _If you want repositories to be cloned again_: remove `rm -rf ~/.sourcegraph/repos/` directory (local cache) 4. _to trigger the flow_: sign out and register a new user
I tried adding some extra context in single comments to some files. ### Todos - [x] Because of backend API limitation, we decided to change how the `Terminal` displays progress data. Now I need to confirm with @quinnkeast what UI/UX changes need to happen to make progress more easily readable.

TrackingIssues.Author: chrispine
TrackingIssues.Title: Campaigns 3.20 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Goal

**Remove the feature flag, so campaigns will be available by default.** This means getting campaigns to a state where we are comfortable doing so.

In order to feel good about the removal of the feature flag, this release will entail a good deal of cleaning up, polish, and minor bug fixes. We will also be focusing on documentation, user testing, more design work, and a marketing video and blog post.

As in the previous release cycle, we will work as a team to meet this single goal, dividing up the work roughly as follows: @eseliger will focus on front-end features and collaboration with design, @mrnugget will work on the back-end, and @LawnGnome will continue with `src-cli` work. (While this is the same division of labor as last cycle, we state an explicit intention to rotate in the future, so no one becomes a knowledge silo or â€œthe engineer who always does Xâ€.) This is also @chrispineâ€™s first full release cycle, so he has some tasks aimed at ramping him up.

Campaigns will remain in beta for 3.20.

### Availability

Period is from August 20th to September 18th (22 working days, ~17 working days before branch cut). Please write the days you wonâ€™t be working and the number of working days for the period.

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

- @mrnugget 5d vacation (September 7 to September 11)
- @LawnGnome: 5d vacation (August 31 to September 4) + 1d public holiday (Labour Day, September 7)
- @eseliger: Likely 5d vacation as well

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: â­ Q3B1 Bazel: Build our frontend code
TrackingIssues.Body:
See [Bazel @ Sourcegraph](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HYbaYz9GAhjfHKCMgxi8O3Zi6n3uDkezR3pETxjtO8g/edit) for the document introducing the idea. 

## Problem

Introducing Bazel in our codebase is challenging, as it will require us to adapt our codebase to the constraints that Bazel requires to be able to provide the guarantees we are after: hermetic builds, better caching, reliably test only what changed, etc â€¦ (see the original doc). 

One of the most significant sources of slowness on the CI is the frontend client, which takes a long time to build and has some flaky tests due to browser based nature. Integrating frontend code and Bazel while retaining a good enough developer experience is also challenging, as the ecosystem is moving very fast and our codebase has some debts when it comes to tooling (running behind major versions on significant dependencies, such as test runners, etc â€¦) 

Therefore this makes the frontend the best candidate to get started with Bazel. If we can't make it work, there is very little point in porting the other parts of the codebase, but at least we'll have identified what are the areas that need to be updated on the frontend side to make it work. 
## Scope

### Boundaries 

- Focus purely on the frontend code
- Web client first. 
- Audience: people familiar with Bazel
- CI + local
- Unit Tests > Integration Tests > (E2E tests, stretch goal)

### Definition of Done

- Can run client tests, if and only if necessary. 
- Can build a client bundle, if and only if necessary. 
- Can do the above both in CI and local
- Behind a feature flag in CI, unless we're 100% sure it's working well. 
- CI runs its own Bazel cache.

## Payout

We know that one of the trickiest parts of our codebase can work with Bazel or we have established what needs to be changed to make it work, were we to fail this bet. 

Faster (>10% avg per day) builds on CI. 

Less build failures on main due to flakes (from [10%,15%] to [8%, 12%]) 

## Approach 

Use aspect.build rules for the frontend. 
Get direct help from the FrontEnd Platform team.

### Tracked issues

We want to break apart `<FilteredConnection />` into composable chunks and refactor existing parts of the app to a new approach.

This will make it much easier to make changes to individual components, specifically UI changes. It'll also mean it's a lot easier to gain understanding and write tests around the `FilteredConnection` logic that has been built over time.

TrackingIssues.Author: mrnugget
TrackingIssues.Title: Campaigns 3.19 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Goal

**Release the [new spec-based campaigns workflow](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/@campaigns-new-flow/user/campaigns/hello_world_campaign) behind a feature flag for site-admins and non-site-admins.**

After Quinn designed the new campaigns workflow in the past two iterations in [#10921](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/10921) we finished the API design and conceptual work in the last iteration and are now ready to implement the complete workflow. Since @eseliger and @mrnugget already started the implementation in 3.18, our goal for this iteration is to finish the implementation and release the new campaigns workflow to customers.

We are going to work on this single goal together as a team. @eseliger will be working on the frontend. After finishing GitLab support by implementing webhook support, @LawnGnome will first focus on the `src-cli` side and then join @mrnugget in implementing the missing pieces in the backend. We anticipate that the first half of the iteration will be spent working on well-defined tasks and the second half on polishing and bugfixing.

We also want to combine the release of the new workflow with the loosening of the campaigns feature-flag: instead of campaigns only being fully available to site-admins and in a read-only mode to users, we want to make keep the feature flag but, when enabled, make campaigns available to all users of a Sourcegraph instance.

Campaigns will still be marked as "beta", since we don't feel confident to go out of beta with the first release of the new workflow (that included major changes to large parts of our codebase). But the aim is that 3.19 will be the last release with campaigns as a beta feature and should be considered more of a "release candidate" than a beta. 

### Availability

Period is from July 20th to August 19th (23 working days). Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

**NOTE**: This iteration will also include Q3 planning and a new 360 review cycle.

- @mrnugget: 19d (on vacation: 12.-17. August)
- @eseliger: 23d
- @LawnGnome: 22d (BC Day 3rd August)

TrackingIssues.Author: malomarrec
TrackingIssues.Title: Restrict who can create batch changes (needs RBAC)
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Problem statement

Some of our customers operate in regulated industries and have compliance requirements to **limit access to creating batch changes to only some users.**

### Problem validation / why 

Our initial reaction to this request was that :
- Permission issue: Batch Changes, when set up properly, map code hosts permissions and do not give more access to users than they already have without batch changes.
- PR spam issue: any developer can script out opening many changesets

We have verified that this was clear to those customers and confirmed that they still need to control access to batch changes to meet compliance goals. The customer's perception is that enabling developers to access a tool that makes it easier to automate creating many changesets increases risk and creates a compliance issue.

#### Other concerns

We were initially concerned that this could [slow down adoption](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1QkNLeLYOB_IwMp4s9Pd8kRiayI4EhvUp06XmDY9X3aQ/edit#heading=h.rvuii5ra4y31) and have a business impact. This was mitigated by making sure all users can _view_ batch changes, and only `creating` batch changes is optionally restricted.

### Customers

The customers are currently **blocked**:

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/579
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/1
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/3
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/8613

>There's no way we're going to give x,000 engineers the ability to deploy changes across all our repositories

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/8243
Also see [product gap](https://sourcegraph2020.lightning.force.com/lightning/r/Product_Gap__c/a1B5b00000MwQNZEA3/view).

### Solution

**MVP:**

- Allow site-admins to optionally whitelist who can `create` batch changes. If a `restrictBatchChangesAccess` is set with a list of allowListed users, then creating Batch Changes is restricted to those users. What does that mean:
  - Running a preview with src-cli gives an error message `Creating batch changes has been restricted to some users only, you should contact your admin to get access`.
  - The create batch change button is disabled with an infobox and the same message
  - The Create batch change button on the search page is hidden (as well as any other buttons that prompt to create batch changes from another context)
  - All bulk actions / any edit action are disabled
  - The Batch Changes dashboard and batch change page are still visible, as well as non-edit `src batch` commands

TrackingIssues.Author: keegancsmith
TrackingIssues.Title: Core Services: 3.6 Tracking Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Goal

99th percentile latency of the search query â€œprintâ€ at 42req/s with 20k repos is under 2s.

## Availability

- @mrnugget: Not working July 8th-10th
- @tsenart All month
- @keegancsmith All month

## Dependencies

We will want to avoid conflicting with the work the Search team is doing https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/4582

## Completed

Our main focus in this iteration was to load test the large-scale instance at k8s.sgdev.org and to analyze profiling data to spot bottlenecks and possible improvements. 

The first major theme we found were large and needless allocations in the GraphQL layer, that were due to multiple parts of the code relying on a list of all repositories. That caused out-of-memory errors, GC pressure and resulted in increased request latency. 

Solving this issue by reducing the number of allocations and changing what we allocate took up a large part of this iteration. 

After that, we focused on the next component, Zoekt, by profiling it and trying to understand its behavior under load. 

We now have multiple ideas for improving Zoekt's performance, including horizontal scaling. 

- [x] Start by adding a benchmark for the `(r *searchResolver) doResults` method in the GraphQL layer
  - [x] Use `*searchbackend.Zoekt.DisableCache = true` in `BenchmarkSearchResults`
  - [x] Create a database-hitting integration version of `BenchmarkSearchResults`
- [x] Add a `backend.ListRepoIDs` method to be used in `resolveRepositories`. This could use a [roaring bitset](https://www.notion.so/thorstenball/Sourcegraph-Performance-Investigation-5b8a753039e34c3da18098700ac214f9) to encode the IDs in a compressed way. **Update after investigation on June 28th**: we cannot use only the repository IDs, because a lot of places in the search code path use the repository name, including `gitserver`.
- [x] externalrepospec not a pointer in types.Repo
- [x] Avoiding allocating the repositoryRevision slice if all revisions are empty. (@tsenart)
- [x] Before search results are returned from `doResults` the repositories-IDs need to be turned into repositories ("hydrated"). This requires a `backend.LoadByIDs`. **Update after investigation on June 28th**: the easier and "dumb" thing (because it includes N+1 queries) to do would be to load "minimal repositories" with only `ID` and `Name` and `ExternalRepo` fields. Whenever a method on `*repositoryResolver` that's not ID, Name, etc. is called, we load the information from the database and fill up the `*repositoryResolver.Repo`
- [x] Dogfood traces for common paths so that these are useful (donâ€™t have to jump straight to logs)
- [x] Clone status indicator #4120 #3413
  - [x] Fix status indicator to show actual cloning status (#4591)
  - [x] Follow #4591 up with investigating possible performance improvements described [here](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/4591#issuecomment-503899644)
  - [x] Remove feature flag and enable feature by default
- [x] Possible follow-up on #4685: delete all existing `repoupdater` migrations now that they've been in two versions of Sourcegraph (#4886)
- [x] Adding a new external service that syncs slowly results in 504 Gateway Timeout (#4511)

## Won't do

- Abandoned because at the moment it wouldn't bring us that much closer to our goal, compared to other ideas that we will be pursuing. We might still do this in the future:
  - [ ] Fix ACL layer to work with repository IDs instead of names (https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/4812)
  - [ ] Add support for repository IDs to Zoekt.
    - Record sourcegraph ID in zoekt shards
    - Support specifying a set of sourcegraph IDs in `zoekt/query.Q`
  - [ ] IDs need to be stable for "restoring of previously deleted repos" to work in repo-updater/Zoekt

## Backlogged

- [ ] Repositories can end up in bad state and harm overall system #4565
- [ ] Introduce some form of rate limiting in the GraphQL API to prevent slowing down requests for everyone. 
- [ ] Refactor the "scatter/gather" pattern to remove duplication in `gitserver.Client` ([see comment](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/4440#discussion_r292517859))
- [ ] Refactor `repoupdater.Client.do` method to use the same interface as the `bitbucketserver.Client.send` method ([see comment here](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/4440#discussion_r292519431))

## Moved to 3.7

- [ ] Determine resource allocation "equation" and update docs for admins to provision them accordingly for their Sourcegraph installation (e.g. https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/scaling-bitbucket-server-776640073.html)
  - _Note_: We don't know enough yet to do this.
- [ ] Experiment with more efficient posting lists in Zoekt https://github.com/sourcegraph/zoekt/pull/10
  - _Note_: Partially done.

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: GraphQL Client adoption: Tracking Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
We want to refactor more code to use [Apollo](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/graphql#graphql-client).

Key actions:
- Migrating from `requestGraphQL | queryGraphQL | mutateGraphQL` usage to [useMutation and useQuery](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/client/shared/src/graphql/graphql.ts?L127-157) hooks.
- Utilising the [Apollo cache](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/graphql#how-do-i-use-the-apollo-cache) by adding the correct `id` fields to queries or providing alternative [keyFields](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/caching/cache-configuration/#customizing-identifier-generation-by-type) to use.

This tracking issue is to capture the work required to migrate much of the codebase to this new approach.

**Note**: While working on refactoring code, it would also be beneficial to clean up and simplify requests where we can. This [PR comment from Rok](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/40263/files/06d001af01d76041472609e49f60c23b1f6dab64#r946393225) is just one example of the types of fetching functions we'd hope to clean up. The goal would be to improve readability and make these functions much easier to debug when there are issues.

TrackingIssues.Author: courier-new
TrackingIssues.Title: [Accessibility]: Audit Batch Changes user journeys
TrackingIssues.Body:
As part of our goal to obtain WCAG 2.1 AA Accessibility compliance by the end of FY23, we will need to audit all major user journeys within the Batch Changes product, log accessibility issues, and plan to fix as many as we can.

This issue reflects the **auditing** stage of this work.

See https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/31475 for more.

### How to use this issue

At the end of every sprint, @courier-new will identify and â­ 5 new user journeys that have not yet been audited, in order of relative importance, until every user journey has been audited. These issues should be moved into P0, and their audits completed over the course of that sprint. Next-up issues will be identified and pre-flagged with â¬†ï¸, and moved into P1.

For planning purposes, each team member should plan to set aside at least half a day per sprint to dedicate to conducting a new audit and fixing issues reported from a previously-completed audit.

During an audit, a team member can try to fix any trivial issues encountered as they are conducting the audit. For larger, non-trivial issues or issues with design questions, a team member should record the issue using the [accessibility issue template](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/new?assignees=&labels=accessibility%2Cwcag%2F2.1%2Cwcag%2F2.1%2Ffixing%2Cestimate%2F3d&template=accessibility_issue.yaml&title=%5BAccessibility%5D%3A+) to follow up on in [the fixing stage](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/34376). For issues with straightforward requirements and steps to reproduce, consider setting the ticket aside to delegate to GitStart.

An issue should be marked as done when each type of audit is complete and all accessibility issues identified in it have been logged.

Let's get rid of that pesky migration conflict when two different teams merge around the same with database changes. We can get around this by reading migration definitions in a manner which don't impose a complete sequential order so that two unrelated migrations do not conflict.

See the attached issues for an implementation plan.

TrackingIssues.Author: indradhanush
TrackingIssues.Title: sg maintenance improvement tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

`sg maintenance` has been identified as the root cause for corrupting repos. This has caused us to effectively have it disabled in all MIs and also for some customers. Along with that, some customers continue to see repo corruption.

While we know that running `sg maintenance` causes repo corruption, we have not yet identified the root cause. This tracking issue will focus on identifying the root causes and subsequently fixing them.

TrackingIssues.Author: tsenart
TrackingIssues.Title: Cloud 2020-10-07 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

1. RFC 167 - Enforcing product license tiers: @flying-robot and @unknwon will work on this with the aim to have it all done by the end of the cycle.
1. RFC 211 - User added public repos: @ryanslade and @asdine are wrapping up the last bits of this (monitoring and alerting, enabling it for all teammates, making a demo video).
1. Syncing repos is more scalable: We'll be paying down some technical debt we have introduced in repo-updater in the last few months, with the aim to make further changes down the line easier to implement.

Apart from these high level themes, we're going to work on a few customer issues and smaller improvements.

TrackingIssues.Author: pecigonzalo
TrackingIssues.Title: Distribution 3.21 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### [Support new and existing deployments](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/74)

This is an ongoing expense, we anticipate this taking no more than 10d of work spread across the entire team.

#### Support Security in deploying a log analysis tool

Security is planning to deploy a centralized logging and analysis system and will require our assistance to setup and review this new infrastructure.

#### [Implement 2+ sourcegraph.com services using dhall](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/71)

`sourcegraph.com` sees the highest amount of Kubernetes changes out of all of our deployments + `deploy-sourcegraph`. Scoping a single component limits the customizations that we need to implement and allows for easier onboarding other engineers.

- @ggilmore 
- @uwedeportivo
- @slimsag 

#### [Releases are created in a single day](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/90)

We have a goal of reducing the time it takes to create releases, and this current several-day system has encouraged us to view releases as â€œbakedâ€ rather than â€œsnapshots of the main branchâ€, leading to situations where main is broken and we have to retrospectively fix it or adding last minute features.

- @slimsag 
- @davejrt 
- @uwedeportivo 
- @bobheadxi 

#### [Split infrastructure into separate GCP projects](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/92)

GCP utilizes project wide roles and permissions, to ensure resources are isolated from each other and reduce the blast radius of changes, we should split resources into separate projects. Additionally, this will grant us more insight into our infrastructure costs and will become more important as we grow and expand it.

- @pecigonzalo 

### Availability

Period is from **September 20th** to **October 19th (21 working days)**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- **Gonza**: 19d (23rd Sept and TBD)

TrackingIssues.Title: Distribution: 2020.10.20 - Vibrant Beetle
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### [Support new and existing deployments](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/74)

This is an ongoing expense, we anticipate this taking no more than 5d of work spread across the entire team.

#### [Create a Dhall demo to gather customer feedback](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/71)

We would like to create a demo that we can share with customers and gather feedback about our proposed solution.

- @ggilmore 
- @uwedeportivo 

#### [Releases are created in a single day](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/90)

We have a goal of reducing the time it takes to create releases, and this current several-day system has encouraged us to view releases as â€œbakedâ€ rather than â€œsnapshots of the main branchâ€, leading to situations where main is broken and we have to retrospectively fix it or adding last minute features.

- @davejrt 
- @bobheadxi 
- @pecigonzalo 

### Availability

Period is from **October 20th** to **November 2nd (10 working days)**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- @uwedeportivo (5d, date TBD)

TrackingIssues.Author: quinnkeast
TrackingIssues.Title: RFC 227: Code monitoring
TrackingIssues.Body:
Tracking issue for [RFC 227: Code monitoring](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_R5DgpUkxyZilsJ9vBQm5cvRPT2udc3tZIPg2q3cnZU/edit#), in response to [PD 12](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1D9Useap2CuPJmed7Htdoho4nyzM0MMT0LJL_MlhoMv4/edit#).

<!-- BEGIN WORK -->
<!-- BEGIN ASSIGNEE: quinnkeast -->
@quinnkeast

- [ ] Add link to user research signup to saved search notification emails ([#13673](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/13673))
<!-- END ASSIGNEE -->
<!-- END WORK -->

**Version 1**

- Private code monitors
    - Emails 
    - Web Hooks (focus: Test with Zapier, Slack)
With private code monitors individuals can create code monitors for themselves (no sharing or organization level code monitors). Version 1 improves the existing functionality ([saved searches with notifications](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/code_search/explanations/features#saved-searches)) significantly where the user experience is poor and the value of monitoring isnâ€™t communicated in the product clearly. 

- [ ] Allow users to test the new email and webhook code monitor they've set up
- [ ] Throw error message if SMTP email support isn't enabled for a customer instance
- [ ] Documentation
    - Link from `Learn more` to core concepts 
    - When notifications are sent (frequency)
         - Query performance related time delays
    - Mention performance constraints that can improve ux like encouraging scoping to repos, etc.
    - Getting Started Examples
    - Link from `confidential information` to related issues
    - Webhook data format information (Simple, Zapier, Slack)

**Future Iterations**
- Event Log
    - See a code monitor's event history on sourcegraph (both successes and failures, particularly useful for webhooks)

- Starting points for code monitors
    - In future iterations, these can be a part of the actual creation flow and include additional starting points.
- More search result content in notification messages 
    - This will make notifications more valuable for users. Thereâ€™s a few considerations to keep in mind.
        - For security and compliance use cases, it isnâ€™t safe to include some content in plain text emails
        - Repository viewing permissions: Currently emails are sent via SMTP support on customers instances. 
            - We donâ€™t and I believe we canâ€™t check for repo viewing permissions easily because this happens on the customer instance. 
           - To solve this, perhaps it means supporting email sending on our systems?
            - Campaigns team is dealing with issues where we donâ€™t always have user supplied auth tokens to check their repo permissions
              - Web Hooks notifications are shared into channels consumers by multiple users. This can be a security concern.

- Scale
    - Performance needs to be monitored to understand if this can break for customers with larger codebases.
    - We currently don't have 50 repository limit for code monitoring notifications (like commit and diff search). This is because notifications are sent very frequently, helping us avoid running into performance concerns that come up with batching a huge number of notifications together. 

- Organization
    - Notify multiple recipients for users in our system. How would individuals unsubscribe in this case? 
    - Alternatively notify the entire organizations.

TrackingIssues.Author: tsenart
TrackingIssues.Title: Cloud: 3.19 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### Goal 1: Allow users to add public code from github.com, gitlab.com and bitbucket.org

@unknwon, @ryanslade and @asdine are working on this together. Figuring out multi-tenancy is going to unlock a lot of the capabilities we want from the Cloud project. External services are at the center of this because they are our current mechanism for specifying which repos to sync. We want to think through the product changes (and consequences) necessary for users and organizations to create external services on any Sourcegraph instance and at least prototype what it would look like. We recognize that we're starting work on this goal in an uphill (i.e. discovery) phase so the amount of planned work will grow over time. We'll gather feedback on the end-user product experience we're thinking of from a larger group including @christinaforney, @sqs and @rrhyne as part of this discovery process.

#### Goal 2: Store and handle external service and external account secrets securely.

@chayim, and @daxmc99 are working on this together. As we already know, there's a lot of security ground-work to do before we can allow any user or organization to use sourcegraph.com with private code. This is one of the key changes that need to happen and aligns well with the first goal for this iteration.

#### Leftover

There's some work individual members of the team are doing this iteration that was left over from the previous, notably @unknwon is working on Enforcing Product Tiers  #11577.

### Availability

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

- @unknwon: July 27 to July 31 (5 days), on vacation.
- @ryanslade: Not working 10th August

TrackingIssues.Author: burmudar
TrackingIssues.Title: DevX: Q2B2 Improve actionability of CI
TrackingIssues.Body:
<!-----

Yay, no errors, warnings, or alerts!

Conversion time: 0.51 seconds.


Using this Markdown file:

1. Paste this output into your source file.
2. See the notes and action items below regarding this conversion run.
3. Check the rendered output (headings, lists, code blocks, tables) for proper
   formatting and use a linkchecker before you publish this page.

Conversion notes:

* Docs to Markdown version 1.0Î²33
* Tue Jul 05 2022 07:51:40 GMT-0700 (PDT)
* Source doc: Scratch - Q2B2 Make CI more actionable
----->


## Problem

Devs often donâ€™t know what the pipeline is doing or why their pipeline has failed. 

We (devx) often get asked to help diagnose and figure out what the actual problem is. This is because we have in-depth knowledge about the pipeline and how it works. 

The pipeline needs to be less of a blackbox and surface useful information which allows one to investigate further.

## Boundaries

### Scope

Our primary concern is with the pipeline and its communication channels. As it stands the pipeline has 3 communication channels:

1. Buildkite UI
2. Slack notifications
3. `sg ci status`

Each channel can be enhanced to provide more contextual information and easy on-ramps to other tools that help failure diagnosis.

Improving pipeline stability also falls into improving pipeline communication. A false positive or bug communicates the wrong thing and confuses the end user. Therefore, addressing bugs falls into the scope of this bet.


### Out of scope

* Nice to haves = eye candy
* Speed improvements
* Test out buildkite tracing / opentelemetry
* Better test output can help with making a broken pipeline more actionable
    * [https://github.com/mfridman/tparse](https://github.com/mfridman/tparse)
    * [https://github.com/gotestyourself/gotestsum](https://github.com/gotestyourself/gotestsum)
        * This requires investigation as both support  ci like features
        * Does showing a test failure better improve actionability ?
        * Less test verbosity leads to less pipeline noise
            * Everyone hates verbosity until they need it

## Definition of Done

* Document our various annotations and what each link on an annotation does.
* Make everyone aware of the new on ramps to tools to help them diagnose their pipeline.
* All pipeline failures generate a unified failure annotation


## Payout:

* Annotations provide more contextual help
* All Job failures have relevant annotations
    * Some integration / client tests donâ€™t produce annotations therefore we have to add it
* Details of build failures are clearly communicated and next steps to investigate are provided.

	


### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Title: Repo Management: First-class Gerrit Support Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

TrackingIssues.Author: slimsag
TrackingIssues.Title: code insights: backend MVP implementation
TrackingIssues.Body:
This is a tracking issue for implementing the MVP backend for Code Insights.

General strategy is documented in [RFC 273: Code Insights backend](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LX6Msbxnz_DRf6OItZLaX-vELfnHGKgODkb1bVauolk/edit#heading=h.trqab8y0kufp).

**TL;DR**: We have a good amount of information that customers are interested in Code Insights. We have an experimental frontend demo we have been showing to prospective customers (viewable on k8s.sgdev.org) and multiple customers are interested in this. However, we are entirely blocked on having a scalable backend before customers can actually use it and we can get feedback on it to determine the product direction in general (there are still many open questions.) The team has not yet been able to hire a backend engineer, and Felix and Joel have chatted with me extensively about having me step in to contribute a solid foundation which customers can use at scale so we can determine what to do with the product next, and be able to make our first backend engineer hire for the team and make them be productive / have clear direction. The goal here is for @slimsag to work with the code insights team closely to add an MVP backend that can be used at scale and as a good foundation, and help with making the team generally successful in the future (once @slimsag steps back and goes onto other projects.)

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: tsenart
TrackingIssues.Title: Cloud 2020-11-04 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

1. **Cloud**: @ryanslade, @artemruts and @asdine will be working towards the first milestone of [RFC 255](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HW3WvtuYBzGpXXq3MTj1jiVscwgcKAmet-zJFf1GGZ4/edit#heading=h.trqab8y0kufp), as broken down by @quinnkeast in Product Board.
1. **Cloud Security**: @unknwon, @flying-robot and @arussellsaw will be working on faster permissions updates with webhooks, speccing out 2FA auth and potentially implementing it already this cycle, and writing an RFC for end to end testing of our authorization.
1. **Metrics**: @arussellsaw will also be working on **Log Sourcegraph extensions events in BigQuery** which unblocks the @sourcegraph/web team's ability to have metrics around their extensions work.

### Availability

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

### Tracked issues

<!-- BEGIN WORK -->

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: DevX log15 to sourcegraph/log migration Tracking issue ğŸ›¤ï¸
TrackingIssues.Body:
This is a reboot of https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/37586. 

<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: roadmap --> 
<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: team/devx --> 
<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: devx/logging --> 

### Plan

We want to migrate all `log15` related code to github.com/sourcegraph/log as it provides tighter integration with our observability stack (structured logging, contextual informations, more robust API, ...) 

As we discussed during our offsite at the beginning of August, if we all take an hour here and here to take a bit of our time to make those migrations, we can crunch through all of it much more rapidly. 

Also, we originally started on this with GitStart, which produced mixed results as it's very often much better to have at least some base Sourcegraph knowledge to conduce such migrations efficiently. 

**Tracking the migration**: 

We're tracking this migration with CodeInsights: https://sourcegraph.sourcegraph.com/insights/dashboards/ZGFzaGJvYXJkOnsiSWRUeXBlIjoiY3VzdG9tIiwiQXJnIjoxMH0=

### What's in for me if I do this? 

Other than joining the global effort toward migrating the logging code, this will give you the opportunity to walk the codebase with an actual goal in mind, making it easier to explore our codebase and be exposed to application code that you maybe haven't seen before. 

ğŸ’¡ An interesting challenge is to try to _speedrun_ those PRs, trying to see how fast and focused you can be at tackling such changes and the opportunity to study your own workflow. This is helpful because these changes are very mechanical but still includes some subtleties when it comes to define scopes and see how to drill the loggers elegantly in parts of the codebase. 

ğŸ’¡ It may be a good idea to start with this first thing in the morning before even looking at Slack. Some teammates mentioned many times how starting with coding is a great day to give the right mindset to your day when coding is the first thing you do!

### Ok, I'm up for it, how do I start?

1. Read the documentation about [How to add logging](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/how-to/add_logging), particularly the advice about [sub-loggers](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/how-to/add_logging#sub-loggers)
2. Take a look at the previous PRs that migrated stuff, that'll give you some insights of what it entails. See the tracked issues below!
3. Scout the codebase, trying to find a place where there are `log15` imports. [This query](https://sourcegraph.sourcegraph.com/search?q=context%3Aglobal+repo%3A%5E%28github%5C.com%2Fsourcegraph%2Fsourcegraph%29%24+log15.%28Debug%7CError%7CWarn%29+lang%3Ago&patternType=regexp&sm=0&groupBy=group) will show you where there are instances of `log15`
4. Find a package that you would enjoy taking a look at and dabble with. 
5. As this migration will require to drill into function calls to add `log.Logger` parameters, try to see how much that package is called by others, because that will affect the amount of changes you'll have to do. 
6. Start migrating! 

### I have submitted my PR, what do I do now? 

1. Add the tracking label `migration/log` to your PR so it gets tagged in here. 
2. Tag the devx team **and** the team responsible for that domain for the review. 
  - The owning team may have ideas on how to improve the scopes for example. 
3. If you noticed anything worth sharing, you'll want to add a log entry in our [scratch log](https://sourcegraph.sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/devx-scratch/-/blob/2022/maintenance/log.snb.md). Keep in mind that it's a Sourcegraph notebook, so if you want you can include queries to show stuff. 
4. Get your reviews and merge. If the owning team takes too long to answer, it's fine to merge as long as the PR got reviewed.

TrackingIssues.Author: asdine
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue: Scalable explicit repository permissions
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

This is the tracking issue about adding new APIs to allow large scale modifications of repository permissions.
The `setRepositoryPermissionsForUsers` GraphQL endpoint is not sufficient to manipulate repo permissions for a set of users, especially when the number of repositories is very large.
The goal here is to add a minimal set of APIs that allow more granular control over repository permissions.

Related to https://github.com/sourcegraph/customer/issues/546

We'll likely have to implement multiple codemods and lint rules to achieve this, but they will all ultimately be very similar. We should start with some initial focused issues here, so we can easily estimate future work and create a foundation to work from.

TrackingIssues.Author: Joelkw
TrackingIssues.Title: Code Insights: Beta (3.31) Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

The remaining items for us to be in beta: both from a [support perspective](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/admin/beta_and_prototype_features#beta-features) and [the conceptual requirements](https://about.sourcegraph.com/handbook/product/beta_and_experimental_feature_labels#beta-features). 

### Availability

TrackingIssues.Author: marekweb
TrackingIssues.Title: DevX: Q2B2 DevX product analytics tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Problem

We're improving how we collect and aggregate analytics and metrics that are relevant to DevX work.

We need these analytics to better inform DevX team work, and also to be able to better inform external stakeholders about the outcomes of DevX work.

[Scratch doc link.](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1EUQuyBHT6TfmpIWX1Av-nNM4OxGKWcIp_K-rixCjWqQ/edit?usp=sharing)

### Scope

- **Boundaries**
  - Confirm our preferred choice of tooling for analytics (decisions about OkayHQ, Honeycomb)
  - Identify the metrics that we're tracking
  - Transfer metrics from deprecated tooling to our new preferred tooling
  - Idenfity new metrics that we're not yet tracking but we'd like to track
- **Definition of done**
  - We have a clear idea of which metrics we're collecting and which tool to access them
  -  We make metrics available in an accessible location to stakeholders outside of the team
  - **Rollout Plan**
    -  Communicate our preferred tooling for analytics, with explanation for why we're choosing it, and which tools we will be dropping.
    - Communicate which DevX metrics we're tracking and how they might be useful outside of the team
    - Communicate which DevX metrics are informing our decisions internally to the team

TrackingIssues.Author: jyavorska
TrackingIssues.Title: Find and replace without writing code
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve

Using batch changes requires running a code rewrite tool (refactoring tool, comby, sed) which many users don't intuitively grok. Iterating on simple batch changes takes time, and isn't intuitive for many devs.
The consequence is that today, only a small niche of users use batch changes. We have an opportunity to make batch changes useful for every dev.

## Validation

- We had conversations with https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/3, who initially expected that all that batch changes does is search and replace strings and found that compelling on its own. See [notes](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ywVPx1uFmG5MjRVYsrRV5VZSvyNF5_AK_ef-ByZgtVI/edit#heading=h.ey3oi8j49w6b).
- We had similar feedback from https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/7583. Example use cases where rebranding a project (eg. after an acquisition), which involves changing logo URLs or names across a large codebase.

## Solution summary

Users can "replace in files" just like they do in the IDE:
- MVP: string search and replace
- Later: regex, structural search and replace

See [RFC 713: Compute-powered batch changes](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1c9vGgSfh35HNzhPSMltgVkMA9B1NO4QF5GgZwFlt5Ys/edit#heading=h.trqab8y0kufp) for current candidate

[mockup](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.figma.com/proto/q8pwZ1WECUTIJa3D0UzlOS/Search-And-Replace-Batch-Changes?page-id%3D37%253A6133%26node-id%3D51%253A7646%26viewport%3D1789%252C532%252C0.63%26scaling%3Dmin-zoom%26starting-point-node-id%3D51%253A7646&sa=D&source=docs&ust=1658501644158787&usg=AOvVaw1Xftx3JgdGjx-IK8mlPyTj)

## Measure of success

- MAUs increase 2x
- number batch changes/customer increase x3

## Delivery plan

- [x] map out solution candidates in RFC

<!-- LABEL: needs-design -->
<!-- LABEL: needs-rfc-->
<!-- LABEL: needs-investigation -->

<!-- END WORK -->

TrackingIssues.Author: ElizabethStirling
TrackingIssues.Title: WIP: Security 2021-01-25 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

<!--
Summarize what the team wants to achieve this iteration.
- What are the problems we want to solve or what information do we want to gather?
- Why is solving those problems or gathering that information important?
- How do we plan to solve those problems or gather that information?
-->
The main goal of this iteration is to ensure a smooth transition of responsibilities as @chayim offboards. For the most part, we'll be tackling administrative, documentation, and planning work, rather than GitHub issues.
@ElizabethStirling is getting onboarded to hiring, and is working with the team to update our [security team goals](https://about.sourcegraph.com/handbook/engineering/security/goals). She is also working on handbook documentation for security processes and responsibilities, as well as grooming our upcoming work.
@andreeleuterio is working to get onboarded on #15452 so that he can hammer out secret management during @ElizabethStirling's upcoming medical leave. We're also working to redefine and rescope how we want to manage infrastructure secrets, since managing Vault isn't feasible within the time and team constraints.
@chayim is currently offboarding and working to help ensure a smooth transition period. 

### Availability

Duration: 2021-01-25 to 2021-02-05

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

TrackingIssues.Author: pdubroy
TrackingIssues.Title: WIP: Frontend Platform Design Refresh Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

This issue tracks the work by the Frontend Platform team in executing the FY22 design refresh. See [RFC 357: Frontend Platform Refresh Plan](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Zomc7cb2uWtp86Cvl6_W0r2aaF-vdGREVeCHVOZNMOU/edit#heading=h.trqab8y0kufp) for more discussion.

- [X] New themes defined in global styles, with the ability to turn them on in the web app and Storybook. ([#19653](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/19653))
- [ ] 90% of affected components/pages covered by a visual regression test ([#19520](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/19520))
    - [ ] File Tree. Currently partially supported through Percy. It would be useful to have in the Storybook but not essential. Ticket:  https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/19736
    - [X] NavBar. Covered in Storybook: https://5f0f381c0e50750022dc6bf7-kbvryslswx.chromatic.com/?path=/story/web-nav-globalnav--anonymous-viewer
    - [ ] Symbol tree/search. Not captured in either Percy or Storybook. It needs to be done. Ticket: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/19736
    - [x] Code view. Not captured in either Percy or Storybook. I think it would be quickest to capture this through Percy, as we have some integration tests that cover this area. 
    - [x] Reference Panel - PR to add branded component to Storybook: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/19647. It should also be tested through Percy as this component can become quite involved, as that's difficult to replicate through Storybook 
    - [X] Hover Overlay. Covered in Storybook https://5f0f381c0e50750022dc6bf7-kbvryslswx.chromatic.com/?path=/story/shared-hoveroverlay--loading
    - [ ] Branch/Tag/Commits selector. Not captured in either Percy or Storybook. It needs to be done. As this is more of a self container component than a typical page, it would make sense to add to Storybook if possible. Ticket: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/19735 
    - [X] Search Results. Covered in Storybook https://5f0f381c0e50750022dc6bf7-kbvryslswx.chromatic.com/?path=/story/web-search-results-streaming-streamingsearchresults--standard-render
    - [X] Diff View. I believe this is also covered in Storybook: https://5f0f381c0e50750022dc6bf7-kbvryslswx.chromatic.com/?path=/story/web-diffs-filediffnode--all-file-node-states-overview
- [x] Enable screenshot tests in Storybook for dark-mode and redesign-theme to catch regressions. (#19955)
- [ ] Implement new theme in global styles
  - [x] Update color tokens (#19926)
  - [x] Update Bootstrap colors (https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/19970)
  - [ ] Better align files that are not using global color variables (https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/19970)
  - [x] Update typography (#19954)
- [x] Implement new design for new nav (#20023)
- [x] Introduce a feature flag for the redesign theme (#20444)
- [x] Implement new nav under feature flag (using old styles)
- [x] File tree
- [x] Code
- [x] Diff view

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue: Generic user code executor
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

The precise-code-intel-indexer and precise-code-intel-indexer-vm is (as far as we have discussed) exactly the infrastructure that the @sourcegraph/campaigns team will need to safely and efficiently apply campaigns within Sourcegraph.

As a method to increase code quality, documentation, and testing, I am going to perform an experiment to make the current set of services completely generic (and free of any code-intelligence-specific behavior or mentions). This will leave future use cases open for adoption and will also give us a chance to remove some of the cruft that accumulated during rapid development and CNCF-specific efforts.

These services are deployed only in the cloud environment, so this should not affect any user deployments.

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: leonore
TrackingIssues.Title: insights: data retention: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
**context**: code insights save data at pre-defined periodic times (hourly/daily/weekly/monthly/yearly). each data point corresponds to up to X * N rows in the database, where X is the number of repos the insight is defined to run over, and N is the number of query matches (1 for regular search, 1+ for capture group matching). we currently have no system in place to prune this data, even though we know 1) insights get slower to load the more data there is, 2) insights are not very legible the more samples are loaded.

**success criteria**
* Each insight is limited to some N samples.
* Samples older than samples[len(samples)-N:N] are moved to a separate table
* N is configurable (to some upper bound?)
* We allow users to view only a subset of samples, where the subset is of size L <= N 
* Older samples that have been moved to a separate table can be exported by a user (with their user context)

[original sync notes](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1H9jik0g5h_ZsDUTNTTAOXuW4rgnTk4wzp0HCJg5oUFs/edit)

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: â­ Q3B1: Scale Testing â€“ Manually reproducing customer issues
TrackingIssues.Body:
<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: team/devx --> 

â¡ï¸ **Bet conclusion** https://docs.google.com/document/d/1EikVa90v_itxaN5bKSfx59_Dn2q0ElEDhZA6Zp1aiCI/edit#bookmark=id.4thqlb3dusam 

There is a critical need to have a way of providing large-instances of various code hosts for internal testing purposes. These tools should be sourcegraph-wide services and all new features should be going through scale testing to ensure they work for all customers, especially strategic customers. 

See [Codehost Scale Testing](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1f9GcEpqJ5KA3YvfsOy48mdhILkvJZrqD9SfpZoNlQTg/edit#heading=h.1dosuqn3s1bf) for more. 

This is an essential pillar to reach strategic readiness. See [Toward a confidently Strategic-ready code intelligence platform (post-4.0) 2022-08](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qQTbEytX5VENOsoaMIaZV8lsFBEsa4n_XU5Aod-dGrw/edit) for more.

[Scratch Log](https://github.com/sourcegraph/devx-scratch/blob/main/2022/scaletesting/log.snb.md) 

## Problem

The context mentioned above is quite clear, but how to get there is very blurry. 

For example, there are no defined use cases yet. What each team wants to test at scale is purely based on previous observations, with varying confidence levels. What kind of data is relevant enough is totally unclear. What kind of synthetic data represents accurately enough a customer instance so we can be confident that testing against it will tell us that it'll work with the customer? 

â¡ï¸ So we're navigating uncharted waters, and we need to provide tooling to make this happen, as early as possible so each team can use their findings to reshape their roadmap toward strategic readiness. 

- Repo management & IAM
  - Have a L/XL instance to play with, connected to GitHub, Gitlab, BitBucket, Perforce (sorted by priority)
- CodeNav
  - Need to understand how scaling affects performances: have an instance you can scale up to whichever size you want and connect to any codehost
- Search Core
  - Find out how many concurrent searches we can support
  - What can 2,000 engineers do? What do they do to an instance?

See [Strategic customer support, state of the world ](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1n-KfGc8m1w09rIzNKm5tRxAYmP4-w11CVOCplMvVazk/edit#gid=1172385107) for L / XL definitions.

## Scope

At this stage, there is no need for any kind of automation because teams can simply take turns in using the scale testing environment. 

- We are to actively support teammates using the instance and document as we go. 
- We push for its use. If it's not being used, we seek to understand why.  
- We build tools that are useful to observe the instance if needed. 
- We are to pair with them to build tooling to feed data into the instances. 
- And we maintain the instance, of course.

### Boundaries

- Single instance only. Or if really needed, we manually duplicate it. 
- Limited automation for provisioning the instance: populate, snapshot and restore. 
- Non-goal: replicating customer traffic on the instance. 
- Non-goal: cost optimization; this is an investment, just don't overspend for no reason. 
- We maintain, but do not monitor the scale testing instance, that's up to the teams using the instance (but if you see something, tell them eh). 

### Definition of Done

- An engineer familiar with infrastructure and observability can operate and monitor the instance while conducting some tests. 
- At least two teams got data relevant to strategic readiness out of the scale testing instance. 
- Instance can be fed with synthetic data
- Users can be populated up to 10k < X < 20k 
  - Repositories up to 100k < X < 250k and with the largest one being 16 GB < X < 30 GB 
  - Code hosts: GitHub, GitLab at minimum. Perforce.
- We know what the limits of our scale testing instance are. How big can we go? 
- How much does this cost? 

### Payout

Each participating team has collected feedback on how their domain operates at scale and knows how to create meaningful data. We can reproduce hypothetical use cases that approximate our customer use case (repos count and size, users count). 

The best case scenario is that each team has uncovered potential blockers and has mapped out how to reproduce customers' scenarios. The worst-case scenario is they have simply uncovered bugs that would or have affected customers in the past. 

We'll have enough data (cost, usage, reliability) to accurately decide if we want to keep focusing on improving the testing capabilities and/or if we want to focus on automating the tooling itself. 

### Approach 

We previously implemented an MVP, see [Scale testing](https://handbook.sourcegraph.com/departments/engineering/dev/tools/scaletesting/) that is currently being tested by Eric Friz and Stephan Hengl. This is our starting point.

- Assist @efritz, @stefanhengl and @ryanslade in their usage of the scale testing instance. 
  - ğŸ”¥ This is the most important thing here. Nobody using the scale testing instance means having zero impact. 
- Being able to populate >10k+ users on CodeHost
  - In particular GitHub which is a problem @quinnhare and @jhchabran  are in touch with their support) 
- Creating synthetic data
  - What do we have so far? What do we need? How can we plug this in easily? 

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: michaellzc
TrackingIssues.Title: CI failure on `3.36` release branch
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Context

The Delivery team received a [patch request](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/30553) for `3.36` and `3.35`.

## The problem

[Buildkite builds on 3.36](https://buildkite.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/builds?branch=3.36). 

After only cherry-picking the [patch commit](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/commit/dbc5723990672d130981e1496103c0cea3a6acfd), many CI builds failed right away

- [GCR permission issue](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C01N83PS4TU/p1643824861428809?thread_ts=1643824826.104819&cid=C01N83PS4TU)
- [Weird python error](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C01N83PS4TU/p1643824925792549?thread_ts=1643824826.104819&cid=C01N83PS4TU)
- and more...

We were able to resolve most of them by guessing the right CI-related commits to cherry-pick into the `3.36` release branch, learn more from [3.36 branch commit history](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/commits/3.36)

In one of the latest CI build, all failure but `backcompact` tests are resolved. We couldn't make some sense out of the failing db backward compatibility tests https://buildkite.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/builds/128674

also, there seems to be a lot of backcompact test and migrate related code changes lately on `main` https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/commits/main/dev

What is the next step for the Release Captain? We are hoping the DevX team can provide some guidance.

TrackingIssues.Author: valerybugakov
TrackingIssues.Title: Improve client error tracking of the Sourcegraph application: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve
<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->
Today, we lack processes around client-side error monitoring, error reporting, and prioritizing and fixing runtime errors. Consequently, it can be difficult for Sourcegraph engineers to see, understand, and fix problems in the Sourcegraph application, which has a negative impact on engineering teams' effectiveness and, ultimately, on our customers. For the observability of on-prem instances, distributed traces, and other more advanced observability efforts, we'll follow the lead of the DevX team. 

## Measure of success
<!-- How will we validate/verify/know that we have solved the problem? -->
- [ ] We have a robust process for runtime error monitoring on the client, and it's documented in the handbook. 
- [ ] Relevant services and tools are configured to support the error monitoring process documented in the handbook. 
- [ ] An automated notification process lets the right people know there's an issue, and we have documentation that tells them how to address it. 

## Solution summary
<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artifacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

- [x] Evaluate the relative advantages and disadvantages of Sentry vs Datadog and determine the best path forward
- [ ] Improve Sentry configuration to make production error debugging easier. 
- [ ] Collaborate with the DevX team on proxying client events through our backend.
- [ ] Introduce guidelines on error handling in client applications. 

What we're not doing right now:
- Explore ways to allow on-prem clients to share logs with the Sourcegraph team to speed up debugging.
- Extend Open Telemetry traces into the frontend, so that client teams can easily collect a sequence of events to debug client issues
- Explore what `src debug` can do today in regard to traces, and see if it can be used to export client log events as well


Artifacts:
- [RFC 501 REVIEW: Runtime error monitoring](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1d18e_YFJsw5cgDId8Iz1MT8A_GsHZTOGHMuem1JMzuM/edit#)

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?
<!--
Reference customers by linking to their issue in our accounts repository. DON'T REFERENCE CUSTOMERS BY NAME!

Example:
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/537
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
-->

Internal Sourcegraph developers

## Impact on use cases

<!--
Describe how this roadmap item contributes to improving the customer experience for one or more of the 5 use cases and apply the relevant use-case/* labels to this issue.

For enablement projects that don't target a specific use case, describe how you expect this work to enable teams/projects that are focused on use cases.
-->

## Delivery plan
<!--
The overall plan for how we are going to achieve this roadmap item. This should be formulated as a checklist of concrete steps that are kept up-to-date so anyone can glance at the issue description to get a sense of what we have already delivered and what remains.

Each item on this list is ideally a concrete deliverable with an estimated delivery date and owner, but we don't want false precision, so just document the plan to the best of your ability, even if you don't have all the steps yet.
-->

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: GraphQL Client adoption: Settings pages
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
Weâ€™re looking to increase adoption of Apollo Client across settings components.

The aim of this issue is to identify and eventually improve areas that:
- Would benefit from serving cached data. High-traffic areas where data is unlikely to change whilst the user is on the page.
- Would benefit from refactoring data fetching logic into a shared API. Some examples may be complicated RxJS code that could be abstracted, or usage of FilteredConnection that has proven difficult to modify previously. 

### Useful resources
- Migrating from `requestGraphQL | queryGraphQL | mutateGraphQL` usage to [useMutation and useQuery](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/client/shared/src/graphql/graphql.ts?L127-157) hooks.
- Utilising the [Apollo cache](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/graphql#how-do-i-use-the-apollo-cache) by adding the correct `id` fields to queries or providing alternative [keyFields](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/caching/cache-configuration/#customizing-identifier-generation-by-type) to use.
- Migrating from `FilteredConnection` to `useConnection` and abstract FilteredConnection UI components: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/commit/037dc8022ae8e0368e07131856c684715b731a1e

Please use this issue to discuss and identify these areas. Will create follow-on tickets to track implementation.

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: DevInfra: Migrate go:generate directives to Bazel Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: team/dev-infra -->

Using `go:generate` directives doesn't play well with Bazel because the outputs are not deterministic and there is no way they can be integrated that way directly. 

We could argue that we're fine with that and that we'll keep running `sg generate go` and rely on the linter to catch cases where we didn't update the generated files. But it comes with a price: 

- it's moderately slow, it takes about 32s on my machine to complete. 
- it's can be surprising: we're generating src-cli ref docs with the latest released version, but we're using a pinned version when shipping it in the container images.
- it's also fragile, the above example makes a network call; if GitHub is down, it fails. 

So the best approach here is to extract the `go:generate` statement into Bazel. We get the following benefits: 

- it's fast most of the time, because it's cached. 
- it's deterministic, because bazel. 
- it's one step closer to not having to run `sg lint go` in CI.

While it might look complicated on the first look, such statements are merely about calling a shell command. So to bazelify them, we can turn them into a `genrule` and deal with the outputs so they're now deterministic. 

### Plan

- Go through them one by one
- Turn it into a `genrule` 
- If it's a repeated use case, write a macro 
- If files are written back to the source tree,

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: PD 503 sub-repository permissions tracking: complete implementation
TrackingIssues.Body:
This is a tracking issue for the **complete implementation of [PD 503: Sub-repository permissions model](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1d8j-6VC_nk8HXEDT6U2_s-_9uSzgzHWZzrJjII9pKEE/edit#)**, formerly RFC 503. This follows our work on [developing a proof-of-concept (milestone 139)](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/milestone/139?closed=1), and it primarily covered spikes on an implementation path and work that has carried forward on syncing permissions from Perforce (https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/26644) and the sub-repo perms smart client (https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/26645).

See the [November 15 update](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1d8j-6VC_nk8HXEDT6U2_s-_9uSzgzHWZzrJjII9pKEE/edit#bookmark=id.6brtu8eazde1) for more details on the outcome of the proof-of-concept, and the [complete implementation roadmap](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1d8j-6VC_nk8HXEDT6U2_s-_9uSzgzHWZzrJjII9pKEE/edit#bookmark=kix.xoo5gukib3q7) for an overview and discussion of the path forward.

### Background

Some code hosts support permissions being set against more granular items than repositories, which is currently all Sourcegraph supports. The high level aim of this project is to add support for permissions at a more granular level than repo.

See [PD 503](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1d8j-6VC_nk8HXEDT6U2_s-_9uSzgzHWZzrJjII9pKEE/edit) for a complete overview.

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: chwarwick
TrackingIssues.Title: insights: Backfiller Improvements (backfill by series) Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
The original backfill process for code insights backfills all insight series runs in two steps the first step determines all the queries that need to be run for any series that needs to be backfilled and puts them in to a queue.  The 2nd step runs the queries and records the results. There are several challenges with this approach:

- Determining all the queries can be a long process and if it fails it needs to restart completely 
- The worker that runs the backfill queries processes all series in parallel which delays the time until any series is complete
- It is difficult to determine the current status of a backfill and how much work it has remaining


To solve these issues we will make a new backfilling mechanism that backfills a series at a time and breaks the work into repo sized chunks.  When backfilling it will plan, execute and record the data for 1 repo at a time. This will allow for smaller units of work that require retries if an error occurs and will enable a more accurate progress/status.  

Backfilling a series at a time means that insights over a smaller set of repos could be delayed behind insights over a larger set of repos.  To address this the backfill process will be made interruptible, so that if any work with a higher priority is created it can be processed before continuing on with lower priority work.

TrackingIssues.Author: thenamankumar
TrackingIssues.Title: Permissions Center: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
[PR-FAQ](https://github.com/sourcegraph/pr-faqs/issues/23) | [Slack](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C04J31SQQNN) | [Figma mockups](https://www.figma.com/file/wmP7mAQds8DsrqQMuU2VSq/Permission-Center?node-id=78%3A2179&t=wuGZI0Uxv7sJBWT4-0)

### Plan
Currently, site admins need more visibility around who has access to what part of the code and why. Admins can not monitor the permissions syncing model, which runs in the background and struggle with debugging permissions issues for their users. 

With the Permissions Center MVP project, we aim to resolve all these pain points for our customers and make the system more â€œinspectable, debuggable, predictable" by having:
- Database-backed permissions syncing
- Permissions Sync Dashboard to monitor permission sync jobs
- Permissions Info Dashboard to view who has access to which repositories

*The [SCIM Project](https://github.com/sourcegraph/pr-faqs/issues/66), under the Permissions Center umbrella, works separately on adding new automation capabilities to our users management system and making it more intelligent.*

[DB backed perms syncing queue migration plan](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/46078).
