TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking: release rough edges
TrackingIssues.Body:
Mini-tracking issue for some rough edges encountered by @pecigonzalo , most notably during the recent 3.22 release (#15023). Adapted from a Google doc he wrote up. We should split some of these into separate issues if they amount to a lot of work.

Check list indicates if an issue was created to track work, or if the problem itself was resolved directly

## Release tool

* [ ]  If you dont enter a version on `upcoming version` (_prompt_) it crashes, and you cant recover, you have to `git clean -fxd` => bug in confirmation prompt that ensures captains are aware of the configured version => fixed in https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/16689
* [x] Secrets configuration could be from something more universal (`.env`? `.envrc`?) => opened issue https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/16645
* [x] Would be nice to have a more "CLI-like" experience => fixed in https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/16519
* [x] Terrible things happen if release tool is interrupted (e.g. error on a repo) => opened issue https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/16549
* [x] Errors leave release in bad state => https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/16549

## Continuous integration

* [x] env vars in CI env are not good because they are displayed directly in the console and stored at Buildkite. => opened issue https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/16647

## Incorrect documentation

* [x] `git branch 3.22` incorrect => fixed in https://github.com/sourcegraph/about/pull/2128
* [x] ~"Upon branch cut, create and test the first release candidate:" should indicate to checkout 3.22~ this step is not required, candidates are cut from branches by the release tool
* [x] `yarn run release release-candidate:create final` should be `yarn run release release:create-candidate final` => fixed by https://github.com/sourcegraph/about/pull/2128
* [ ] Many steps on https://github.com/sourcegraph/deploy-sourcegraph-docker/blob/master/RELEASING.md are already done by buildkite, should note and/or remove => fixed in https://github.com/sourcegraph/deploy-sourcegraph-docker/pull/192
* [x] Testing instructions => covered by #15750 , instead of fixing this I believe we should just remove these steps
   * Regression tests docs point to wrong directory, should be `client/web`, tools missing
* [x] Releasing pure-docker are incorrect => opened issue https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/16646

### Tracked issues

<!-- BEGIN WORK -->
<!-- BEGIN ASSIGNEE: bobheadxi -->
@bobheadxi: __0.50d__

- [ ] release: continue on errors ([#16549](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/16549)) __0.50d__

Completed
- [x] (ğŸ 1 day ago) release: remove manual regression testing from release process ([~#15750~](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/15750))
<!-- END ASSIGNEE -->
<!-- END WORK -->

TrackingIssues.Author: taylorsperry
TrackingIssues.Title: Improve consistency in Sourcegraph's frontend codebase
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve
<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->
Quarterly [DevX surveys](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1YlQRsnwGz77sI3m9Lekff9q56GtaFWqfuR7Wuh-4ex4/edit#slide=id.ge8aecb9a14_0_45) regularly identify "codebase inconsistency" as a main contributor to poor developer experience at Sourcegraph. It makes it difficult for teams to iterate quickly, complicates the debugging process, and bloats CI/CD time. 

A more consistent client codebase will: 
- Reduce mental overhead for engineers by standardizing file structure, naming conventions, patterns, and conventions
- Make it easier to find, implement, and update reusable components 
- Enable us to automate wide-ranging changes and migrate technologies quickly
- Empower teammates to work outside their domain area (and jump into new ones)
- Improve onboarding so that new teammates can have an impact faster

## Measure of success
<!-- How will we validate/verify/know that we have solved the problem? -->
- There's one answer to every question: Codebase conventions are documented in the handbook, as is the long-term vision for our tech stack, tooling, and libraries.
- All major ongoing migrations are complete.
- We see fewer comments about codebase complexity in the quarterly DevX surveys.  

## Solution summary
<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artifacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

- Define React component file structure, naming conventions, and organization for reusable modules.
- Track and complete ongoing migrations, improve tooling for future migrations, and identify next priority migrations
- Set up linters and component generators that enforce consistency

Artifacts:
- [RFC 641: Consistent frontend platform](https://docs.google.com/document/d/19ZIlY_7ZYtbFRfL1OrLvYh2AlLTQuuBRvN-NzOub59c/edit#heading=h.qmb0cmhf6z2i)
- [RFC 555: Convergence -- project structure and naming](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lIVS7ABFTV8i6Mq89Mz3oCeQxf5qHOgvr9oUnd-Xp9M/edit#)
- [RFC 674: HSL color migration](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/35499)

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?
<!--
Reference customers by linking to their issue in our accounts repository. DON'T REFERENCE CUSTOMERS BY NAME!

Example:
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/537
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
-->

Internal Sourcegraph developers

## Impact on use cases

<!--
Describe how this roadmap item contributes to improving the customer experience for one or more of the 5 use cases and apply the relevant use-case/* labels to this issue.

For enablement projects that don't target a specific use case, describe how you expect this work to enable teams/projects that are focused on use cases.
-->

## Delivery plan
<!--
The overall plan for how we are going to achieve this roadmap item. This should be formulated as a checklist of concrete steps that are kept up-to-date so anyone can glace at the issue description to get a sense of what we have already delivered and what remains.

Each item on this list is ideally a concrete deliverable with an estimated delivery date and owner, but we don't want false precision, so just document the plan to the best of your ability, even if you don't have all the steps yet.
-->

- TODO

TrackingIssues.Author: nicksnyder
TrackingIssues.Title: Search 3.20 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

<!--
Summarize what the team wants to achieve this iteration.
- What are the problems we want to solve or what information do we want to gather?
- Why is solving those problems or gathering that information important?
- How do we plan to solve those problems or gather that information?
-->

@keegancsmith will be working on an initial implementation of streaming search. This is a backend change which gives us more flexibility. Immediately it will improve time to first result for slower searches other issues we have with timeouts. In general it will improve the user (and machine) experience around searches which are not interactive (unindexed, diff/commit, etc).

@rvantonder is taking some time off this iteration and will be doing less. He'll (1) ship [search expressions](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/13126) and (2) enable the new query parser for 3.20 onwards. These will build a foundation for expressing new queries and enable future extensions for long-awaited features to pipe, filter, and customize powerful searches for understanding code.

@stefanhengl will wrap-up his work around `@` and `rev:` and then move on to adding support for negation to searcher and, if time allows, introduce the concept of .sourcegraphignore to our search engines.

@limitedmage and @attfarhan will finalize planning for the Enterprise Home feature and file necessary issues related to this, then start working on implementation.

### Availability

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

@rvantonder proposed time off: 31 August to 9 September (8 days off)
@limitedmage holiday: 7 September (Labor Day)

TrackingIssues.Author: pjlast
TrackingIssues.Title: Gerrit Permission Syncing tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Gerrit background
We have two options to interface with Gerrit: an `experimentalFeature` and a Generic Git code host.

Gerrit has some thorough access management capabilities, and users can interact with Gerrit in 3 ways:
1. Web interface
2. Over SSH
3. Using an HTTP Rest API

We can't leverage the Web interface. We could _possibly_ leverage SSH, but I don't think we quite have the necessary groundwork to have users upload SSH keys and interact with Gerrit like that. So that leaves the HTTP Rest API.

Authentication on the HTTP Rest API uses basic HTTP Auth. This means the user will have to provide us with a username and password. We'll have to be clear on this, and we should double check with customers asking for this if this is okay.

If a user's HTTP password gets reset, which is very easy to do, it's a single button click in the HTTP interface with no warning, they will have to reprovide that password on Sourcegraph.

## Tech decisions

Apart from the above decision, there is also another decision we need to make.
How do we handle the "Auth provider" part of Gerrit?

Auth providers used for permissions syncing need to be linked back to their respective code host. This is generally done through a URL and the code host type. We can do something like this with the Gerrit experimental feautre. But it would maybe be a tiny bit trickier with the generic git code host.

## Tasks

Permissions syncing

- [x] #46773
  - Use the Gerrit HTTP API to fetch repositories a user can access
  - There is no repo-based permissions syncing
    - The Gerrit HTTP API cannot provide a list of users that can access a repository, we would have to traverse groups and subgroups and try to infer permissions from rules, which is very error-prone

User account

- [x] #46622
  - Should not be presented as a sign-in option
  - Users should be able to provide a username and password pair, which would correspond with their Gerrit HTTP credentials

/cc @sourcegraph/source

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Code intelligence: 3.18 tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

Our Q2 OKR is to increase the number of WAU of LSIF code intelligence actions.

Here are the problems that we want to solve this iteration:

1. Users aren't configuring repositories to upload LSIF data.

    1. LSIF is a non-trivial amount of technical work to setup, which is a barrier to adoption.

        **SOLUTION: Expand the number of languages and cases where we can automatically index repositories with LSIF. Use data from sourcegraph.com to determine which repositories are the source of the most search based code intel queries.**

    1. Even though the technical work to setup LSIF is straightforward, we have observed that engineers who are motivated to do this work get blocked due to how their organization functions (e.g., adding stuff to CI is hard and/or requires approvals).

        **SOLUTION: Make it possible to configure LSIF auto-indexing within Sourcegraph without needing to make a change to your company's CI system for common cases.**

1. We have multiple customers who want precise C++ code intel and current DXP approach is not sufficient.

    **SOLUTION: Ship MVP of new clangd indexer to [C1](https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/company/2931649618/), [C2](https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/company/947819054/)**

1. Users don't understand that there are two kinds of code intelligence. When they encounter issues with imprecise code intel, they don't know how to enable precise code intel. When precise code intel is configured, but is unavailable for multiple possible reasons, it is not clear to the user why they are seeing imprecise code intel.

    **SOLUTION: Improve hover tooltips to include more information on the state/source of code intel.**

1. [C1](https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/company/464956351/) and [C2](https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/company/554275594/) are blocked from adopting LSIF because they have large repositories with high commit rates.

    **SOLUTION: Design incremental indexing (start validating assumptions next month). Design scalable find-nearest queries (stretch begin implementing this month)**

### Availability

Period is from **2020-06-20** to **2020-07-20**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- Eric: 21d
- Garo: 12d

TrackingIssues.Author: pecigonzalo
TrackingIssues.Title: Distribution: 2020.11.16 - Elegant Sardine
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

#### [Support new and existing deployments](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/74)

This is an ongoing expense, we anticipate this taking no more than 5d of work spread across the entire team.

#### [Releases are created in a single day](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/90)

We have include E2E, QA and multiple other manual tests in our automated tests pipelines, but we have found several tests need to be updated or fixed. We will be working with all teams to fix the tests and get a stable pipeline.

- @davejrt 
- @daxmc99 

#### [Market k8s.sgdev.org internally](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/107)

Make k8s.sgdev.org a compelling destination for Sourcegraph engineers to encourage dogfood. Changes should mostly be surface-level improvements.

- @bobheadxi 
- @pecigonzalo 


#### [Implement 2+ sourcegraph.com services using dhall](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/71)

`sourcegraph.com` sees the highest amount of Kubernetes changes out of all of our deployments + `deploy-sourcegraph`. Scoping a single component limits the customizations that we need to implement and allows for easier onboarding other engineers.

- @ggilmore 
- @uwedeportivo
- @daxmc99 

### Availability

Period is from **November 16rd** to **November 30th (10 working days)**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: DevInfra: CI usability and speed Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

  - `sg skeleton buildkite`
    - default pipeline that offers you all the plugins available at the moment
  - Do not depend on `sg lint` (use underlying commands instead) 
  - No more `go:generate` 
  - Enable merge-queues (GitHub based)
    - when: Once ESBuild work is complete + aspect.dev workflows
  - IFF aspect.dev workflows do not provide a remote cache solution we can reuse 
    - Use GCP Cloud Storage to host the files
    - Scale horizontally bazel's remote cache 
  - Setup caching on Github Actions for Cody
  - Record a loom video for introducing Bazel and the mental model
  - Record a loom video for introducing Bazel and Go
  - When a bazel target fails to build, the logs should be uploaded (right now, it's only if test fails) 
    - IFF not handled by aspect.workflows
  - Post build failures logs in an annotation 
    - IFF not handled by aspect.workflows
  - Name the uploaded logs as per the target that failed and not a random number 
    - IFF not handled by aspect.workflows
  - DM teammates when their build fail (not just main, all of them) 
  - Display the owner of a given test when a test fails

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking Issue: WCAG 2.1 AA Accessibility - Auditing user journeys
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve
<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->

This tracking issue reflects the **Auditing** stage of the accessibility work that began in Q1. Today, the Sourcegraph web application does not comply with current WCAG guidelines. Our ultimate goal and measure of success is to reach (and maintain) compliance by the end of FY23 (January 2023).

## Measure of success
<!-- How will we validate/verify/know that we have solved the problem? -->
Each team's user journeys have been audited per the guidance in the artifacts below. 

## Solution summary
<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artifacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

- Accessibility champions begin auditing user journeys within their product areas. They use [this issue template](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/new?assignees=&labels=accessibility%2Cwcag%2F2.1%2Cwcag%2F2.1%2Ffixing%2Cestimate%2F3d&template=accessibility_issue.yaml&title=%5BAccessibility%5D%3A+) (found in [How to conduct an accessibility audit](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/accessibility)) to raise issues that need to be addressed. 
- Frontend Platform Team improves automated scanning by adding new routes and journeys that can be scanned by TPGi. 
- Frontend Platform Team monitors automated scans for any regressions and raises issues accordingly. 

Artifacts:
- #31200 
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/31476

**Step 2: Self auditing (May, June)**

- [ ] Cloud SaaS - June 1

TrackingIssues.Author: chrispine
TrackingIssues.Title: Campaigns Sprint 2 Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

The main theme of this sprint is a continuation from our last sprint: quality of life improvements for our users. We need to make campaigns easier to use in everyday situations in order to get more people using campaigns. This includes easier debugging, better docs, and bug fixing.

We also have a couple of larger items: allowing users to use their own code host tokens, and enabling campaigns to create draft PRs.

### Availability

Period is from Oct 7 to Oct 20, for 10 working days in total.

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

@chrispine 0d
@mrnugget 0d
@eseliger 0d
@LawnGnome 1d (:canada: Thanksgiving October 12)

### Tracked issues

<!-- BEGIN ASSIGNEE:  -->

TrackingIssues.Author: mrnugget
TrackingIssues.Title: Campaigns: 3.18 Tracking Issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

The main goals for this iteration are: 

- Add support for Gitlab to campaigns (Adam)
- Implement the campaigns workflow as documented in #10921 (Erik, Thorsten)

Both tie back to our OKR-based overarching goal to release campaigns as a non-feature-flagged, non-beta feature and get N customers using it to create campaigns.

Implementing Gitlab support is the result of multiple customers asking for it. Implementing the new workflow is the result of usertesting with Sourcegraph colleagues.

The first one should increase the number of customers trying out campaigns, the second one should make it easier for all customers to get started with campaigns and actually _create_ campaigns.

### Availability

Period is from **June 22nd** to **July 17th** (20 days). Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- @mrnugget: 17d (Not working 6-8th July )
- @eseliger: 20d
- @LawnGnome: 19d (Canada Day 1st July)

### Workload

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue: Remove the precise code intel bundle manager
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

The precise-code-intelligence-bundle-manager is no longer a necessary core service after we've migrated data from SQLite to Postgres. Removing this service will simplify a lot of ops concerns from the code intel team (data retention, space clearing, monitoring, alerts, provisioning, etc). In broad strokes, our plan is to:

- Read/write from/to S3, GCS, or minio for upload data (falling back to the bundle manager)
- Remove fallbacks from the bundle manager client so that the service receives no ingress traffic
- Remove the bundle manager from all deployments. This requires that:
  - Ensure all bundle data has been migrated from the bundle manager persistent volume to Postgres
  - Ensure all upload data has been migrated to a volume which is managed independently (S3, GCS, or minio)

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: malomarrec
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking: Improve and extend comby
TrackingIssues.Body:
This is a tracking issue for improving and extending comby.

#### Background / problem

Comby is a powerful code rewrite tool, but it doesn't get used much by users based on anecdotal evidence (datapoint needed).
There are a few potential issues to dig into and validate:
- comby might be missing some capabilities (I can't change pattern x with comby)
- it's hard for users to write comby predicates for their use case
- it's har for users to get discover and get started with comby

Recently, @beyang and I were playing with comby and trying to identify the limitations. The findings are tracked here or in related issues.

<!-- BEGIN WORK -->
<!-- END WORK -->

End of tracking

TrackingIssues.Author: efritz
TrackingIssues.Title: Code intelligence: 3.17 tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Status

**Milestone Focus**: We are trying to increase adoption of precise code intelligence by implementing an auto-indexing strategy, improving the UI related to codeintel, and increasing performance of queries and index conversion, and expanding indexer support. We are improving stability of the precise code intel backend and ensuring it does not regress by implementing a set of integration tests. We are also expanding the code intel API surface with diagnostics, which is a critical part of code insights.

### Availability

Period is from **2020-05-20** to **2020-06-20**. Please write the days you won't be working and the number of working days for the period.

- Eric: 21d (off memorial day 5/25)
- Garo: 14d

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: All Sourcegraph components can export standardized sets of metrics
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve
<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->

Today, our services do not export uniform metrics. With various implementations and custom metrics, this makes it difficult to interpret what a user is actually experiencing when the metrics are being viewed by an individual, or take any meaningful action if it isn't clear what the metric represents. It's also been [noted](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C02VDNKBWDU/p1651063380116879?thread_ts=1651043351.515279&cid=C02VDNKBWDU) that custom metrics can be very expensive, which we'd like to avoid. 

In order to accurately display what users are experiencing when using Sourcegraph and provide a way to determine service issues more easily, we should export metrics using the [RED method](https://www.infoworld.com/article/3638693/the-red-method-a-new-strategy-for-monitoring-microservices.html#jump). 

## Measure of success
<!-- How will we validate/verify/know that we have solved the problem? -->

- Services adhere to and export a standardized set of Rate, Error and Duration based metrics, which are consumable via more meaningful dashboards. 
- The handbook documents this implementation and how to use it effectively
- Migration to use the new metrics is in progress for any service not currently using it. 

## Solution summary
<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artefacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

We will propose a migration of any services not currently using the [RED metrics package](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/internal/metrics/operation.go?subtree=true) to provide better information for our users. 

Artefacts:
- Current [RED metrics implementation](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/internal/metrics/operation.go?subtree=true)

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?
<!--
Reference customers by linking to their issue in our accounts repository. DON'T REFERENCE CUSTOMERS BY NAME!

Example:
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/537
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
-->

Internal Sourcegraph developers, and those teams who consume these metrics most often (Customer Engineering, Delivery, Cloud DevOps). 

## Impact on use cases

<!--
Describe how this roadmap item contributes to improving the customer experience for one or more of the 5 use cases and apply the relevant use-case/* labels to this issue.

For enablement projects that don't target a specific use case, describe how you expect this work to enable teams/projects that are focused on use cases.
-->

This effort contributes to the company-wide effort to improve Observability.


## Delivery plan
<!--
The overall plan for how we are going to achieve this roadmap item. This should be formulated as a checklist of concrete steps that are kept up-to-date so anyone can glance at the issue description to get a sense of what we have already delivered and what remains.

Each item on this list is ideally a concrete deliverable with an estimated delivery date and owner, but we don't want false precision, so just document the plan to the best of your ability, even if you don't have all the steps yet.
-->

- [ ] Investigate existing proposals, issues, and problem space
- [ ] Prepare a draft docs page with standardized proposal
- [ ] Partner with team to implement and refine the implementation approach
- [ ] Start performing migration of services to new metrics

### Tracked issues

<!-- OPTIONAL LABEL: roadmap -->

TrackingIssues.Author: Piszmog
TrackingIssues.Title: Pool Manager (Push Model)
TrackingIssues.Body:
Today, executors pull jobs from Sourcegraph and handle the jobs within their instance. Once #46175 is complete, we can create a "Pool Manager" to process jobs in a push-even model. This means that Sourcegraph can push jobs to executor instances and within the instance can spawn runtimes to handle the jobs.

To achieve this, executors will have **job handling** and **runtimes** split. Job handling will live in Sourcegraph, pushing out jobs to executors. Runtimes will be spun up within the executor instances to actually process the jobs. Executors will manage the pools of runtimes within the instances.

## Done

* Implement a "Pool Manager" within Executors
    * Accept Jobs via API
    * Spin up and process outputs of runtimes
    * Send lifecycle information back to Job Handler
* Implement a "job handler" within Sourcegraph
    * Process queued jobs and send to "Pool Manager"
    * Accept lifecycle events from "Pool Manager"

## Technical Considerations

* Backwards compatibility
     * Is this something new and do not need to worry about back compat?
*  When pushing jobs, determine which executor should get a job
* How should APIs for cloning repos, log streaming, artifact uploads, job completion work?

## Reference Docs

* [Executor vision](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1kwf2UISqzho8RQGyb0Pht8SKL-iESUoFHcm_sJqIa94/edit#heading=h.piwjg45rimes)

## Tasks

- [ ] #50743
- [ ] #49917 
- [ ] #50643
- [ ] #46179

TrackingIssues.Author: eseliger
TrackingIssues.Title: Private batch changes (needs RBAC)
TrackingIssues.Body:
##### Current situation and problem

The current (simplistic) permission model of Batch Changes and long-term improvements is described in #29048.
The first problem we want to tackle is allowing a batch change to be private to a user (that is, only this use has read, write/run and admin access).

That's been validated for several use cases:
- Strategic customers don't want Batch Changes to be shared with everybody on the instance. They ideally need Batch Changes to support being private, team, or org-wide batch changes.
- In security use cases, batch changes need to be private while they're being worked on, before being published.

#### Solution

- At create time, users can make batch changes in their namespace private.
- In that case, the creator is the only one to have access.
- At any point in the life of the batch change, they can set the visibility to public. That means (see #29048) that all instance users can `read`, and all instance admins can `read` and `admin`.
- To make the batch change runnable by someone else, they can transfer it to the organisation namespace)
- Note: the UI needs to offer clear explanations for this model.

#### Delivery plan

- [ ] Validate this first step with the IAM team, and make sure it's forward compatible with [RFC 617: Unifying permissions](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1B3A-PQTykOSnp6BtHZTbIFpSRrvbiV-0FrnukJeaM3A/edit)
- [ ] x

TrackingIssues.Author: valerybugakov
TrackingIssues.Title: Address the unstable CSS order in the web application production bundle: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve

The CSS rules order in the production environment is different from what we have in the development env. We can choose only one thing with the current build configuration:
1. Consistent CSS rules order in production.
2. Tree shaking powered by `sideEffects: false`.

[See this comment](https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/7094#issuecomment-945663737) on the unresolved issue:
> In addition to that, `mini-css-plugin` makes no strong guarantee about the order of independent CSS files. It tries its best to keep the importing order, but there are some cases where this is not followed, e. g. because modules are split into multiple css bundles.
I would recommend to not rely on CSS order between multiple files in general.

See [the Slack thread](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C03JMRKLJHZ/p1663661972699879) and [the initial issue](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/41736) that triggered this investigation. 

## Measure of success

- [ ] We have a consistent order of CSS rules in the production and development of web application bundles.
- [ ] We use the production bundle for visual regression testing to ensure such issues are captured early.
- [ ] The CSS tree-shaking works without changes.

## Solution Summary

- [ ] Restructure exports in packages with CSS modules to enable tree-shaking without relying on the `sideEffects` property.
    - [ ] #42218
    - [ ] #42219
- [ ] #42220
- [x] #22831
- [ ] #42221
- [ ] #42222

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?

Internal Sourcegraph developers

TrackingIssues.Author: adeola-ak
TrackingIssues.Title: GitHub credential alternatives (Tracking)
TrackingIssues.Body:
A customer reported a batch changes blocker ([slack)](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C0W2E592M/p1678316168364169) that stems from their use of SSH certificate authentication with github.

**Summary:** 
- engineers dont generate and upload ssh keys
- they use a service that generates and signs keys which is trusted by their org instead of the uploaded key material
- as a result if a user tries to clone a repo with a classic PAT they get `$ git clone https://x-access-token/:$CLASSIC_PAT@github.com/.../REPO.git
remote: This repository requires SSH certificate authentication. Contact the owner to receive a certificate.` `
- if a user tries to publish a changeset using a PAT added to settings, they get `$ git -c credential.helper= -c protocol.version=2 push --force https://<redacted>@github.com/squareup/appseceng-test-cash-toolbox 648f69cef393a917f157570638dacaa0a096b5ef:refs/heads/lsc/20230303-owner-owl-cleanup
remote: This repository requires SSH certificate authentication. Contact the owner to receive a certificate.
fatal: unable to access 'https://github.com/.../.../': The requested URL returned error: 403`

**Customers attempt to clone repos over HTTP instead of ssh:**
Fine-grained PATv2: The Code host tokens UI rejects a PATv2 value (although the site-wide Code hosts UI accepted one) with this error:request to http://github-proxy/graphql returned status 401: Personal access tokens with fine grained access do not support the GraphQL API

[IAT](https://docs.github.com/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authenticating-with-a-github-app/generating-an-installation-access-token-for-a-github-app): max shelf life of 1 hour only

**Questions:**
1. Test connection" feature doesn't use the graphql endpoint to test the connection. Meanwhile, the command that's failing â€” git push â€” would work just fine with a PATv2. Is the personal Code host tokens UI too narrowly constrained? Could a PATv2 work for the ability to manipulate changesets?
2. Scope for adding to job fair?

**More context:** [slack](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C03P5NYGF2T/p1678127205995309), [github SSH certificate blog ](https://github.blog/2019-08-14-ssh-certificate-authentication-for-github-enterprise-cloud/), [a separate slack](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C04M9JE73E1/p1678215813849369)

Some further team discussion pointed out the need to have a GitHub enterprise Cloud testing org and someone to set this up for us 

### Tracked issues

<!-- BEGIN WORK -->
<!-- END WORK -->

TrackingIssues.Author: bobheadxi
TrackingIssues.Title: DevX proposal: release tool rewrite tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
The release tool currently exists as a standalone Typescript tool developed in `dev/release`. The DevX team proposes that this tool be rewritten in Go as part of `sg`, which will bring numerous benefits:

- integration with `sg` features like automated documentation, secrets management, and more, which are currently adhoc-implemented within the release tool
- help `sg` align with a core competency of most of engineering at Sourcegraph, Go, which all our core developer tools are built in (`sg` itself, pipeline generator, and more)

Such a rewrite can also be an opportunity to redesign and rebuild core parts of the release tool and process, such as offloading changeset generation into serverside batch changes and other potential improvements outlined here: https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/240/views/2

TrackingIssues.Author: mrnugget
TrackingIssues.Title: Source tracking issue: Licensing
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Work

Define and implement license expiration behavior, Ensure success of telemetry-export project

### Milestones/Tasks

#### License expiration
**Goal**: When a license expires the system should continue functioning, but users should be signed out and only one admin should be able to sign in
- [ ] Sourcegraph features shouldn't get disabled when a license expires. Sourcegraph should continue functioning
  - Looking for references of [this function](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/internal/license/license.go?L51) is a good start
- [ ] Sign out all user sessions when a license is expired
  - License expiration isn't quite a trigger we can react to, so the check should probably happen on user session validation, with the session being deleted if the license is expired
- [ ] Prevent user sign-in when a license is expired
  - Similar to above, the sign-out and prevent-sign-in checks will probably be in the same place and happen together
- [ ] Only allow one active admin session at a time
  - It should be enough to handle this on sign-in. Check if the user is an admin, if so, remove all other user sessions
- [ ] Clearly document license expiration behaviour, as well as the events leading up to license expiration
- [ ] Communicate upcoming changes with technical support and make sure that everyone knows where to find answers

#### Telemetry-export project
- [ ] Review duplicate site-ID + license key behaviour
  - Action items here might be a tiny bit unclear. Do we think the existing system is reliable? Can we make it more robust?
- [ ] Routinely check if we're receiving duplicate pings for the same license key
- [ ] Establish clear communication channels when duplicate license keys are detected

#### Open questions
- What happens to user access tokens? Can we prevent their use while a license is expired? Would it have any unintended consequences?

/cc @sourcegraph/source

TrackingIssues.Author: stefanhengl
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue: sg maintenance
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
Gitserver periodically runs various cleanup jobs on the repositories. One of
those jobs is "sg maintenance". 

The goal of "sg maintenance" is to optimize repositories mainly  by repacking
and pruning. It is on per default and replaces the legacy "git gc" job. 

Recently we have seen OOMs on smaller Soucegraph instances. The OOMs
directly trace back to "sg maintenance". Logs shows that "sg maintenance"
exits with code 137.  

At the same time, we have seen an increase in I/O since we switched from "git gc"
to "sg maintenance".

This issue tracks the progress we are making towards resolving the issue and improving "sg maintenance".

### Tracked issues / PRs

- #32841
- #33079 
- #33217 
- #33259 
- #33281 
- #33304 
- #33432
- #35939

TrackingIssues.Author: taylorsperry
TrackingIssues.Title: All Sourcegraph components can export uniform, structured logs
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve
<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->

Today, `log15` is used throughout the Sourcegraph codebase for logging. It is mostly sufficient, but has some issues:

- Strange conventions: log levels are `dbug`, `eror`, etc. which is a common source of confusion, and causes interop issues with external tools
- Unmaintained: [most of `log15`'s commit activity is from over 5 years ago](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/inconshreveable/log15@master/-/commits), and the repository has a number of abandoned open PRs. We are unlikely to run into `log4j`-style security risk, but this is still a potential risk.
- Performance: logging libraries like https://github.com/uber-go/zap are ~1000% to ~5000% faster than `log15` ([reference](https://github.com/uber-go/zap#performance)) - at Sourcegraph's logging volume this is a likely a non-negligible difference

We also have issues such as extensive use of global logging, which does not include any structured metadata, and extensive use of unstructured logs in general. This leads to a low signal to noise ratio, and a lack of ability to filter logs in a useful manner.

We can take this opportunity to improve tie-in with [OpenTracing standards](https://opentelemetry.io/docs/reference/specification/logs/data-model/#trace-context-fields), and improve our sensitive data redaction in logging.

## Measure of success
<!-- How will we validate/verify/know that we have solved the problem? -->

- A standardized logging package is introduced that exports a logger with standardized fields (~[`lib/log`](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/tree/lib/log)~ now https://github.com/sourcegraph/log)
- A document is created that describes logging best practices: ["How to add and use logging"](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/how-to/add_and_use_logging)
- Migration is in progress for all Sourcegraph services to switch to the new logging package ([dashboard](https://k8s.sgdev.org/sign-in?returnTo=%2Finsights%2Fdashboards%2FZGFzaGJvYXJkOnsiSWRUeXBlIjoiY3VzdG9tIiwiQXJnIjo3MjcyNTN9))

## Solution summary
<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artifacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

We will propose a complete migration to [zap](https://github.com/uber-go/zap) (which would work for Cloud as well as on-prem) and encourage use of passing loggers instances around to enable better structured logging by attaching metadata to logger instances and log entries that can be propagated. Part of this will likely include banning the use of other printing/logging packages other than the chosen logging library.

Artifacts:
- Brainstorming and feedback discussion: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/discussions/33248

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?
<!--
Reference customers by linking to their issue in our accounts repository. DON'T REFERENCE CUSTOMERS BY NAME!

Example:
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/565
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/537
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
-->

Internal Sourcegraph developers.

## Impact on use cases

<!--
Describe how this roadmap item contributes to improving the customer experience for one or more of the 5 use cases and apply the relevant use-case/* labels to this issue.

For enablement projects that don't target a specific use case, describe how you expect this work to enable teams/projects that are focused on use cases.
-->

This effort contributes to the company-wide effort to improve Observability. 

## Delivery plan
<!--
The overall plan for how we are going to achieve this roadmap item. This should be formulated as a checklist of concrete steps that are kept up-to-date so anyone can glace at the issue description to get a sense of what we have already delivered and what remains.

Each item on this list is ideally a concrete deliverable with an estimated delivery date and owner, but we don't want false precision, so just document the plan to the best of your ability, even if you don't have all the steps yet.
-->

- [x] Investigate existing proposals, issues, and problem space [details](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/discussions/33248)
- [x] MVP implementation and proposal is prepared [details](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/33953)
- [x] Initial rounds of implementation and migration are handled by DevX
- [x] Roll out JSON logs in Cloud: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/34599 and ensure the format works ([update](https://sourcegraph.slack.com/archives/C033PDEV740/p1651597329911709?thread_ts=1651514676.645109&cid=C033PDEV740))
- [x] Set up tooling to avoid migration regressions and communicate new recommendations to #dev-backend
- [x] Allocate some migrations to GitStart and ramp them up to perform migrations effectively
- [x] Support teams in performing their own migrations, and address feedback/documentation issues continuously

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: eseliger
TrackingIssues.Title: Ingesting CODEOWNERS data into Sourcegraph
TrackingIssues.Body:
What we want:

- [ ] Ingesting ownership data from external systems
  - [ ] The Own service should opaquely consult both data sources
  - [ ] Ingestion works like that: You specify a codeowners flavored document per repository, and can attach it to either all commits or commit beyond a certain point (TBD)
- [ ] Expose ingested CODEOWNERS data as well, similar interface as the CODEOWNERS git file
- [ ] CLI interface to add CODEOWNERS entries to files

Items to work on:
- [x] API schema
   - https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/47821

TrackingIssues.Title: Introduce client performance observability to the Sourcegraph application: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve

The client's observability is lacking. We use Sentry for error tracking but do not have client [RUM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_user_monitoring) and performance monitoring instrumentations. It means that we do not understand how real users use our client application in terms of performance/interactions. It limits our ability to assess and prioritize areas for improvement. We are forced to do it based on limited customer development sessions, anecdotal evidence, or one-time testing without the ability to monitor trends and proactively jump on the most impactful issues. Instrumenting our client application can reveal user issues that couldn't be observed or diagnosed any other way.

## Measure of success

- [ ] We have a robust process for client performance observability on the client, and it's documented in the handbook. 
- [ ] Relevant services and tools are configured to enable the client performance observability. 
- [ ] Auto instrumentations for client performance monitoring are configured. 
- [ ] The collected amount of app telemetry data is sufficient for running queries, visualizing traces, and asking questions about specific user interactions.

## Solution Summary

- [x] Evaluate the relative advantages and disadvantages of available performance monitoring tooling and determine the best path forward
- [ ] Enable continuous web application bundlesize monitoring.
    - [x] #39736
    - [x] #39735
    - [x] #39737
    - [ ] #39738
- [ ] Basic OpenTelemetry integration to enable gathering performance metrics immediately so that we can identify bottlenecks across the application and make targeted improvements that improve core workflow. 
    - [x] #39273
    - [ ] #39276
    - [x] #39274
- [ ] Integrate client OpenTelemetry data with backend OpenTelemetry collector
    - [x] #39277
    - [ ] #39278
- [ ] #39275
- [ ] Instrument the web application.
    - [x] #40467
    - [x] #40468
- [ ] Implement client OpenTelemetry instrumentations
    - [ ] #39280
    - [ ] #39279
    - [x] #39281
    - [x] #39282
    - [x] #40466
    - [ ] #40592
    - [x] #43847
    - [x] #44008
- [ ] Implement integration tests for client OpenTelemetry instrumentation
   - [ ] #43844
   - [ ] #43845
   - [ ] #43846
- [ ] Improve client OpenTelemetry events by adding valuable information
    - [x] #40562
    - [ ] #40559 
- [ ] Make targeted performance improvements to core workflow based on OpenTelementy metrics.
- [ ] Document configuration
    - [ ] #45165
- [ ] Configure OpenTelemetry backends
    - [x] #45166
    - [ ] #45168
- [ ] Document usage
    - [ ] Recommended tags and context for traces
    - [ ] Best practices for instrumenting features
    - [ ] Docs on inspecting and interpreting results in Honeycomb
- [ ] Configure event sampling
- [ ] Configure event batching to limit API calls

Artifacts:
- [RFC 722: client performance observability](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1aGsPEjC8TcWG-V6WT5oOV7AJq71nvu0_KVSmJDloiME/edit#)
- [Client observability state](https://docs.google.com/document/d/19lPGwZDdWp5R6-RdX4pGrZ4UQWslse8_UvDN2J2RlaM/edit#)

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?

Internal Sourcegraph developers

TrackingIssues.Author: Strum355
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue: improve worker observability
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Goal

Make the worker service provide more useful information that customers can provide us with to debug issues without having to engage in a sync call. High-level problems to be addressed include:

1) Difficulties in filtering and grouping logs, their sources and responsible teams
2) Complex to navigate and cluttered dashboard
4) Lack of documentation/playbooks for diagnosing issues besides a reference to the Grafana dashboard
5) ???

- [ ] #37942

TrackingIssues.Author: rrhyne
TrackingIssues.Title: Primary action button consistency (Tracker)
TrackingIssues.Body:
Our primary actions are all defined differently on all major sections of the product. We need to standardize these implementations with a single direction. 

Rules:

1.  Generally, a 'Create' primary action should exist on an entity's index page
2. In rare cases, a primary action may not exist, in which case any action should be a secondary button (for example, on the extensions page)
3. If a primary action exists, it should be a primary button
4. The label for this action should be verb + entity name

* Batch changes should add the entity name so that the button reads "Create batch change"
  * https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/27772
* Code insights should change the button name to "Create code insight" and change the button type to primary
  * https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/27616
* Code monitors should add a primary button with the name "Create code monitor" when no monitors exist
  *  It should also change the empty state button to be a secondary button
  * When a code monitor exists, the button should read "Create code monitor"
  * https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/27776


Design resources:
https://www.figma.com/file/ZzWVJSMGKYDMLbfIAqWCvX/Consistency-of-primary-actions?node-id=0%3A1

TrackingIssues.Author: umpox
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking Issue: WCAG 2.1 AA Accessibility - Fixing known issues
TrackingIssues.Body:
## Problem to solve
<!-- What is the problem and why is this an important problem to solve? -->

This tracking issue reflects the **Fixing** stage of the accessibility work that began in Q1. Today, the Sourcegraph web application does not comply with current WCAG guidelines. Our ultimate goal and measure of success is to reach (and maintain) compliance by the end of FY23 (January 2023).

## Measure of success
<!-- How will we validate/verify/know that we have solved the problem? -->
Accessibility issues within each product area have been fixed and we are ready for a comprehensive audit in Q3. The VPAT (the certification we need) is issued alongside the audit, so we want to be in the best shape possible in order to avoid paying (and waiting) for another audit. 

## Solution summary
<!-- How are we going to solve this problem? What dependencies are there? This should be a concise summary followed by a list of concrete artifacts that contain more details (for example: PDs, RFCs) -->

- Accessibility champions use [this issue template](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/new?assignees=&labels=accessibility%2Cwcag%2F2.1%2Cwcag%2F2.1%2Ffixing%2Cestimate%2F3d&template=accessibility_issue.yaml&title=%5BAccessibility%5D%3A+) (found in [How to conduct an accessibility audit](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/accessibility)) to begin fixing accessibility issues within their product areas. 
- Frontend Platform Team supports accessibility champions in auditing and fixing accessibility issues. 
- Frontend Platform Team will take responsibility for any work that spans multiple teams.
- Where possible, Frontend Platform Team will delegate work to Gitstart to minimize effort required from accessibility champions and their teams. 

Artifacts:
- #31200 
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/31475
- [Sourcegraph Accessibility Remediation Plan](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1kVinUrMukEEFfqcHS1o36ASAezHKDkSjrBiILvGuDiE/edit)
- [RFC 557: WCAG 2.1 AA Compliance Plan](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1r9W3ZvSaT_CPzzLpp0cZgcFR47Qk8pbT76ATQPiIDRk/edit)
- [Accessibility Champions](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1j0c77t5T9hlBno_htYj2Wd3RQzE02vq70l7gQvd4DHc/edit#gid=0)
- [WCAG 2.1 AA Accessibility Project Board](https://github.com/orgs/sourcegraph/projects/238/views/1)
- [How to conduct an accessibility audit](https://docs.sourcegraph.com/dev/background-information/web/accessibility)

## What specific customers are we iterating on the problem and solution with?
<!--

Example:

- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/580
-->
- https://github.com/sourcegraph/accounts/issues/278

## Impact on use cases

<!--
Describe how this roadmap item contributes to improving the customer experience for one or more of the 5 use cases and apply the relevant use-case/* labels to this issue.

For enablement projects that don't target a specific use case, describe how you expect this work to enable teams/projects that are focused on use cases.
-->
This work contributes to the overall effort to scale our business. 

## Delivery plan
<!--
The overall plan for how we are going to achieve this roadmap item. This should be formulated as a checklist of concrete steps that are kept up-to-date so anyone can glance at the issue description to get a sense of what we have already delivered and what remains.

Each item on this list is ideally a concrete deliverable with an estimated delivery date and owner, but we don't want false precision, so just document the plan to the best of your ability, even if you don't have all the steps yet.
-->

**Step 2: Self auditing (June, July)**
Teams have committed to the following deadlines for fixing known issues: 
- [ ] Frontend Platform
- [ ] Repo Management
- [ ] Growth and Integrations
- [ ] Cloud SaaS
- [ ] Search
- [ ] Code Insights
- [ ] Batch Changes - June 28
- [ ] Conde Intel

TrackingIssues.Author: slimsag
TrackingIssues.Title: Tracking issue: RFC 128: Frictionless release & upgrade process
TrackingIssues.Body:
This is a tracking issue for the implementation of [RFC 128: Frictionless release & upgrade process](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1YHYxx63jxEyLb3Hs7VnzZcASQXn3dWb6IUyQXvP2i30/edit#heading=h.rg0uspwsxz5a). The work needed to implement this RFC is tracked below and may span multiple iterations.

### 3.15

- [ ] @slimsag Investigate and propose a solution for how the Slack /release command could be implemented behind the scenes #9252
- [ ] @slimsag Implement consistent versioning for all Sourcegraph Docker images, according to the proposal in the RFC. https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/9251

### Unplanned

Bullet points below not yet planned or fully spec'd out, and may not land in 3.15. Depends on discussion with @uwedeportivo about his ideas for automating the execution of e2e/regression tests, and on the investigation above #9252

- (owner TBD) Implement the Slack `/release` command for major version releases.
- (owner TBD) Implement the Slack `/release` command for minor patch version releases.

TrackingIssues.Author: CristinaBirkel
TrackingIssues.Title: insights: strategic scoped insights: Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
[RFC](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vWxSDSbslZQFEK24rhlo8-K2sCiaaCX5PQoCqEdpI_8/edit#heading=h.4zxjk7qxn6f3)

We currently have 2 ways to scope series by repository. Either a small, (think ~10 or less from a UX perspective,) explicitly defined list of repositories, or "all repositories." At strategic sized customers, having the ability to easily scope it to a group of repositories (by using some sort of repo filter, whether that's a context or something else,) is essential. Until we understand what the functionality will be, we will use the term "strategic scoped insight" for this project.

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: Devx Buildkite-Analytics Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

Buildkite is releasing https://buildkite.com/test-analytics in beta this week. It supports out the box only Ruby RSpec and Junit test outputs. 

We need to convert the output of our tests into a format that Builkdite Analytics can parse, i.e JUnit xml reports. 

@jhchabran TODO update this ticket if needed when the beta is released.

### Availability

If you have planned unavailability this iteration (e.g., vacation), you can note that here.

TrackingIssues.Author: nicksnyder
TrackingIssues.Title: Core Services: 3.9 tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
**Theme**: What will break with 80k repositories across multiple code hosts?

#### Required

We expect this section to grow after setting up 80k repos task is complete.

- [x] Setup 80k repos on k8s.sgdev.org #5726
- [x] Finish src-expose #5469
- [ ] Horizontally scaling indexed-search #5725

#### Polish

These are extra tasks mostly unrelated to the theme, so can slip on this milestone. However, they are generally smaller so are useful to do inbetween larger tasks.

- [x] zoekt-indexserver: wait for frontend to start #3371
- [x] zoekt: Cleanup failed shards #5300
- [x] Handle bad repositories with ref HEAD #5291
- [x] k8s.sgdev.org: symbols pod evicted #5305
- [x] Search query `repohascommitafter:"january 1 2018"` fails if you have an empty repository #5149

#### Investigate

These tasks are similiar to the polish tasks (can slip), but require some investigation.

- [x] Gitserver GC logic potentially not working #5522
- [x] Re-index all repos after `search.largeFiles` changes #4889
- [ ] GraphQL request for repository returning null #5286

This tracking issue does not include work being done for automation, which is tracked separately in #5678.

3.8 tracking issue is #5147

TrackingIssues.Author: sourcegraph-bot
TrackingIssues.Title: Pagination, filtering, sorting, searching at 2XL scale
TrackingIssues.Body:
#### Problem statement

For customers with a large number of changesets (in particular strategic customers), it's hard to manage batch changes. The current management UI has the current shortcomings:
- no pagination
- no sorting
- searching is limited

We can start by assuming that a batch change has 10,000 changesets.

#### Solution

- As a baseline, add pagination + sorting that works at 2XL scale.
- This needs studying to determine what new dimensions we need to add to filtering / searching

#### Delivery plan

- [ ] Research. Need to determine what we want to sort by (and anticipate on search/sort by metadata)
- [ ] Introduce pagination/sorting UI/logic that other Sourcegraph components can use, needs-design (estimate: 4 weeks). Would benefit many other areas: repo page, etc.

TrackingIssues.Author: coury-clark
TrackingIssues.Title: insights: Insights setting persistence migration tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan
Currently all code insights metadata is stored in Sourcegraph user / org / global settings. In the short term this is a useful tool for iteration. The long term storage location for all of this insight metadata should be in a persistent data storage and retrieved through an API.
<!--
Summarize what the team wants to achieve this iteration.
- What are the problems we want to solve or what information do we want to gather?
- Why is solving those problems or gathering that information important?
- How do we plan to solve those problems or gather that information?
-->

### Release plan

We will release the new API in 3.34 with a feature flag default-on, which can be turned off by customers in case they run into issues.

This API will be released behind a feature flag in 3.34 that will be default enabled. If the flag is disabled, Code Insights will revert to using settings as the primary storage.

When the flag is enabled, all interactions with Code Insights will occur through the GraphQL API. Any changes or updates made during this time will not be synced back to settings, such that disabling the feature flag will revert the state prior to the flag being enabled. It is also possible to enter partially broken states, where backend insights were deleted that can no longer be resolved from the Database but is still referenced from settings files.

With the flag disabled, Code Insights will treat settings files as the source of truth for insight definitions, and continue to resolve backend insight data from the database.

Insights and dashboards that were previously created prior to the release of this API will be migrated in a job that runs regularly. 

Once the API is stable and we are ready to retire the settings based storage permanently, we will do the following:
1. Retire all settings related interactions for storing insights
2. Retire the feature flag
3. Ship an out of band migration to perform a final one time pass over all settings files and migrate insights and dashboards.

At this point, it will no longer be possible to revert to using settings files for insight definitions.

### Tracked issues

TrackingIssues.Author: jhchabran
TrackingIssues.Title: DevInfra: Trial Aspect.dev Workflows Tracking issue
TrackingIssues.Body:
### Plan

  - [ ] #55123
    - If we need two pipelines, so be it.
  - Provision agents for test builds 
    - GCP VMs
  - Run the normal test job (excepted tasks that require docker) on those agents (only when we ask for it)
  - Run the normal test job on those agents (only when we ask for it)
  - Update agents so they can handle doing stuff with Docker
  - Re-use bazel cache from aspect.dev workflows if possible 
    - Tear down old cache if applicable
  - Run the backcompat test job on those agents (only when we ask for it)
    - Can be skipped momentarily
    - Ask aspect.dev support if struggling
      - How to run shell commands before the build starts?
        - bazel run something perhaps?
  - Send all normal bazel test job on those agents 
  - Send all back compat bazel test job on those agents 
  - Enable the security team to install Falco in the new agents
  - Adjust the pipeline generator and remove old code for these 
  - Write documentation + loom recording + demo
  - (stretch) make bazel-do/* work with workflows ?
  - Review observability capabilities and create new tasks if necessary 
  - Make VERSION generation work outside the pipeline generator
  - Push artifacts (images) with workflows
    - https://docs.aspect.build/v/workflows/delivery
  - Take a final decision regarding workflows go/nogo
    - It's a nogo 
      - if we can't implement this within the trial period
      - if we don't get any speed improvement 
      - if we don't get lowered costs 
      - if we struggle to support it

Issues.Author: unknwon
Issues.Title: RFC-214: Encrypt secrets in user_external_accounts, external_services, saved_searches and external_service_repos
Issues.Body:
We need to encrypt existing data in `user_exernal_accounts.{auth_data, account_data}`, `external_services.{config}`, `saved_searches.query` and `external_service_repos.clone_url`.

Prior art: https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/pull/13093/files#diff-0d2a8ca7d4bdc94a4127a855a8a814b4R323

TODO:
- [ ] Come up a helper that accepts a table name, and list of columns to encrypt. #14231
- [ ] Have a background worker in repo-updater to identify rows that are not encrypted by the current `primaryKey` (i.e. search rows that do not have expected `keyHash` prefix). This would cover both cases of encryption bootstrap and future key rotation.
- [ ] Have a Prometheus metric to track how many rows are encrypted/unencrypted until we have good UI on this.
- [ ] Decide if `ConfiguredToRotate` is worth keeping given the `Decrypt`/`RotateEncryption` method now does no-op if the ciphertext does not look like being encrypted.

Issues.Author: efritz
Issues.Title: RFC 235: Find equivalent of the now useless "freeSpace" operation in the janitor
Issues.Body: Previously we stored all data on disk, which made it easy to stat to know our capacity and our used space. Now that we store data in Postgres, we need to know how to clean things out over time. But we can't as easily determine the size occupied by a single dump over several large tables. It may be a critical feature for some disk-constrained deployments with large uploads so we should do this before the 3.21 branch cut.

#### Steps to reproduce:

Customer: https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/contact/15781901/

Issues.Author: slimsag
Issues.Title: release steps: do not verify CHANGELOG entries
Issues.Body:
Our current release process https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/13374 indicates that the release captain should:

> - [x] Verify for each CHANGELOG item the following (if any item does not have these, disable it,
>   notify the owner, and remove it from the CHANGELOG):
>   - It has an owner attached to it
>   - It has undergone manual QA (and the QA was done on k8s.sgdev.org or at scale if the feature requires it).
>   - It is covered by the regression test suite

In practice I do not think this is something the release captain can, or actually does, well. Yes it sounds ideal that every change is verified to have an owner, has undergone QA at scale, and is covered by regression tests - but I seriously doubt the release captain is actually able to effectively do this. Do they look at every commit since the last release and message every author? I doubt it.

I propose removing this and leaving it up to individual teams and dev practices to ensure this has happened. We can update handbook docs to make it clear that we expect this to be done for all changes to a reasonable degree (but I think that is already assumed by most, and perhaps already documented.)

Issues.Author: efritz
Issues.Title: RFC 235: Update bundle manager to read from Postgres
Issues.Body:
This is part of [RFC 235: Move LSIF data to Postgres](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Y9p29hK8xrPUTvBdWqP9uAHDg3JLV-HCaxsbCo9-YHQ).

Update the bundle manager database layer to read from postgres, then fall back to data on disk. This should be done before actually writing to Postgres so that we can ensure that _someone_ is reading the new data instead of blackholing writes.

This issue must follow https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/13884.

Issues.Author: chayim
Issues.Title: Sourcegraph should encrypt rotate customer token encrypted data
Issues.Body: Once customers have their [key rotation token](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/14299) to Sourcegraph, we should re-encrypt their data in the background, using the new encryption key.

Issues.Author: dadlerj
Issues.Title: Show last ping data to admins on the Site-admin > Pings page
Issues.Body:
https://app.hubspot.com/contacts/2762526/company/557692623 requires offline support for Sourcegraph, and we have agreed that they will simply email us a copy of the standard telemetry, but once per month (or on some other schedule). 

This dovetails nicely with the desire to be more transparent about our ping telemetry. We have discussed in the past displaying the actual telemetry payloads to admins for full transparency, and that could solve this problem.

Proposal
* On the Site-admin > Pings page, add a box at the top (or bottom? or on another tab?) that illustrates the payload generated for the "last" ping (or if not exactly the last, some ping in the last 24 hours) that was sent.
* Add a button to the top to download that payload (similar to the download button on https://sourcegraph.com/site-admin/usage-statistics).
* Ensure that this whole flow works, even if the instance is not connected to the internet (so pings aren't actually going out). In this case, I believe we still generate the payload, but the post to sourcegraph.com fails, so just make sure everything is sequenced correctly...

Issues.Author: efritz
Issues.Title: tracking-issue: Display partially nested items
Issues.Body: The current behavior of nesting tracking issues doesn't work unless they are tagged in the same milestone. A feature tracking issue should not be required to be tagged in the same milestone as the parent as long as they share some issues/prs that _are_ tagged in the root tracking issue's milestone.

Issues.Author: macraig
Issues.Title: Code Intel - LSIF Indexing CNCF effort tracking
Issues.Body:
Our goal is to make our best effort with the tools we have today to index as many repos as possible to give CNCF a great code intel experience. This issue will serve as a central point to track our efforts for this project.

- [x] Index all Go repos by 2020-10-05

- [x] Index all C++ repos by 2020-10-05

- [x] Index all Typescript repos by 2020-10-05


Related issues:
[#14318](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/14318)
[#14343 ](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/14343)

List of repos and their status: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/125x9ayF7irnQGnWSwRg5nFoU23fsIt37bIeBmpjYNBY/edit#gid=0](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/125x9ayF7irnQGnWSwRg5nFoU23fsIt37bIeBmpjYNBY/edit#gid=0)

Issues.Author: ryanslade
Issues.Title: RFC 211: User added external services on Cloud should clone newly added repos on first sync
Issues.Body: When user owned external services are created on Cloud they are synced ASAP however the repos themselves are not cloned until they are accessed. Instead, we should clone and index them on first sync as this is a much better user experience.

Issues.Author: efritz
Issues.Title: RFC 201: Write a JSONC index configuration format parser
Issues.Body:
This is part of [RFC 201: Auto-indexer build configuration](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NPQs1s814LZjNXjPuavqC1N7hZR192DNtmSBmAeH9UY).

Write the datatypes for the index configuration as well as unmarshalling routines to convert from JSONC to these types.

Issues.Author: efritz
Issues.Title: RFC 201: Create index record based on configuration file
Issues.Body:
This is part of [RFC 201: Auto-indexer build configuration](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NPQs1s814LZjNXjPuavqC1N7hZR192DNtmSBmAeH9UY).

If a repo contains an index configuration file, this should be read and used instead of the canned configuration published for _any_ repository. This may result in many index records per repository as this will respect roots, of which multiple can be defined.

Issues.Author: ggilmore
Issues.Title: dhall: generate separate yaml files for each "component" instead of one large one
Issues.Body: need a wrapper and dhall expressions

Issues.Author: efritz
Issues.Title: LSIF uploads fail with abbreviated OID
Issues.Body:
Uploading LSIF data with an abbreviated OID produces an error from src lsif upload:

```
failed to enqueue payload: pq: new row for relation "lsif_uploads" violates check constraint "lsif_uploads_commit_valid_chars"
```

This is the wrong error to display - we should be validating the hash before attempting to insert it. Best implementation would be able to disambiguate an abbreviated OID into a full one, as we need to ensure that the commit exists first anyway.

Issues.Author: efritz
Issues.Title: RFC 235: Document minimum time required to be spent in 3.21
Issues.Body:
We need the users to spend at least as much time in 3.21 as it takes to migrate all of their SQLite data into postgres.

- [x] Create a distinct, self-documenting log message
- [x] Call out this message in the docs (along with a fallback way to check for running services)

Issues.Author: slimsag
Issues.Title: run "e2e regression tests" in CI once/day, even if they fail all the time
Issues.Body:
We should be able to run the e2e regression tests described in our release process https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/issues/13374 in our CI pipeline:

> - [ ] Run regression tests:
>   - [ ] Follow [README.md](https://github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/blob/main/web/src/regression/README.md) to set up your e2e environment. 
>         Run the tests from the `web` directory. A more complete set of env vars can be found in this
>         [1password](https://team-sourcegraph.1password.com/vaults/dnrhbauihkhjs5ag6vszsme45a/allitems/gm5dfflq6sfclmotneuayfdj5q) entry.
>   - [ ] New Sourcegraph Docker container:
>     - Run the initializer: `E2E_INIT=true SOURCEGRAPH_BASE_URL=http://localhost:7080 yarn run test:regression -t 'Initialize new Sourcegraph instance'`
>     - Run the regression test suite: `SOURCEGRAPH_BASE_URL=http://localhost:7080 yarn run test:regression`

Actually having these _pass_ is going to not be likely possible in 3.21, but we should aim to have them running (even if they fail all the time) in CI once per day.

https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/web/src/regression/README.md

>     - Run the regression test suite.

There has to be a better way we can reduce the number of manual steps here, maybe using Pulumni or some other form of scripting for this. Let's investigate and find possible opportunities, even if we don't get around to actually implementing them in 3.21.

Load a source file in Sourcegraph, and mouse over an element to get a code intelligence popup. 2. Move your mouse away to dismiss the popup. 3. Leave the page alone for 5 minutes. 4. Issues.Author: efritz
Issues.Title: RFC 235: Do not mush data together in the server deployment
Issues.Body:
Right now the code intel and frontend database is the same in dev (on purpose) and in the server environment (incidental). Because people actually use the server environment and would need an upgrade path to compose or kubernetes, we need to ensure that we don't allow any _real_ (non-local/non-dev) instance from using the same database.

We should update the server startup to ensure that are two databases (in the same postgres) container, and that it works with fresh and existing postgres data.
